PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully calls for; the establishment of a parliamentary inquiry into the Family Law Act.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Company Tax Collection System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's Budget decision to change the company tax collection system will be a crippling blow to many small businesses, already suffering as a direct result of the Hawke Labor Government's high interest rate policy.
The earlier remittance of company tax payments to the Government will substantially reduce the cash-flow position of thousands of small businesses.

Many small businesses will be driven under as a result of the Government's decision-unable to find funds for both tax commitments and new stock, only able to borrow at record high interest rates and unable to claim any tax relief on such borrowings to meet their tax commitment.
The Government's proposed changes to the company tax collection system has only been introduced as a greedy grab for more tax revenue.

The small business community would prefer the Government to completely abandon the proposal rather than make only minor alterations to the original Budget decision, which are not likely to alleviate the situation to any significant extent.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469,274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Peace Tax Trust Fund Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
At present all Australians, including those who conscientiously object to war and the preparation of war, are required by law for a portion of their income tax to be spent on military use.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;

That you support the Peace Tax Trust Fund Bill 1989 which has been presented by Western Australian Independent Senator, Jo Vallentine. This Bill does not propose that anyone be permitted to withhold tax, but that the law should be changed to allow conscientious objectors to divert the military portion of their tax into more positive and socially useful programmes.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Ownership and Control
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned notes that the level of foreign ownership and control of Australian assets is of concern to many Australians.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled,
(a) establish a register of foreign ownership
(b) limit foreign ownership of real estate
(c) control foreign investment in Australia so as to protect the national interest
(d) increase the powers and resources of the foreign Investment Review Board
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bell, Kernot, Lees and McLean (from 112, 42, 186 and 164 citizens respectively). and

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act and Child Support Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That serious injustices are occurring daily due to the operations of the Family Law Act and the Child Support Act.

Your petitioners therefore humbly ask that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to call as a matter of urgency for a comprehensive inquiry into the Family Law Act and the Child Support Act.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Schedule Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government urgently alter its disastrous decision to cut back the Medicare schedule fee for 24 hours medical clinics, which has resulted in the closure of these necessary services in the neediest parts of the Adelaide metropolitan area, and placed even greater pressure on overloaded public hospitals in those and nearby areas.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

The speeches read as follows-
BROADCASTING AMENDMENT BILL 1990

This Bill represents the first stage of legislation to reform the operation of broadcasting regulation. It replaces a similar Bill which was introduced in the other place on 1 November 1990 but which lapsed when Parliament was dissolved.

This Bill and a package of efficiency reforms that I propose to introduce later in the current sittings represent useful interim measures to address some immediate deficiencies in the Broadcasting Act 1942. However, the Government remains fully committed to the wider reform of this Act, and work is proceeding well on the main reform package. I expect to announce the results of this later this year.

The Bill gives the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal access to more appropriate remedies in cases where a commercial radio or television licensee does not meet the basic suitability requirements that are currently applicable to a licence. It also includes amendments to:
- confirm that the Minister can initiate, and the Tribunal can hold, joint inquiries into the grant of a licence for a supplementary or an independent commercial FM radio service in a regional area;
- allow aspirant public broadcasters to transmit sponsorship announcements when conducting test transmissions; and
- allow public licensees to broadcast community promotional material.

Before turning to the detailed provisions of the Bill, I will briefly remind Honourable Senators of the framework for reform of the Broadcasting Act laid down late last year. We are addressing seven key areas and the scope of the Review remains as outlined by the Minister on 1 November last year.

First, future broadcasting legislation must serve the explicit policy aim that there be no more regulation of industry than is necessary to support stated objectives. The current legislation casts a very wide and complex regulatory net. In seeking to address all aspects of broadcasting it can also extend regulation to non-broadcasting communications services, and indeed to other commercial activities. Future legislation will need to be more closely targeted.

Secondly, we are examining the regulatory needs and implications of new electronic communications services and service delivery methods. Where new services are different from broadcasting, they should not be subjected to regulation aimed at broadcasting. We need a regime that encourages initiative and service development and facilitates the innovative use and development of technology. But, of course, where any particular service amounts to mainstream broadcasting, then we must ensure that it is regulated as such, regardless of whether it is ultimately delivered from radio transmitters, from satellites or by cable.

Thirdly, we are examining the need for reform in the broadcasting planning processes. We intend to provide a more transparent process that also provides for proper commercial and public accountability. We need a framework within which technology, and especially the radio frequency spectrum, is allocated and used efficiently and equitably. We need to avoid unnecessary second-guessing of commercial decisions or commercial outcomes.
Fourthly, we are continuing to examine options for further reform in the area of ownership and control regulation.

Fifthly, we are examining reform to the processes of licence allocation, review and renewal in order to enhance efficiency and to streamline processing. We will, of course, retain arrangements for public accountability on the part of broadcasting licensees within this framework.

Sixthly, we are examining possible changes to the process for setting the program standards which broadcasters are required to observe. Whatever new arrangements are adopted, the Government will maintain support for Australian content, quality children's programming and observance of community standards.

The final area involves the future of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal as the regulatory authority in this area. Its role, function, powers and structure may require amendment to reflect changes decided on in the overall regulatory regime. It is not, however, intended to abolish the Tribunal. It is important that that body has the appropriate powers, resources and status to do its job efficiently and effectively.

In developing options against this agenda the Government's position remains that broadcasting is more than just another industry. Its cultural role means that it has special characteristics which will continue to require government intervention to ensure that undue concentrations of ownership or control do not arise in commercial broadcasting; to ensure that commercial and programming control remains firmly in Australian hands; and to ensure community responsibility on the part of broadcasters through appropriate program standards. The Government's concern does not relate only to ensuring the efficient, equitable and responsible use of the radiofrequency spectrum. Increasingly our efforts are directed to the product or service being delivered to homes or businesses, whatever the method of transmission and delivery-be it terrestrial radiocommunication, satellite or cable.
These concerns present special challenges to Government in our efforts to develop a more appropriate, contemporary regulatory regime.

The first challenge is to ensure that public interest safeguards are provided with rigour, but in a manner which recognises that, while it has these special requirements, commercial broadcasting is also a business where its participants compete at some considerable risk for commercial returns. It is therefore important that only the minimum regulation needed to meet those objectives is imposed, so as not to unnecessarily inhibit normal commercial development.

The second challenge is to ensure that essential regulation of mainstream broadcasting is not unnecessarily applied to new and emerging electronic services. Differences in the nature of services provided by broadcasting, telecommunications and publishing have narrowed significantly through their use of common technology and through the development of new and complementary services. Inappropriate regulatory restriction on some electronic entertainment and information services, on educational services and potentially on pay TV, would be likely to significantly constrain their development. This in turn could deny Australian homes and businesses timely access to the technologies and to the entertainment and information services that they have the potential to provide. However when these services converge to the point where they become de facto mainstream broadcasting, broadcasting regulatory provisions should of course apply.

The third challenge is to recognise that, in addition to its special regulatory regime, the broadcasting industry is subject to a wide range of general business regulation. It is therefore important that interaction between the two regimes avoids conflict and provides, as far as possible, a stable and consistent environment in which the industry can operate efficiently.
This Bill and the Efficiency Package to be introduced later are consistent with the objectives of the wider review.
I will deal now with the provisions of the Bill, concentrating first on the ownership and control changes.

At present, the Tribunal would be faced with extremely limited options if, after conducting an inquiry that it was required to hold, it were to find that a commercial licensee was no longer fit and proper, or no longer had the financial, technical or management capacity to provide an adequate and comprehensive service. It presently may only impose licence conditions or suspend, revoke or not renew the licence. If the licensee's unsuitability was due to the conduct or character of a person in a position to control the licensee company or its operations, licence conditions may not be an effective remedy. This is because the conditions may not be capable of affecting the influence of the relevant person on the licensee company. The only other remedies available-suspension, revocation or refusal to renew the licence-would put the service off the air.

Cessation of a service would penalise not only the licensee company, but also the viewing or listening public and other innocent shareholders and creditors. There is a need to give the Tribunal more flexible and less draconian remedies. This Bill achieves that objective.

The Bill allows the Tribunal, where it finds that a commercial licensee is no longer suitable to hold the licence, to issue specific directions to relevant parties and/or to impose appropriate licence conditions.
These provisions do not create new substantive powers for the Tribunal.

In the case of licence conditions, the Bill confirms that the existing power of the Tribunal under section 85 of the Act can be used as an alternative to licence cancellation. Similarly, in the case of directions, the Bill extends the current directions power under section 92M of the Act to enable it to be used in the event of a failure by a licensee to meet basic suitability requirements.

In some circumstances, licence conditions or directions may still be insufficient to deal with the situation. In these cases, the amendments allow the Tribunal to order divestment of relevant interests.

If a relevant interest is directed to be divested, a six month deadline will apply. By then it would have been fully established by the Tribunal, if necessary through court and Administrative Appeals Tribunal avenues, that the licensee had failed to meet the suitability requirements and that divestment was the appropriate remedy.
At this stage, the Government proposes no change to arrangements for any divestment that may be required in other circumstances, such as following a breach of ownership limits.
The Bill also provides powers for the Tribunal to impose licence conditions and to issue directions to apply pending divestment.

These powers will mirror the existing provisions that are available to the Tribunal pending its consideration of a share transaction. The purpose of this power is to enable the Tribunal to prevent actions that might adversely affect the service.

The range of licensing remedies provided in this Bill enables the sanctions of licence suspension or revocation to be put in a clearer perspective. These remedies are best used as an ultimate deterrent against repeated or serious breaches of the Act. This Bill will remove concern that such draconian actions could be taken by the Tribunal because it had no other real alternative.

At this point, I would like to refer more generally to the powers that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has long held under section 85 to impose licence conditions at any time, and, under section 92M, to issue directions pending an inquiry into an ownership transaction. In recent months, some doubt had been cast on the possible validity of the section 92M power and a possible procedural requirement may have inhibited its use in practice.

These doubts had led to calls for additional powers to be provided to the Tribunal. In the light of advice from the Attorney-General's Department, the Government now considers that the current section 92M powers are valid. There are no undue obstacles to the use of these powers, or to the imposition of licence conditions, in cases where those steps would by warranted. Accordingly, the Government is not proposing any amendments in this respect at this stage.
This Bill also proposes some minor adjustments and clarifications that reinforce existing policy and do not pre-empt the Government's ongoing review of broadcasting regulation.

The Bill places beyond doubt the power of the Tribunal to inquire concurrently into applications for grant of both commercial radio licences and supplementary licences in the same market. These amendments answer arguments that the Act may require those applications to be considered sequentially, an interpretation that could substantially delay the introduction of new, competitive radio services in non-metropolitan markets.

The Bill also will permit public broadcasters to transmit community promotional material. Presently, public broadcasters may transmit community information, which under recent interpretations, may not be promotional in nature. The Government considers that this is too restrictive and that public broadcasters should be able to promote actively genuine community events of interest to their listeners.

While the promotion of commercial sponsors will continue to be prohibited as a form of advertising, the Government is considering the implications of recent Tribunal findings (and a Federal Court decision) on these aspects, and may propose further clarifying amendments if that seems necessary. The amendment has been cast in broad terms on the basis that the Tribunal has power to make Program Standards in this area if it considers that to be appropriate.

The Bill will also allow public broadcasters undertaking test transmissions to broadcast sponsorship announcements as if they were licensed services. This will assist aspirant public groups to pay for the tests, and enable them to gauge the level of support likely to be available within the community. Any of the sponsorship requirements during the test would be an offence, and may also be taken into account by the Tribunal it comes to determining who should be licensed.

The continued growth of public broadcasting as an integral element of the Australian broadcasting system is fully appreciated by the Government and these amendments will continue to assist that growth.

I mentioned earlier that this Bill is substantially similar to one introduced last year, but not passed before Parliament was dissolved. The present Bill incorporates a number of changes arising from representations on the previous Bill. Those changes are as follows:
- The Tribunal will now have the power to extend the period of six months allowed for divestment of interests required on suitability grounds; and
- provision has been made for appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal over directions by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal under proposed paragraph 92M (1A) (b) or subsection 92M (1B).

The first change recognises that an absolute limit in which interests must be disposed of may not be appropriate in every case. However, the Government is not prepared to allow people who do not meet the suitability requirement to hold interests indefinitely. The maximum extension, therefore, is six months and the Tribunal is required to consider whether all reasonable steps have been taken to dispose of the interest before an extension can be granted.

The second change does not allow appeals against protective directions by the Tribunal. These are interim measures designed to protect the licensee company and it is consistent with the current scheme of the Act that these protective directions are not subject to appeal.
These changes respond to industry concerns while maintaining the role of the Tribunal to protect broadcasting services to the Australian public.
Financial Impact
The Bill is expected to have no significant impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
BROADCASTING AMENDMENT BILL (No.2) 1990

This Bill represents a further step in the process of reform of broadcasting regulation in Australia. The efficiency measures proposed in the Bill were announced on 20 February 1990. However, I stress that they are interim measures pending the outcome of the review of broadcasting regulation currently under way.
The framework for that Review and its underlying philosophy were outlined in my Second Reading Speech on the Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1990.

This Bill proposes a number of improvements to the efficiency and effectiveness of key areas of the Broadcasting Act 1942, particularly in respect of ownership and control of commercial broadcasting licences. The amendments are designed to:

a) change the share transaction approvals process to require Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) inquiry into, and approval of, only those transactions which result in the acquisition of a prescribed interest; in changes in actual control; or in possible breaches of the foreign ownership licence condition;

b) change the `prescribed interest' definition for television licences to exclude loan interests and to increase the threshold for shareholding interests from 5 per cent to 15 per cent, except in the case of the newspaper-television cross ownership limit which remains at 5 per cent;
c) require licensees to notify the ABT on a quarterly basis of arrangements, other than shareholdings, which give rise to actual control of the licensee;
d) clarify the definition of actual control of a company;
e) extend the maximum licence renewal period from three to five years and allow concurrent renewal inquiries of licences where the licensees agree; and
f) ensure that legitimate networking arrangements do not breach relevant ownership and control limits.

While a necessary interim step in the process of reform, these measures in no way compromise the Government's commitment to wider reform of the Broadcasting Act. Rather, they ensure that the Act continues to be workable while the complex task of crystallising policy options to minimise special and costly regulation and deliver a system of straightforward and generally applicable rules is completed.

Consistent with that objective, this package addresses a number of deficiencies in the Act which give rise to unnecessary regulation. It will bring about some immediate reductions in paperwork, time and effort, and substantially reduce the ABT's current backlog of work to enable it to concentrate on issues of real public importance. The package has been developed in close consultation with all interested parties and has general support.
I will now discuss the measures to be covered in this Bill.
Revised share transaction approval process

The present ownership and control regime of the Act requires ABT approval for every share transaction involving the acquisition of, or increase in, a prescribed interest in a commercial licence. This scheme allows the ABT to check the suitability of new owners and to ensure that any associated change in control will not adversely affect the licensee. It also provides a means of enforcing the foreign shareholding licence condition and general ownership and control limits.

The process has been a major source of investor and industry complaint. Because the Act attempts to identify all persons who might conceivably exercise control, the approval process catches many persons who are in no position to exercise actual control. Furthermore, approval is required for all acquisitions of, or increases in, prescribed interest holdings, irrespective of the size of the transaction, or of its impact on control of the licensee. The process itself has a range of automatic notice and application requirements.

This process is widely acknowledged to be inappropriate and the Bill proposes a range of measures to streamline it. The changes are expected to reduce substantially the workload on all parties to a transaction and the ABT in three main ways:
- by reducing the number of transactions requiring inquiry approval and focusing ABT resources on those transactions requiring closer attention;
- by reducing delays and increasing certainty in the current process by establishing time limits; and
- by reducing reporting requirements, consistent with the ABT maintaining sufficient information to carry out its regulatory functions.

The amendments will mean that ABT approval will only be required in three cases. First, where a person acquires a 15 per cent prescribed interest in a licensee for the first time. Second, where the ABT considers that an increased prescribed interest results in a change in actual control of a licensee. Third, where the ABT considers that there may be a breach of the foreign ownership licence condition. As a result, it is expected that up to 90 per cent of transactions currently requiring approval would no longer have that requirement.
Time Limits

The Government is, for the first time, introducing time limits for various stages of the process to reduce delays and increase certainty for the ABT and affected parties. In cases where the ABT has commenced an inquiry into a share transaction it will be required to complete that inquiry within six months of its commencement, unless the Tribunal formally extends the inquiry period. The same time limits will apply also to applications for transfer of a commercial licence. Where the Tribunal extends the period, which it could do repeatedly if necessary, the extension will need to be for a fixed period and the ABT will have to give reasons in writing for the extension. If the ABT chooses not to continue an inquiry by extending the period, the transactions subject to the inquiry will be deemed to have been approved.
Reporting Requirements

This Bill also represents a substantial streamlining in the reporting and general paperwork associated with a transaction. This includes: the complete removal of the requirement for pre-notification of share transactions; a streamlined post-transaction notice to replace applications in most cases; and removal of procedural requirements such as statutory declarations. Generally, notice and application requirements have been reduced to a minimum compatible with the ABT being able to carry out its relevant statutory functions. The aim is to reduce routine, detailed reporting under the Act and to rely instead on the ABT's information gathering powers to supplement its information base as required. For the revised process to work optimally, co-operation from licensees will be necessary, and the Government will be monitoring the outcome of the revised procedures closely.

It will also be a condition of a commercial licence that the licensee report to the Tribunal each quarter if, during that quarterly period, a person gains control of the licensee company. This procedure will enable the ABT to identify and inquire into situations of changes of actual control without having to rely on the detailed share transaction reporting arrangements under the current Act.

These revised reporting and transaction procedures have been the subject of detailed consultation with licensees and the ABT and have received strong support as worthwhile improvements to the administration of the ownership and control provisions. During these discussions, it was suggested, however, that the broader requirements for reporting of information to the ABT should be reviewed in the light of practical experience over recent years. The Department of Transport and Communications will hold further discussions with the broadcasting industry, public interest groups and the ABT to consider areas for further reform of the reporting and information provisions. This review will link with the current inquiry by the Administrative Review Council into ABT procedures.
Definition of Television Prescribed Interest

The ownership and control limits in the Act apply to a person who has a `prescribed interest' in a licence (or newspaper). For commercial radio licensees and newspaper companies, this occurs when a person acquires a 15 per cent equity or voting interest in a licensee through shareholdings. For television, however, the prescribed interest level for shareholdings is 5 per cent and loan interests are regulated under a 5 per cent `financial' (aggregate shareholding and loan) interests test.

The television prescribed interest rules were introduced in 1965 to address concern about the potential for control or influence to be exercised through loans or small shareholdings. However, the current prescribed interest level has been ineffective in achieving the intended purpose, and often imposes an excessive regulatory burden on licensees, investors in licensee companies and the ABT.

Few, if any, share and loan transactions involving prescribed interests between 5 per cent and 15 per cent confer actual control. More importantly, there are consequences for legitimate business investment. For example, it is common for investors to acquire (indirectly and unintentionally) a 5 per cent interest in a television licensee through the tracing and aggregation of unrelated shareholding interests. The ownership and control limits then apply, restricting their further investment in companies that may hold similar deemed interests in other television licences. The potential for acquiring a prescribed interest through loans has similar consequences.

The Bill, therefore, proposes to raise the prescribed interest threshold for a television licence from 5 per cent to 15 per cent, except in respect of the television-newspaper cross media limit. This recognises legitimate concerns that increasing the 5 per cent threshold could weaken the effectiveness of this cross media limit by allowing strategic newspaper investments in television licensees of up to 15 per cent (the television radio limit is already set at 15 per cent).

In 1987, this Government introduced strict limits on cross media holdings by radio and television licensee companies. Those provisions ensure diversification in the ownership in any one area of radio or television services and local newspapers. The Government does not wish to change the application of these rules through alterations in the level of interests allowable in individual licensee companies.

Consistent with other cross media limits, a person already having a prescribed interest in a newspaper will continue to be required to notify the Tribunal when acquiring a 5 per cent or greater interest in a television licensee. That person would then have a six month period of grace from the date of the transaction in which to divest excess interests.

I mentioned earlier the matter of television loan interests which are subject to regulation under the current provisions of the Act. The Bill proposes deletion of the current 5 per cent financial interest component of the television prescribed interest test and of the registered lender provisions.

Experience has shown that it is unnecessary to regulate all direct and indirect loan interests. In the vast majority of cases, loan interests do not confer real control of licensees.These provisions have been a particular source of justified complaint from broadcasting licensees and financial institutions.

Where substantial loan interests do confer a real capacity for control, those interests can be investigated by the ABT case by case. The special quarterly reporting arrangements to which I referred earlier will bring to the notice of the ABT any situation of actual control arising through loan arrangements.
Definition of `Control'

The primary concern of the ownership and control provisions of the Broadcasting Act is to identify situations where there is an actual capacity to exercise control of a commercial licence, either through control of the licensee company or through control over programming or other broadcasting operations. It is a matter for the Tribunal in administering the Act to determine whether actual control can be exercised in the particular circumstances of each case.

Related provisions in this Bill require the licensees to report actual changes in corporate control and the ABT to determine whether particular share transactions have resulted in an actual change in control of the licensee company. It is therefore considered desirable for the Act to give clear guidance to the ABT and to licensees on the meaning of the term `control of a company'. The definition of `control of a company' to be inserted in the Act is based on, and consistent with, the Federal Court ruling in Re News Corporation Ltd on which the ABT has relied in its recent decisions. The definition covers situations where a person is in a position to exercise direct or indirect `control', whether through the power of direction or restraint, over any substantial issues affecting the management or affairs of a company.

The Bill will also make it clear that, for the purposes of the administration of the Act, two or more persons will each be taken to be in a position to exercise control of a licensee (or newspaper) if an agreement, arrangement or understanding puts them in a position to jointly exercise control of a licence. This `associate' provision is intended to further assist the ABT and all parties to arrangements in setting out clearly situations in which actual control will arise. Control would not exist, for example, merely because two persons at a shareholders' meeting agreed to vote together on a single issue affecting the management or affairs of a company (such as a decision whether the company should take over another company). If, however, two persons agreed to act regularly together for the purpose of securing control, the new associate provision would apply to deem each to be in a position to exercise control.

In introducing amendments in relation to actual control of a licensee company, I should also emphasise the importance of related provisions already in the Broadcasting Act which attribute control of a licence to any person in a position to control the selection or provision of programs to be broadcast by a licensee. The existing provisions in the Act, in particular, prohibit any foreign person or company from entering into transactions or other arrangements which confer control over the programs to be broadcast by a commercial licensee. While it is a matter for the Tribunal to determine whether particular arrangements confer control, potential foreign investors in licensee companies need to have regard not only to the individual and aggregate limits on foreign shareholding interests, but also the prohibition on foreign programming control.
Periods of Grace

The current Act allows a period of grace in which purchasers or third parties to a transaction may dispose of interests which contravene the ownership and control limits. There has been criticism that, in conjunction with the system for approval of share transactions, the operation of these period of grace provisions has allowed companies to hold excess interests for indefinite periods. A practical effect of the streamlined transaction approval system which I have outlined will be to reduce the length of time during which contraventions of the limits can be allowed under a period of grace. The Bill also makes consistent the requirement that applications for extension of time must be made within the initial six month period. This remedies a previous anomaly in relation to cross-media limits which allowed repeated applications for extensions of the period of grace. The Bill also makes it clear that all reasonable efforts must be made to dispose of excess interests as quickly as possible before any extension of the six months period can be considered by the Tribunal.
Licensing and Renewal Inquiry Procedures

There are currently 273 broadcasting licences on issue which, after the initial period of grant, are subject to renewal every three years. This process is so demanding that the ABT has not been able to cope with the current workload. It has deferred renewals for periods of between 18 months and two years for up to 40 per cent of the licences due for renewal in the 1989/90 period.

In practice, the experience of the ABT has shown that it is unnecessary to review the performance of licensees every three years and that an extension to five years would be sensible in terms of practical evaluation and use of resources. Such an extension would continue to allow public interest groups and concerned citizens adequate opportunity to participate in the evaluation process.

These provisions do not prevent the ABT from examining any issue of importance which may be raised with it during the term of a licence. Similarly, the ABT is still able to renew a licence for a shorter period if it believes this desirable.

The Bill will allow the ABT to shorten licence periods, with the agreement of the licensees concerned, to synchronise renewal inquiries for licences. This mechanism will enable the ABT to consider issues common to all related licences as part of a single inquiry. Normally, this will apply to commonly owned licences or licences that have substantial programming or operations in common. Issues specific to a particular licensee would still be considered individually but in the context of a common inquiry process.

The procedure will save licensees time, effort and expense, and will enable the ABT to streamline its licence renewals by avoiding repeated inquiries into issues common to a number of other licences. Consent of affected licensees will be required before a joint renewal inquiry can be held for licences that have common ownership or programming operations.
Exemptions for Networking Arrangements

Recent legal advice indicates that arrangements between licensees who are affiliated to networks for the purposes of distribution of programming could breach the 60 per cent population reach television limit or associated cross media limits. Clearly, such arrangements between licensees are encouraged to make possible economies of scale in the production of programs and to support the Government's policy for equalisation of television services in regional areas of Eastern Australia.

Accordingly, to ensure that these legitimate affiliation agreements proceed, the Bill provides that parties to a written networking agreement, lodged with the ABT for this purpose, will be exempted from operation of relevant ownership and control limits to the extent that direct or indirect control would arise from the terms of the agreement.

In considering the means of resolving this issue, it has also been necessary to look at the effect of networking arrangements on the provisions of the Act relating to participation in the benefits of a licence to which programs are supplied. The amendments proposed in the Bill ensure that these provisions are similarly not compromised. A minor amendment to the provisions on participation in the benefits of a licence is included to exempt agreements under which a percentage of a licensee's revenue is payable to another party under programming rights agreements for performing artists or other copyright purposes.During consideration of these amendments, it was suggested that, in the context of revised provisions dealing with control of a licence, provisions in the Act relating to participation in the benefits of a licence may no longer be required. This issue will be considered further in the more fundamental review of the Broadcasting Act.

This package of measures has been the subject of detailed consultation with representatives of licensees, public interest groups and the ABT. I express my appreciation for the constructive assistance provided by all these parties. Should any interested persons or industry representatives wish to have further discussion on the effect of the detailed provisions of the Bill, I will be pleased to facilitate those discussions.

I indicated at the outset that the package of measures is an interim step in the overall process of comprehensive reform of broadcasting legislation by this Government. Further proposals will be brought forward when the results of the broader review have been exposed and decisions taken by the Government later this year.
Financial Impact
The Bill is expected to have no significant impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Patents Bill 1990 has had a very long history. Industrial property rights and ownerships have been recognised for many years. This Bill replaces the Patents Act 1952. In 1979 the then Minister for Productivity initiated an inquiry into industrial property by the Industrial Property Advisory Committee. The Committee, representing the Australian Law Society, the Institute of Patent Attorneys of Australia and the Patent Office, reported to the Government in 1984. On 28 November 1986 the Government made its response and in 1989 the then Minister for Science and Technology brought down legislation in the House of Representatives. However, as we know, Parliament was prorogued, the Minister changed, and we now have a new 1990 Bill before us for debate today.

SPEECH.PARA: By any standards, Australians have a very proud record of inventiveness, novelty and innovation and, per capita, are amongst the world leaders-and I do not just mean the Victa lawn-mower, the Hill's hoist and the photocopier.

The Patents Office is a fee for service operation, its fees cover its running costs, rent, superannuation and so on and, in addition, provides the Government with some cash input. The Australian patents system is part of an international network, and the Australian staff and leadership have a very high reputation throughout the world.

According to the second reading speech of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), the essence of the patent system is designed to encourage entrepreneurs to develop and commercialise new technology. We hope that that is what it will do. I will come back to that later. The patent system confers a limited monopoly to the grantee and, hopefully, should extend sales into export markets. The legislation before us is designed to perform several particular functions. It brings Australian inventions under international scrutiny, not just in Australia. It goes along the way towards providing a simpler piece of legislation, stated in simpler English than previously. It transfers much of the mechanics of the system from legislation into regulations. It does not change the standard 16-year patent system or the six-year petty patent system. It puts us in better shape for negotiations in the Uruguay Round of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, in which Australia is playing quite a senior role.

In the second reading speech of the 1989 Bill, the then Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, made a point which I think is worth repeating. When discussing what we were doing with patents legislation, the Minister quoted the Industrial Property Advisory Committee report as follows:
More specifically, this implies seeking-

to gain increased benefits for Australians by fostering indigenous innovation, and utilising the international patent system in developing export markets to improve Australia's international competitive position;
to reduce unnecessary social costs including those resulting from undesirable anti-competitive conduct involving patents; and
to improve the efficiency of the administration of the patent system with consequent reduction of direct costs.

That is what the legislation is all about and I believe that is the way that we should all pursue the matter. Later on in the second reading speech, the then Minister raised the question of New Zealand. I would like the Minister, when closing the debate, to give some information on where we now stand on the New Zealand question. In the next few years our cooperation with New Zealand is going to be essential.

I referred to the transfer of some of the previous legislation into regulation. I have been here long enough now to always be a bit suspicious when things are taken out of an Act to be dealt with by regulation. In the meantime, I am unable to give the Bill my total support, but I will wait and see. If the legislation is changed by legislation, then we know we can thoroughly cover it in this place after full and proper debate. However, I hope that the regulations will not be used to do things that may be difficult by amendment, but I trust the officers and I presume that we can rely on being fully informed.

The process of getting a patent inspected currently takes about 20 months, but with increasing efficiency the office hopes to have this reduced to its goal of approximately 18 months, despite the fact that there was, according to the last available figures, a 6.5 per cent increase in lodgment. In 1988-89, according to the annual report of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, there was a 6.5 per cent increase in lodgment. Page 49 of the report indicates that, in 1988-89, 16,915 standard patent applications were lodged and that there had been an increase each year since 1984-85, when 15,720 applications were lodged.

I, along with many other people who used the technology information service, greatly regretted its cancellation in 1986. It had become an integral part of the process for innovative people to use, and it was supported by the Australian Science and Technology Council and the Industrial Property Advisory Committee-but it was axed just the same.

The granting of a patent is one of the most misunderstood things that I have ever come across. I know so many people who have saved and slaved and paid and waited until, ultimately, the joy of their life materialises in the form of a piece of paper granting them a patent for this or that. There it stops; that is when the disappointment starts. The piece of paper informing one that one has a patent is not the finish of anything; it is only the beginning. The stage is then reached of wondering whether what has been done has a use, whether it can be put to any commercial production, whether there is a market for it, how it can be sold, how it can be funded, whether it can be exported and all these sorts of things. Regrettably, a huge proportion of the patents currently taken out never materialise into fortunes for the inventor and, in fact, many of them never achieve anything beyond gathering dust in a little workshop somewhere. That does not mean that we should not proceed with the job of inventing and innovating, far from it. I still give encouragement to people with that sort of bent wherever I possibly can.
Patents Bill

In conclusion, I return to the opening of the Minister's second reading speech in which he talked about encouragement for entrepreneurs. I urge him and all members of the Government to stop and look at where Australia's industry and exporters are right now. Over the entire period of this Government so far, Australian industries have been absolutely hammered. We have an artificial dollar fix, a crazy interest regime, an inbuilt accord disaster, rising costs and conditions, all matched by falling productivity as a result. From that we get falling exports, rising imports, a huge growing and mortifying overseas debt and a Treasurer who steadfastly goes full steam ahead for the rocks. Why does the Government believe that the small and dwindling industry and export section can go on being milked and strapped more and more so that the non-productive and non-exporting group are preserved from facing the realities of life?

Recently I raised the same question on another Bill, and I do so again now. I would like to know what difference the value of the Australian dollar makes to the non-productive, non-competitive majority of Australians-whether we work 30 or 40 hours a week, whether there is paternity leave, superannuation, two-hour lunch breaks, eight weeks annual leave or anything else. I talk about people such as hairdressers, accountants, members of parliament, union officials, estate agents, bakers, bankers, insurance salesmen, shop assistants and so on. But if one buys raw materials overseas or sells goods overseas or competes with imported goods, one is in trouble. The accord nonsense has the built-in effect of ensuring that the competitors are always getting further and further in front and the Aussies further and further behind. Is this the Government's plan?

We have many very competitive and very productive industries, but a Patents Bill will not save them. I look at the heartbreaking list of great Australian inventors and inventions that have gone and are going overseas as a direct result of Government policy. I did not say `in accordance with Government policy', but I do say `as a direct result of it'. I also say that unless there are fundamental changes to the underlying problems of our economy-not just tinkering with some of the peripheral spin-offs-the trend will not only continue but grow, and grow rapidly.

The inventors that I know want to do their thing in Australia and I implore the Government to rethink the position. We are not discussing the question of efficient and inefficient industries. This applies to all industries. I draw the Minister's attention to the very alarming list of whole industry groups that we once had that have now gone-probably forever. The list of replacements in the high technology, sunrise, whiz-bang variety is, I regret, very small. That is the problem to be addressed. Even though this Bill has taken since 1979 to produce, it will not change the real problem; it will just draw attention to it. The inventors of Australia want to stay here and the Minister's assistance would be most welcome. However, the Opposition does not oppose the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In common with the Opposition, the Australian Democrats do not oppose the broad thrust of the Patents Bill. However, I would like to make some general remarks before dealing with one particular aspect which concerns us greatly. We seem to be living in a time when more and more considerations are based on what is profitable, not necessarily on what is right or socially desirable or in the best interests of human beings, either as individuals or as a society.

SPEECH.PARA: As a party, we would certainly prefer to see intellectual property developed within publicly-funded institutions, obviously much more widely publicly funded than at present, and in which the intellectual property resided with the public interest and not with private individuals. This suggests a totally different arrangement from that anticipated in this legislation, and indeed in the way in which intellectual property has been regarded in the past.

I make those introductory remarks to indicate the broad thrust of the direction in which we would like society to move. It would mean a much greater level of funding for educational and research institutions. The research institutions themselves, being publicly funded, would hold the property rights in discoveries for the good of the public in general, and not merely because they were commercially advantageous to an individual or company.

However, that is not the position we now have before us. We live in a world where, increasingly, considerations are made on commercial grounds. The idea of patenting intellectual property and exclusively owning it for a period of 16 years to the exclusion of others-except by payment of a fee-is the way in which we are currently organised. This Bill, as Senator Archer said, merely attempts to upgrade the provisions of the Patents Act which have been amended and modified over many years and which have become unsatisfactory in many practical details.

There is one area, however, in which this Bill is remarkably silent and on which the Democrats and many in the community have a great deal of concern. I refer to the area of patenting biological materials. It seems to us that there are two factors which lie behind this aspect of the legislation. One is the fact that science and the results of scientific research are moving on much more quickly than can be understood either by the legislators in this place or elsewhere-certainly by the lawyers outside who have to interpret these very difficult questions. Secondly, I believe that we are living in a society in which we are becoming blunted as to the important distinctions that need to be made between ethical matters and matters of commercial interest. This Bill, which is silent on the question of the patenting of biological material, essentially accepts the view that biological material is like any other material-to be patented and exploited for commercial gain without any consideration whatever of the ethical dimension which underlies it.

It is important for the Senate to recognise that there is no difference-I emphasise that: no difference whatsoever-between the genetic material which serves to describe, at the unicellular level, a human being, a bacterium, a plant, a tiger or an ant. The code which describes the sequence of amino-acids which go to make up the proteins is identical throughout all species. We now know that it is possible, and indeed it is being done, to take bits and pieces of that genetic code from one species and do things which nature was not able to do previously-that is, to take that genetic material from one species and put it into another totally unrelated species and produce something which is absolutely novel.

That poses very significant ethical questions, some of which I hinted at in a question to Senator Button last year. The crux of Senator Button's reply was that the patenting of a creature, for example, containing a large number of human genes, indeed approaching a human being, would be left with the Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Offices. I used that example in the question to draw out, first of all, the power of the technologies which are now available and also the inadequacy of the legislation, as we have it, in dealing with that very important question.

I do not personally for a moment draw any distinction between human genes and the genes of any other creature because, as I have indicated, they indeed use a common vocabulary to describe the sequence of amino acids which go to make up the proteins which determine each individual animal, plant, bacterium or whatever. Indeed, one could find in human beings many genes which have remained essentially unchanged throughout millennia, throughout billions of years, which subserve very similar functions in human beings, bacteria, plants and so on, and which have very similar genetic codes. So one should not, in our view, draw any sharp distinction between human genes or human genetic material and genetic material which comes from any other source.

We are concerned, therefore, that this legislation is silent on the question of the patenting-that is, the exclusive ownership for commercial gain-of genetic material which derives from any source whatsoever, including, indeed, the artificial manufacture of genes. It is now possible to take the individual bases which make up the triplet codes in DNA and to put them together to construct an artificial gene. That gene could be incorporated into an animal, a plant, or, indeed, a human being. Under this legislation, that material would be patentable and could, therefore, be exclusively exploited for commercial gain for a period of 16 years.

We believe that the ethical considerations which underlie this matter are of such a nature and are so far-reaching that there should be an exclusion of the patentability of any of this genetic material at all. In the committee stage, we will be seeking to move an amendment to the clause which deals with the definition of patentable material, clause 18, to exclude from the ability to patent a gene or genes, whether derived from cells or chemically synthesised. That covers the situation in which a gene may be artificially manufactured in a laboratory; a genome, or, in other words, the complete genetic description of an individual cell or a complete animal, one which was intact or one which had been added to or deleted; the altered organisms which might arise as a consequence of the inclusion of those genomes, whether natural or altered, and those organisms would cover humans, plants, bacteria, viruses-in fact, the whole range of living forms; and the progeny which would arise from those genetically engineered organisms.

However, we are not at this stage seeking to prevent the patenting of the techniques which may be used to manipulate genetic material, because, as I have indicated earlier, we do not have any moral or ethical objection to a discovery of the life processes and a discovery of how genes might be interpreted into different enzyme systems in cells and so on. It is the commercial ownership and exploitation of that information and the exclusive nature of that commercial ownership and exploitation which we find extremely abhorrent. It is far worse than, say, taking one's grandmother and commercialising her in prostitution. This is prostituting the very substance of life, prostituting for commercial gain the very essence of life itself. We find that extremely repugnant. It is an ethical question of the highest order. Yet this Bill, because of its silence on this matter, simply seeks to allow that that genetic material is of the same form as any other material-as a piece of machinery, a piece of chemistry or a clever idea which might be fed into a computer. We find that idea repugnant. It indicates an incredible degree of blunting of ethical perception on the part of those who have framed this legislation.

We in Western society have for a very long time, for many millennia, taken a view which we are now recognising as one which is leading to very severe problems in our relationship with the environment. The Judaeo-Christian philosophy, which underlies our view of the world, is one which appears to have led us to a situation in which the rest of the world is out there simply to be owned and exploited by human beings. We are now recognising that that view is not sustainable in the long term and that we need to adopt a different view, a view in which we recognise what many of us, particularly those from a biological background, have known for a long time-that is, that we are part of a living world and we cannot distinguish between ourselves and rest of the environment. We are part of it. We are dependent upon it.

The idea that we can continue to own and exploit the world-that is what underlies what I am saying here-simply advances that old idea which has led to so much destruction and which, if unchecked, will lead to the destruction of life forms on this planet, including our own. This is not inconsistent with the pattern which has been pursued by Western industrial society, particularly over the last several hundred years, but it is certainly inconsistent with the present recognition that it is that very attitude which has to be changed.

Of course, some practical consequences flow from this. They are that we will see increasing conflict between the public interest, as expressed through ethical and moral considerations, and the commercial interests, as expressed through those who own the genetic material. For example, it would now be quite possible to produce crops which are resistant to a range of pesticides by incorporating into those crops genes deliberately manufactured which render the crop, such as a wheat crop, resistant to 2,4-D. Those crops could then be heavily sprayed with material such as 2,4-D to eliminate weeds and other competitive plants.

That may well seriously reduce the genetic base on which future generations will need to make judgments about those genes which are desirable and necessary for a continuation of life, or a continuation of ecological systems, in particular localities. Those judgments will be made increasingly more difficult if the powerful multinational companies have commercial ownership of the very genetic information on which that technology is based and from which it is applied. It will be increasingly difficult to make those sorts of judgments with those very powerful commercial interests intruding their particular short term financial interests against the interests of the public good.

It has been argued that unless we allow the patenting of these sorts of materials we will fall behind the rest of the world. We have been through these arguments in the past with relation to the plant variety rights legislation. It was argued that without plant variety rights Australia would not be well served with new plant varieties. The technologies which have come along in the last couple of years far and away exceed in power the technologies which were available when that legislation was debated.

I point out, as I think the Democrats did on that occasion, that Australia has been particularly well served by publicly-funded research into new plants and new plant varieties. The plants remaining are in public ownership for public use. If people who have defended plant variety rights-particularly those on the Opposition benches-reflect for a moment, they will recognise that in varieties of crops such as wheat, barley, oats and those sorts of things, organisations such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, and the Waite Agricultural Research Institute in South Australia, have served this country extremely well with the development of new plants and new plant varieties. They have done that without having the heavy hand-the inhibitory hand-of commercial ownership and exploitation placed across that research work in such a way that what is done, or what is used, is determined not by the public good but by the good of the company which happens to own the patents and is able to exploit them.

I repeat that we will be introducing an amendment, with a number of consequential amendments, to this legislation in order to bring it into line with what is now known about the capability of genetic engineering and genetic manipulation. As it has taken from 1979 until now-and a review-to get this Bill codified into an up-to-date form in a legal sense, it is a pity that this legislation does not recognise the power of the new techniques which can be used for genetic manipulation. If we pass the legislation in its current form we are passing a piece of legislation which is really out of line with the most recent thinking. In other words, we are simply repeating the errors of the past. The previous legislation had become out of date. This legislation will be out of date when it is passed unless it takes into account this very important area defined in our amendment and excludes it from patentability.

If the Senate sees fit to pass this legislation without accepting this amendment, I can only say that it indicates either or both of these two things: an incredible ignorance on the part of my fellow senators in not understanding the extreme power which modern biological methods have conferred on us; or an incredible degree of blunted perception of the ethical dimensions of what they are legislating when they are prepared to hand over for commercial ownership, commercial exploitation, and exclusive commercial gain, the very substance of life itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague Senator Archer said at the outset, we will not be opposing the legislation but there are some important points that should be made. The first is that the progress of patent law reform over the last decade has been painfully slow. Again, as my colleague pointed out in his speech to the Senate, it was the Fraser Government that initiated reform in this area in 1979 when we ordered a review of patent law.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industrial Property Advisory Committee (IPAC) conducted that review and reported to the Parliament in 1984. It recommended three basic things: firstly, that the present standard patent term of 16 years ought not to be altered, and indeed the Bill leaves that period in place; secondly, that the procedures for granting extensions to terms of standard patents be eliminated and, thirdly, that patents be tested for novelty against disclosures in documentary form anywhere in the world and not merely against prior disclosure in Australia. The Committee also recommended a general streamlining of procedures.

It was not until November 1986 that the Government finally released its response to that report of 1984. More than two years elapsed before the Patents Act 1952 was amended. Now we are told that this Patents Bill, which has come more than six years after the 1984 report, is an attempt to implement parts of that report. Thus the progress of reform in this area has been far too slow, given the pace of technological advance and the dire need to improve our balance of trade.

The substance of the Bill is simply that it replaces the Patents Act 1952 as the principal piece of legislation dealing with patents in Australia. We would like to refer particularly to two of those changes. Firstly, under the Bill patent applicants who apply for a standard 16-year patent will have their inventions tested for novelty and inventive step against disclosures anywhere in the world. We think that this is an important test to introduce. This development, which is welcomed, will make it more difficult for a standard patent to be granted and should be helpful in multilateral trade negotiation forums. More importantly, this development ensures that domestic innovation is not inefficiently protected from competition.

Secondly, procedural matters are to be left to regulations and these are to be completely redrafted. This always creates concern because it means that such matters are subject to less scrutiny by the Parliament than if they were dealt with by an Act. The rationale is, supposedly, that this will make the Act more streamlined. However, as I said, it could mean that the substantial changes that may be made will not be scrutinised in a very full way by the Parliament as a whole. Thus we will have to be vigilant to ensure that the Government does not interfere with the property rights of patent holders without referring that matter to the Parliament. As a matter of principle, the legitimately acquired and inviolate rights of property ownership should not be altered by government without consultation with the parties involved and reference to full debate by the Parliament.

It was interesting to hear some of Senator Coulter's remarks. He puts forward a standard socialist approach and likes the idea that we should somehow nationalise individual intellect. This whole system has failed in eastern Europe, where it is now realised that people need incentive, that the concept of private property is important-indeed, essential-in developing prosperity for individuals within nations. A quick visit to eastern Europe should help Senator Coulter understand that nationalisation does not aid either the inventor or the consumer. Patents are a form of private property. They are intellectual property and as such are, of course, subject to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) round, with which I will deal later.
It was Mark Twain who said:
A country without a Patent Office and good patent laws is just a crab and cannot travel any way but sideways and backways.
Twain's sentiments may very well be true but it is questionable whether the current system of intellectual property laws has been proven to encourage domestic innovation.

As I said, patents do confer property rights. But it is when a government seeks to enact intellectual property laws for some sort of public benefit reason which can allegedly be derived from industry protection that problems are bound to arise. The rationale for the granting of patent rights must be for the enforcement of private property rights rather than the protection of domestic innovation as a matter of industry protection. I think the Government has not delineated clearly enough the basis on which it brings forward this legislation. If research innovation and ideas are to be stimulated by the method of conferring private property rights, this is fair comment; but if this is done by way of bringing forward some additional form of protection for industry, such a course is not sustainable.

It is noteworthy that the 1984 IPAC report concluded that overall the costs of the patent system, if one were to use that public benefit test, probably exceeded the benefits. However, it pointed out that patent systems operate around the world and that patents are an important part of our establishment of private property rights.

Patents are designed to recognise the rights of creators of new ideas. Traditionally, they have been granted for a certain period to allow the originator of that new idea to gain a return for his efforts through the sale of his rights or through the direct production of the product which is patented. Once defined, these rights should be as inviolate as any other form of right to property.

If a government were arbitrarily to alter people's rights to property which was previously acquired, such as land, those owners would legitimately be outraged and seek compensation. Rights to intellectual property are just as important. This means that intellectual property law reforms should be handled just as studiously. But, as I pointed out earlier, intellectual property laws may be used as in a way to prevent competition and to stifle free trade.

In his dissenting statement to the 1984 report, Professor Lamberton recommended a package of reforms which included a reduction in the patent term to 10 years, some freeing of important competition and, among other things, a weakening of professional patent attorney monopoly of costly advice. This creates a good deal of problem in some areas, where government regulation and, indeed, inefficient bureaucracy means that the processing of the patents takes so long that the benefit of the patent is lessened quite considerably. This, of course, is the case with regard to dealing with patents concerning pharmaceuticals, which have to go through a very cumbersome procedure. I had hoped that when legislation concerning therapeutic goods was introduced we may have seen a streamlining of the process rather than added bureaucracy, which much of this legislation introduces.

I believe that Professor Lamberton made some worthwhile points. Rather than extending patents terms, which many protectionist countries and advocates would encourage, we should perhaps look to shortening the term where there is no intervention by government bureaucracy. This would lessen the worthwhile nature of the patent while at the same time recognise the property rights of patents holders.

As I said, it is important to look at patent rights in the context of the current Uruguay Round of the GATT, which is rapidly coming to a close in November. At the outset, I think it is important to say that if there is no satisfactory outcome for agriculture in the GATT, there will be a lessening of protection by the European Community of its common agricultural policy, a lessening of protection by Japan, particularly in respect of rice, and a lessening of protection by the United States by way of its farm Bills.

Carla Hills, the United States trade representative, whom I had the pleasure of meeting with in the last few weeks, understands that very well. On the other hand, I had talks with the European Commission, and I do not think it understands the position at all well. Mr McSparry came up with a proposition that somehow the new piece of European-speak, the AMS, which is an averaging of all subsidies that are paid with regard to agriculture in the European Community, should be used. He proposed that these could be lessened by 30 per cent over a 10 year period and made retrospective to 1986. Having asserted that they have already reduced that protection by 15 per cent, I do not think, bearing in mind the attitude of the European Community, that the final outcome in November is looking at all hopeful.

The reason that I have mentioned that attitude is that protectionism is alive and well in some countries that would like to see free trade in other areas, including the question of intellectual property. Indeed, through the previous US trade representative, Clayton Yeutter, the United States contends that lax respect for intellectual property is costing American firms some $US61 billion a year. He threatened that if there were not a satisfactory outcome for intellectual property from the GATT Round, bilateral action in respect of those countries not willing to agree to their position would be taken. Indeed, he has stated that he may remove them from the generalised system of preferences, which often means the exporting of goods without duty. With the Uruguay Round coming to an end, we have to see a lessening of protection talk. We have to see a true commitment to free trade so that all the world may benefit.

Senator Coulter spent a good deal of his address dealing with proposed amendments which literally appeared on my desk prior to my rising to speak. Senator Archer did not have time to look at them. We usually expect little consultation from the Australian Democrats, but on this occasion there was no consultation whatsoever. Therefore, there has been no opportunity to appraise the merits of the arguments which they may put forward. In accordance with that, the Opposition will not be supporting the Democrats' amendments. However, as I said at the outset, we will not be opposing the legislation.
