The speech read as follows-
DRAFT TABLING SPEECH FOR HIGHER EDUCATION REPORT
Mr President, I present the report of the Senate Committee on Employment, Education and Training on `Priorities for reform in higher education'.

This matter was referred to the Committee in May 1988. The Committee's involvement at that time with its very successful inquiry into `Education for active citizenship' prevented it from focusing on the higher education reference until April last year. In one respect, this delay proved an advantage since it allowed time for the implications of the Government's White Paper on higher education, which was released in July 1988, to be fully appreciated by the higher education sector.

The Committee received a large number of written submissions to this inquiry-277 in all-from a variety of sources including higher education institutions, academic staff associations, students unions, private sector organisations, individual academics, and State and Federal governments. It held public hearings in Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Brisbane and Canberra, gathering evidence from a total of 80 witnesses who included university Vice-Chancellors, student union leaders, employer representatives, individual academic staff, officers of State and Federal departments, and representatives of the National Board on Employment, Education and Training. The Committee has set out its conclusions in this report. I wish to comment briefly on some of the key points we have made.

Mr President, higher education has been a prominent issue on the agenda of public debate in Australia in recent times, particularly since the release of the Government's Green Paper on the subject in late 1987 and the subsequent White Paper in 1988.

The Committee believes, however, that much of this public discussion-including that generated by the White Paper-has missed certain points of major significance. The debate has focused almost exclusively on the way the higher education system is to be structured and how it will be controlled. In the Committee's view, a central consideration in reforming higher education must be the quality of the education which students receive-what they learn, how effectively they are taught, and how well their education prepares them to live and work in a world of rapid change. The preoccupation with the way the system operates, rather than what it is intended to achieve, has excluded these issues from the agenda of the debate. The Committee believes it is time to correct this imbalance.

What are the qualities which graduates from Australia's higher education institutions should possess? In the first place, the Committee believes, they must be highly competent in the sciences and the arts underlying the practice of their profession-they must have a solid grounding in the skills which their profession requires. But their education must go well beyond this narrow base. They must also have a sound understanding of the society in which they are going to practise-its history, its literature, its social structure, and its social mix. In addition, they should possess a critical capacity which enables them to look at problems from a number of differing perspectives-to analyse, to gather evidence, to synthesise, and to be flexible, creative thinkers. They also need to develop a capacity for `lifelong learning' to enable them to keep abreast of the world of rapid change in which they will live and work. And finally, they must be good communicators, orally and in writing.

How well are our institutions meeting these criteria? The Committee believes that Australia's higher education system has generally maintained high standards in the technical aspects of the curriculum. Universities and colleges have produced graduates entering fields such as engineering, medicine, law, architecture and science who are usually well grounded in the knowledge and skills essential to the practice of their professions.

The evidence suggests however that, on the other criteria I have mentioned, the quality of higher education courses is less than satisfactory. The Committee believes that Australia is producing graduates who are often not familiar in any disciplined sense with the society in which they are going to practise their chosen profession; who, all too frequently, are not critical, analytical, creative thinkers; who are not sufficiently attuned to the need for lifelong' learning; and who are not good communicators. The Committee reluctantly finds itself in agreement with a view expressed by one witness that the undergraduate curriculum is tending to produce highly trained, highly competent technicians who are undereducated in the broader sense of that term.

Part of the problem has to do with the narrow and specialised nature of much higher education. The Government's White Paper states that `We wish to be a rich society intellectually, culturally and economically' and that `higher education is a primary source of the skills we need in our cultural, artistic, intellectual and industrial life'. The evidence provided to the Committee indicates that the sense of breadth and intellectual richness suggested by these words is conspicuously absent from the education received by the vast majority of undergraduates. There are too many Economics graduates who have an inadequate understanding of History; too many Science graduates who have no knowledge of their own society; too many History and Politics graduates who have no idea of how national budgets are formulated let alone about the major scientific ideas or arguments of the age; and too many Engineering graduates with no concept of the likely impact on society of the technology which they control.

The Committee is not advocating the mere addition of a thin veneer of cultural enrichment to a technical education. Nor is it arguing that students in the humanities and social sciences should be given a smattering of scientific knowledge. The aim is not to produce graduates who are better equipped to answer questions in a quiz about cultural or scientific topics. As A. N. Whitehead remarked, `culture has nothing to do with accumulating scraps of information' and `a merely well-informed man is the most useless bore on God's earth'. The change which the Committee is advocating is more substantial, and much more closely related to the real needs of graduates in a rapidly changing society. The aim is to produce graduates who are well equipped for both life and work-better citizens and better professionals.

My Committee believes this will require a careful re-examination of the nature of higher education courses. It will not be achieved by law courses which reflect a narrow range of social concerns, economics courses which ignore the political, social and psychological context of many economic problems, engineering courses designed solely to produce technical experts, or humanities courses which remain insulated from the world of science and technology.

Mr President, this question is crucial, but the Committee does not believe that the reforms required in the higher education sector relate only to the content of courses. At stake also is the way in which students are taught. A key issue for the Committee in this inquiry was the quality of teaching in institutions of higher education. The Committee gathered substantial evidence on this topic and concluded that one of the most serious weaknesses of Australian universities is their failure to encourage and reward excellence in teaching.

The Committee recognises that some academics care deeply about their teaching role, and put a lot of time and effort into it. It also recognises that some institutions have taken steps in recent years to give greater recognition to the importance of the teaching function. The evidence presented to the Committee suggests, however, that in many cases only lip-service is paid to the importance of teaching and that in too many instances the crucial factor in decisions concerning appointments, promotion and tenure is research performance and the number of publications produced. The position was well summed up by one academic staff member whom we spoke to who said that in his own faculty the productivity measure is a nice econometric equation which comes down to the number of pages published.

The Committee believes it is imperative to rectify this situation. As Sir Zelman Cowen argued in an address at the University of Tasmania earlier this year, teaching is central to the role and purpose of the university at all levels, and particularly at the undergraduate level. In our attempts to become what the Prime Minister has called the `clever country' this fact will become more and more important. If we are to harness fully the resources of our higher education institutions and ensure that the recent reforms arising from the White Paper have not been made in vain, it is imperative that this central teaching role of higher education institutions be recognised, reinforced and rewarded-not just through pious statements of principle but in real, substantial, concrete terms. Policies within institutions and at Government level must be geared to this end. My Committee's report suggests ways of addressing the problem.

Finally, I wish to comment briefly on the concept of `lifelong education' which is also an important theme in my Committee's report. Recent years have seen a dramatic increase in the numbers of adults undertaking some form of further education. A research study in 1986, aptly titled A Nation of Learners, found that 6 out of every 10 Australians have taken at least one adult education course in their lifetime. The growth in interest has been rapid and seems to be accelerating. For every course taken in the mid-1950s, two were taken in the mid-1960s, six in the mid-1970s and fourteen in the mid-1980s. Employment related courses are the most common, though courses for leisure purposes are not far behind.

I believe that this trend reflects a radical change in outlook-a rapidly growing realisation that it is no longer realistic to expect people to store up sufficient education during their initial vocational education to last them through a lifetime of change.

My Committee believes this trend to be of particular significance for higher education in Australia-for two reasons. First, we believe it is becoming less and less credible to assume that higher education can be provided once and for all at the end of schooling. This is particularly true in the sciences and technologies where the pace of change, and the contemporary knowledge explosion, make it more and more difficult for courses to provide a detailed coverage of any field of knowledge and to keep up with latest developments.

The second reason directly relates to the problems in the higher education curriculum which I have referred to. As I have indicated, a major weakness of undergraduate courses in Australia is the tendency towards excessive narrowness and specialisation. If this problem is to be overcome, institutions and professional organisations must recognise that, while the basic degree course can lay a solid foundation of knowledge and understanding, it can no longer hope to teach students everything they are likely to require in the course of their professional careers. Instruction in many specialist topics will need to be deferred to a later stage, and the emphasis will often need to be placed on key principles rather than on a detailed treatment of every topic. In addition, more stress will need to be placed on giving students the skills and enthusiasm to continue their education after graduation.

If this approach is adopted, it will be possible to reduce the excessively specialist emphasis of many higher education courses and create room for the broadening of course content which my Committee is advocating. Institutions will then be in a position to design courses which place more emphasis on widening social and cultural horizons and promoting capacities such as critical awareness, adaptability and creativity. They will then be in a position to remedy the defects in the higher education curriculum which my Committee has identified.

If this is to occur, however, undergraduate courses must be able to proceed on the assumption that students will have access to continuing education opportunities. Many institutions already provide a range of continuing education courses for both professional and general education purposes. There are also increasing opportunities for continuing education in other areas of the education system and in business and industry. My Committee recognises and applauds this trend but believes that these efforts need more encouragement and also need to be placed on a solid and systematic footing. In short, the higher education system-at both institutional and government level-must adjust to the rapid contemporary trend towards a `learning society'. My Committee's report suggests ways in which this process might be facilitated.

Mr President, higher education is a large and complex topic and my Committee's report covers a wider range of issues than I have addressed today. The remarks I have made have highlighted some of the central themes of our report-themes which I believe are vital to the future of higher education in this country. My Committee believes that we must come to terms with the basic purposes of higher education and look carefully at the nature and quality of the courses which we are providing. It is time to move beyond the current preoccupation with the mechanics of the system and ask what we are really achieving. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of explanation, I have incorporated my speech so that other members of the Committee will have more time to speak to the report. At this stage I will confine myself to some brief remarks. First of all I wish to acknowledge the cooperation and work of the Committee members. As honourable senators know, it is an all-Party committee. Our recommendations and the whole report, in fact, were unanimous. I must say that in the six years or so that I have been in the Senate, I have not had as much pleasure in putting together a report. The relationship that we enjoyed as members of that Committee was extremely good and productive and I think a testimony to the type of people who volunteered to be on that Committee. I might say, also, that we are extremely grateful for the work of the secretariat, led by Derek Allan. This report was a very wide-ranging report and was an extremely difficult one to put together.

SPEECH.PARA: I might just indicate, as a brief observation, that our aim as a committee was basically to create a debate about the fundamentals of higher education in this country, to review our national goals and assess our achievements. Basically it was to place education in the forefront of the public mind. I guess in an age where economic and fiscal news dominates our media, our report is, in fact, extremely timely. I think, on the whole, we have achieved our goal of putting education at the forefront of the minds of many people in this country, and I finish on this basis: no-one, I believe, has summarised the efforts of this Committee better than Mr Sam Lipski in the Bulletin of 17 July 1990. His column begins:
Tertiary studies get the third degree.

At $19.95, Priorities for Reform in Higher Education is somewhat more expensive than the average paperback but it deserves to be a best-seller at the Australian Government Bookshops which began stocking it last week-especially among those who want the talk about Australia as the Clever Country to be more than just talk.

Teachers at universities and high schools should pin the report's conclusion on their walls and, even if they throw darts at it, read what it says: The Committee believes that Australia is producing graduates who, all too frequently, are not familiar in any disciplined sense with the society in which they are going to practice their chosen profession, who are not critical, analytical, creative thinkers, whose education does not provide the basis for adequate flexibility, who are not sufficiently attuned to the need for `lifelong' learning and who are not good communicators. In short, Australia is producing highly trained technicians who are undereducated in the broader sense of the term.

That is from part of the report. There are many other areas in which the report has some very positive statements to make about the progress we have made in higher education in this country. But, above all else, I believe that we have, as all Senate committees should be able to do on major issues, created a forum for public debate, and I thank very much the members of the Committee who helped me, as Chairman, to achieve that goal. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks of the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training in his speech just now, and I look forward to reading the material that he has incorporated on which I cannot, of course, pass any remark at this stage. I, too, regard this report, Priorities for Reform in Higher Education, as one of the important reports of the Senate committee system.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak now after 12 years as a member of this Committee. At some stages, I have been Chairman of the Senate Committee on Education and the Arts, and I happen now to be Deputy Chairman of this successor committee, the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. I will be retiring this week, after these 12 years serving on the Committee, because of my need to concentrate on foreign affairs and defence. It is, therefore, all the more reason why I place on the record the enormous value that I have seen in this Committee. I have enjoyed every day of my involvement with it and with all the colleagues who have served with me, the secretaries and research officers. As I look around the chamber, I see other senators who have contributed to perhaps some 20 reports.

This report, Priorities for Reform in Higher Education, is one of the better reports in that series to which I refer. The one that I feel most proudly associated with is the Committee's report, Towards a National Language Policy for Australia. Having said that, endorsing the committee system of the Senate, endorsing this particular Committee, and endorsing these particular remarks, let me turn to the outrageous comments of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins. When this report was made public he said that it revealed `everything that is wrong with the Senate Committee process'. He had the gall to say that this was senators reporting `the shallow observations of unrepresentative people as fact'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an insult to the Senate.

—It is an insult to the Senate, Senator Reid, and it is the arrogance of this Minister that he can make such a sweeping statement about the Senate. It is unparliamentary. It may well be against the privileges of this House for a Minister to make such an unforgivable denigration of the important processes of this chamber. It shows his ignorance and his foolishness and stupidity. Instead of accepting the bona fide evaluations of eight senators who have looked at 200 submissions evaluating higher education in this country, and instead of reading and understanding what the report says, within minutes of it being made public he comes out with this fatuous and stupid remark.

SPEECH.PARA: The Ministers of any government serving Australia should respond to the bona fide reports of their colleagues in parliament and to important Senate inquiries. It goes without saying that whilst there have been a number of structural changes to provisions for higher education in the last three years while Mr Dawkins has been Minister for Employment, Education and Training, there has been insufficient concentration on the quality of higher education. This need was expressed by those who took part in the White Paper debate and it has been expressed by members of parliament, both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate.

To complement the debate that was already, with such controversy, ensuing about Mr Dawkins' White Paper reforms, we believed it was timely and right, and we had the endorsement of this Senate to conduct this inquiry into other priorities for reform in higher education. It was thoroughly undertaken. I believe, and I still stand by, the recommendations that are in the report. It would have been very much to the Minister's advantage if he had sat down and read the report, referred it to his Department and referred it to the Higher Education Commission of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET) so that there could be a proper and considered response to what we have found.

What did we find? There are five areas that we particularly addressed. In the few minutes remaining to me now, I will refer to the three most important areas: these are, first, the quality of undergraduate higher education, in particular; secondly, the need to reward good teaching in our universities and colleges; and, thirdly, the need for a new focus and additional resources to ensure that there are facilities for adult continuing education in this country. If the Minister thinks that we have `arrived', that we are fully on top of these three areas, let alone the others referred to in this report, and if there was any reflecting impertinence in the Higher Education Council of NBEET-I have no evidence that there will be-they are sadly ignorant. We will never have `arrived' with regard to these matters.

The Committee has taken into account the fact that there have been advances in these areas. There is more recognition of teaching, along with research, amongst our academics. Of course there have been reforms-very notable reforms by some universities-to give recognition to those academics who have excelled in teaching, so that they are promoted to senior lecturer, reader or professor, and their teaching performance has been, in some cases, taken into account along with their research record. But it is still a sad situation that insufficient recognition is being given to the teaching capabilities of academics. We are wanting to give a comprehensive regard to teaching. We are wanting the Higher Education Council and NBEET-indeed, each of the higher education institutions-to systematically give the assurance that they are giving that recognition to teaching. If we are to lift the quality of higher education and to become increasingly a cleverer country, there will need to be excellence in the teaching in those institutions.
I return to the first area-the quality of undergraduate teaching. We say in our conclusions:
The Committee believes that Australia's higher education system has generally maintained high standards in the technical areas of the curriculum.

None of us are here to denigrate Australia's higher education record. This country is looked to by many people in other countries as being amongst those giving a first class higher education, both at the undergraduate level and, especially in certain areas, at postgraduate level.
The point we are wanting to add is this:

The Committee believes that Australia is producing graduates who, all too frequently, are not familiar in any disciplined sense with the society in which they are going to practise their chosen profession, who are not analytical, creative thinkers, whose education does not provide the basis for adequate flexibility, who are not sufficiently attuned to the need for `lifelong' learning, and who are not good communicators. In short, Australia is producing highly trained technicians who are undereducated in the broader sense of the term.

We are ringing an alarm bell. We are saying it is not good enough to have graduates who are good technicians with good specialist knowledge. They need to relate to the whole perspective of Australia to see how their profession fits in to a full social and political perspective and to have the flexibility and the creativity to apply themselves to the continuing needs as they go through their profession.

Undergraduates themselves feel that they are underprovided in this way. Many academics have told us so. Some of the wisest of those who have made submissions to us have made that observation. That is why we bring a particular focus to this. I commend all of the recommendations of the report. I believe that NBEET and the Higher Education Commission should-I believe they will-take them seriously and act upon them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as a member of the Committee that contributed to the production of this extremely significant report. Senator Teague has addressed some of the content of the report. I wish to be fairly brief in my remarks and, essentially, to react to the responses that have been made public by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins.

SPEECH.PARA: For reasons of pressure of work in other areas I have just resigned from this Committee, but for the last three years as one of its members I have taken part in what I consider to have been one of the most productive and positive experiences of a senator. It is an excellent committee. It has committed itself to important areas of reference. It has reported thoroughly and very professionally. I am sorry to be leaving it. I am particularly sorry to be leaving it in a context where such a vitally important report has been rebuked so superficially by one of the key members of the community to whom it was directed-namely, the responsible Minister.

All honourable senators will be aware of the fact that in the last three years, particularly under the architecture of Minister Dawkins, significant structural changes have been made, as Senator Teague has cited, to higher education in this country. They were made very quickly and made very politically by the instruments of Green Papers and White Papers.

Many people in Australia, particularly those who have been involved in higher education for decades, believe that these reforms were railroaded, rammed down their throats and, in fact, were not in receipt of adequate attention by the community at large. They cite Minister Dawkins as being a master strategist in having achieved things so quickly by a process, disguised as a form of participation, called Green Papers and White Papers, which calls for public response, and then substantially ignoring it.

The Committee believes that the public response should be acknowledged for what it is-a responsible, informed response. We have faith in Senate committees as being a vital process by which the public can respond to legislation and administration. That is the importance of this new committee process that we are putting in place.

The Minister responsible for administering one of the most important social processes in our community-education and higher education specifically-has, I believe, responded shamefully, superficially and egotistically to a vital document that emerges from that sector of the community charged with responding and called upon to respond.

We have seen Green Papers and White Papers swiftly achieving major structural change. Members of the Committee asked, `What should we put alongside that as a complementary process of comment and feedback from the community?'. This document was deliberately intended to be a complementary process.

The report said some stinging things to the responsible Minister. That is what it was intended to do. It was provocative. That is what it is intended to be. It is responsible to be provocative; it is responsible to be constructive; and it is responsible to report to the Minister what those who take part in this process feel about its quality. The Minister has reacted in some respects predictably, but absolutely shamefully and superficially. He has denigrated the people who took part in the process, he has denigrated the Chairman and members of the Committee and he has described us as senators who have nothing better to do than to waste our time by sitting in committees and deliberating over these serious processes. His response is shameful. The Senate as a whole needs to react to what the Minister has said about the process of reporting and those who take part in it, let alone its content, which is the area for which he has responsibility on the behalf of the nation. I believe that the Senate must take very seriously the reactions of Minister Dawkins in relation to this report.

Finally, I congratulate those who took part in the process, particularly the staff who spent so much time on it and carefully and objectively synthesised and reported the 200 submissions that were received. The vice-chancellors of all the universities reacted. People in high places taking part in designing and implementing higher education in the country presented submissions to us. Those submissions were then processed and refined in a very responsible manner and now take the form of a vitally important report to this Parliament which has been shamefully and superficially denigrated by the responsible Minister.

Senator Aulich as Chairman has made his comments. He has cited what I believe is a very significant analysis and comment from journalists. I commend this report to the Senate for its serious attention. I direct the attention of honourable senators to the shameful and sad reaction of the Minister, which really deserves our very serious response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the comments of my colleagues. In my first three years in parliament I, like Senator McLean, have found my service on the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training one of the most rewarding experiences. The Committee started off by looking at active citizenship. In the first part of our three years we brought down a report which, I believe, has raised the public's awareness of Australians' lack of understanding of the political process and also made recommendations which have gone some way in addressing that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee then turned its mind to trying to raise the debate about the goals of higher education, at a time when university people and people in the college sector were feeling rather beleaguered and embattled by the structural changes which, as Senator McLean has said, have been forced upon them. It is not often that a Liberal senator can rise in this chamber and agree with the Australian Democrats and Labor senators. On this occasion we are all speaking with the same voice.

Senator Aulich had to withstand an amount of battering from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins. If I were to believe in Freudian psychology-which I do not-I would analyse Mr Dawkins's response as some sort of guilt response because of what he has done to higher education in this country. When we pointed out some positive things-they were constructive suggestions-I believe that his reaction was one of guilt. He knows what he did to the Australian education system for his own personal promotion. Mr Dawkins said that this report revealed everything that was wrong with the Senate committee process. He claimed that it had taken two years to produce and relied on a few observations of a few unrepresentative persons and, in some cases, malcontents around the country. I am sure many people who made very positive submissions to our Committee would have been appalled at the Minister's attitude that they are malcontents.

Certainly we met some people who were feeling pretty pained and upset about what has happened. They had been forced to merge, and they felt that there really had not been a proper discussion about the real issues in education. Many submissions were constructive. They mentioned concerns about teaching, about our lack of use of technology, about adult education and, in particular, about transferability of skills. If we are to make Australia a clever country, then the graduates coming out of our universities need to have research skills in order to update their knowledge. By that I do not mean experimental research; I mean that they should have the ability to use a library to update their knowledge. This was an area where people felt there was a great lack.

Mr Dawkins said that this report was totally useless and a waste of time. I have a few letters that were received by the Committee. I have picked out the letters from the universities, from people whom we are claimed to criticise. One letter states:
I believe that the report is a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate on higher education in Australia, and I hope that our comments will be of service to your Committee.
Another letter states:

I have read with great interest the press excerpts such as . . . producing skilled barbarians . . . appalling teachers . . . and the failure to reward excellence in teaching. You are 100% correct in too many cases!!
To quote another letter:

Thank you for sending me a copy of `Priorities for Reform in Higher Education'. Despite the bucketting from on high, it is a good report. Indeed, I suspect it is because it hits the mark that some critics have been stung. There are issues in it that regrettably the Government and AVCC seem not to want to hear about.
A further quote:
Based on media reports your Committee on higher education has made a welcome contribution-thanks on my part.
Politicians do not often get letters like this. I quote from another letter:
I enjoyed reading this report and thought that many of its recommendations were very valid.
I remind honourable senators that all these comments are written by university people. Another letter from some students says, in part:

We find this report to be particularly relevant to our student organisation, one of our important functions being monitoring the quality of education and the effects that many Dawkins reforms have imposed on our institution.

Those comments come from Mr Dawkins's malcontents. I believe that this report has raised important issues and that our recommendations were reasonable and achievable. From the response we have had from universities and people in the community, I believe that the report will go a long way to changing and raising the standards of higher education in Australia.

I am a member of Monash Council and, as the Senate has been told before, I think I am the only Federal politician who has been the subject of a merger! As a member of Monash Council, I have seen some of the problems that have arisen as a result of mergers. I do not believe that some of these mergers will create increased opportunities for students or will have the effect of reducing costs. In fact, I have great concerns about how we are going to unscramble the egg that Mr Dawkins has scrambled.

I believe that the report raises an issue that was raised by Prince Philip in a graduation address at Monash at which I was present. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report, entitled Priorities for Reform in Higher Education, from the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training deserves more than the brief comments that I am able to bring to the debate now, but I wish to make a few specific points about it. I welcome and agree with many of the aspects of the report. It raises some important and disturbing issues about the quality of higher education in Australia and deserves serious consideration. Unfortunately, as has already been mentioned, the report, immediately upon its release, was subjected to a poor level of political debate. I think Senator Teague's criticisms of that debate are well founded. It is time to concentrate on the public debate which the report deserves and which can and should take place.

SPEECH.PARA: The report recognises major deficiencies in the quality of graduates and describes the quality of teaching at some universities as `appalling'. While the report comes up with some very good recommendations about the essential qualities for graduates, it fails to prioritise sufficiently its recommendations for funding in the current climate and to take into account the enormous resources we need for education in this country. Education is now a question of funding and, as a first step, it is essential to determine which recommendations should be a priority for funding.

The question to be answered is: what is quality teaching? It is time to tone down the politics of the debate and have sensible consensus and discussion involving students, academics, administrators and the Government, such as it is, in this area. We should be aiming for consensus. A consensus approach is needed to determine what quality teaching is and what it means in real terms. We must knuckle down to this debate, disregard the politics and, as Senator Patterson suggested, if it is possible to have a cross-party consensus, take advantage of that opportunity.

Teaching quality is the priority which should become an essential basis of our education system. We have been told that equity is one of the bases, that it is a principle supported at all levels. Teaching quality is the next thing that we should be aiming for. Funding should be directed, for example, to staff development and rooms for small group teaching.

The report talks directly about the quality of education in terms of the individual, while the White Paper discussed education for the country. The two things are compatible. For Australia to become the clever country, we cannot ignore the needs of both. It is important to stop the politicking and get on with establishing proper priorities for funding.

Senator Teague quoted from a section of the report, which also attracted my attention, addressing the capacity of graduates to function in society. The Committee was right to highlight the community's concern about the skills with which graduates leave university. I will not repeat the section from which Senator Teague quoted, but honourable senators will know which one it is. The report provides the basis of the further debate that should take place. Whether or not the Minister wants to hear the debate that the Committee has brought forward, the community has been itching for it to take place.

Another recommendation from the report that appealed to me was recommendation No. 7: that the Commonwealth establish a permanent policy focus for adult and continuing education at the national level and that a mechanism should be established within the structure referred to in the report. The recommendation further said that a leadership role should be assumed for continuing education and that policies should be developed appropriate to the emerging educational needs of Australian society. The section that attracted Senator Teague's attention is the section which asks for people to graduate from university with the capacity to function in society. This recommendation also makes the point that we need to be looking at adult and lifelong education-in other words, the skills to function as a citizen throughout one's life.

The report indicates that, while tertiary institutions have been undergoing massive restructuring associated with amalgamations over the last two years, the real needs in terms of quality education have been largely ignored. In other words, the amalgamations have been taking place perhaps for some other reason and the real needs in quality education do not seem to form part of that process. It is disturbing that amongst the submissions to the Committee is a report that as many as 40 per cent of university graduates lack skills in basic literacy. I wonder how those skills are defined; but even so, literacy is still a concern.

The Australian Democrats believe that the grassroots needs of students at each institution are more relevant than administration as the starting point to achieving quality in higher education. That is a point that the Democrats will continue to make while the community debate on this matter is taking place. We believe that the provision of on-campus and off-campus student accommodation is urgently needed for students attending rural and smaller campuses in particular.

This report is very important in raising these particular matters for community discussion. I am pleased that the report has served as a catalyst for that discussion, and I hope that it is not put aside in the process which can and should take place.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 31 May 1990, and on behalf of Mr President, I lay on the table the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled Debt Recovery under the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlement Act, together with the transcript of evidence which was presented to Mr President on 28 June 1990. In accordance with the terms of the resolution, Mr President has authorised the printing and circulation of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

On 28 June 1990 the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs presented to the President, in accordance with the order of the Senate of 31 May 1990, its report entitled Debt Recovery under the Social Security Act and Veterans' Entitlements Act. The presentation of the report concluded a 14-month inquiry into the methods by which the Department of Social Security (DSS) and the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) recover amounts paid to people under their respective legislation in excess of the amount to which those people are actually entitled.

The title of this report is rather turgid, but it raises some significant matters. It deals with the law that impacts on the vulnerable members of our society and on the disadvantaged-the people whom the community must treat fairly if we are to be a truly humane and decent society. For that reason I think the report is worthy of considerable attention. It draws attention to matters affecting the quality of life of people who, as it were, are at the bottom end of things.

The Committee received more than 40 submissions from the departments concerned, welfare rights groups, community legal centres, banking organisations and law societies, as well as from numerous private individuals. The Committee held public hearings, at which not only institutional witnesses appeared but also people with personal experience of the way in which current procedures impact on social security clients. Evidence was given as to the mix of structures by which social security benefits and benefits under the Veterans' Entitlement Act are delivered to recipients. We also heard evidence from the recipients themselves. Perhaps at this stage I should congratulate the present occupant of the Chair, Senator Colston, on his well-deserved appointment as Deputy President.

At the outset of the inquiry I told the Senate that the Committee was interested in examining both the recovery of overpayments and the impact on people whose benefits were reduced by the departments as a means of recovering such overpayments. I indicated that the inquiry would address such matters as the methods that the departments used to recover overpayments-the use of garnishee proceedings, the processes by which they collected information and their implications for privacy, and the write-off and waiver of debts.

I also said that the Committee would examine the proposed code of conduct to govern banks' dealings with the accounts of social security beneficiaries, and in particular the operation of section 249 of the Social Security Act, which provides that pensions, benefits and allowances paid under the Act are to be `absolutely inalienable'. This is a high issue.
The Committee has dealt with these issues in the report, which contains 29 recommendations, some of them quite detailed. I draw some of the more important recommendations to the Senate's attention.

In regard to the debt recovery process, the Committee in chapter 2 of its report sets out the processes by which debts are recovered. Both DSS and DVA submitted that the primary cause for overpayments was a change in the client's circumstances, with a consequent effect on the benefit payable, and a failure on the part of the client to notify this change of circumstances. Both the Acts involved impose an obligation on the client to notify the relevant department of such changes of circumstance.

Various groups and individuals submitted that administrative error on the part of the Department was a major cause of overpayments. In contrast, DSS told the Committee that such error was present in only a `small proportion' of overpayments. The Department was unable to provide the Committee with any figures on this. In any event, various people submitted that such overpayments should not be recoverable. It was pointed out that this was the situation under equivalent legislation in the United Kingdom. When this proposition was put to representatives of DSS, they said that under the Australian legislation DSS had an obligation to recover all overpayments, which were debts due to the Commonwealth. DSS told the Committee that if a debt arose clearly, unequivocally and for no reason other than administrative error and had been received by the client in good faith, the Department could waive such a debt.

The Committee has recommended that, where a client receives an overpayment in the honest belief that it is part of his or her entitlement, and the overpayments arise because of administrative error or unreasonable administrative delay, recovery procedures should be undertaken only if the department concerned shows that recovery would leave the client in no worse a position than he or she would have been in if the correct payment had been made.
Notifications of overpayment

Chapter 4 of the report deals with the methods by which DSS and DVA notify clients of overpayments. Many of the submissions commented unfavourably on the letters sent out by DSS in particular to advise of alleged overpayments. The Committee noted that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs had identified similar problems in a report published in May 1989 and had made detailed recommendations for `a revised set of standards for the content of letters to clients'. In this report the Committee endorses those recommendations and makes some detailed recommendations of its own in relation to DSS's standard letters.

The Committee has recommended that such letters should be clear, precise, non-intimidatory and in plain language. The DSS's efforts to achieve this goal have been to date `manifestly unsuccessful'. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended that the Government in its response to the report should specifically address what steps have been taken to achieve the improvements called for.
Administrative Charge

Subsection 246 (3) of the Social Security Act allows DSS to recover an amount additional to that owed to the Commonwealth for an overpayment under the Act. This is said by DSS to be an administrative charge, though welfare organisations and others refer to this charge as being penalty interest. The charge is applied where a debt in excess of $50 is not repaid within three months of being notified. It is calculated as 10 per cent of the balance owing plus $15, with the maximum charge allowed being $515.

DSS told the Committee that it was meant both to provide an incentive to repay the debt quickly and to partly offset the cost of administering the debt recovery system. Welfare agencies told the Committee that it impacted most harshly and inequitably on those people least likely to be able to repay a debt within three months. Accordingly, several submissions recommended that it be abolished.

Both points of view have merit. However, as suggested by the National Secretariat of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT), the Committee has recommended that the Act be amended to provide that the charge be not levied where a person has, within the three month period, made arrangements with DSS to pay the debt.

Recovery of overpayments from welfare recipients still receiving payments is usually effected by withholding a portion of the continuing benefit. The current rate applied by DSS is 14 per cent of the basic entitlement plus 55 per cent of any additional income within the allowable income limit plus 27 per cent of any income received over that figure. Submissions to the Committee objected to these levels of withholding. Given the subsistence level of pensions, the Committee has recommended that a standard level of no higher than 10 per cent of the client's entitlement be withheld.

Several submissions expressed concern that child-based payments such as family allowance were withheld in order to recover overpayments. The Committee found that this was inappropriate. Children should not be made to suffer as a result of a parent's obligation to repay a debt. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended that such payments should be exempt from withholding.

The Committee looked at the use of garnishee powers by which overpayments can be recovered from former clients. It was suggested that, since DSS was not required to prove an alleged overpayment before recovering it in this way, it gave the Department a special advantage over other creditors. Indeed, it was pointed out that, under South Australian law, garnishee proceedings were not permissible. The Department of Social Security has assured the Committee that garnishee proceedings were used as a last resort, being applied only when negotiations with the client had failed. The Committee has accepted this. Nonetheless, the Committee recommends that garnishee rates be limited to no higher than 10 per cent of the client's after tax income.
Appeals

Chapter 7 of the report deals with the methods by which people dissatisfied with departmental decisions to raise and recover overpayments can appeal against those decisions. The Committee has made several recommendations about the procedures governing appeals, namely that:
when notifying clients of an overpayment, DVA advise them of the ways in which recovery decisions can be stayed pending the determination of the appeal;
the practice of DSS members sitting on the SSAT be discontinued;
section 182 of the Social Security Act be amended to enable the SSAT to affirm, vary or set aside the Secretary's decisions under section 162 of the Act-the garnishee power;
the SSAT be given the power to stay the operation of a decision, to recover an overpayment pending the outcome of an appeal against that decision;
section 195 of the Social Security Act be amended to clarify the status of orders made under it prohibiting the disclosure of evidence given to the SSAT; and
people appealing to the SSAT be advised by it to the extent to which information disclosed in the course of proceedings before it can be used in criminal proceedings.
Independent Advice

In chapter 8 of the report, the Committee deals specifically with the need to make skilled and dedicated advice available to clients of the welfare system. This advice needs to be independent so that when, for example, DSS makes `discount' offers to debtors those people can, as the Committee also recommended, take advice on whether or not to take up the offer.

The Committee has noted that DSS officers can be placed in the position where their duty to the Department is in conflict with their duty to advise clients on their legal position and on how to protect their interests. Welfare right units and community legal centres are much better placed to advise such people. Accordingly the Committee has recommended that the Government provide funds to such bodies and to allied organisations to enable them to provide competent independent advice to those relying on the social security system for relief. Prevention is better than cure and the cost of funding these bodies may well be offset by savings resulting from disputes being resolved at an early stage.
Financial Institutions and the Social Security System

In chapter 9 of the report, the Committee discusses the role of banks and other financial institutions in the social security system. This discussion traverses such matters as the direct crediting of benefits to clients' accounts, the withholding of benefits by banks to meet shortfalls in other accounts and the code of conduct being negotiated between the Government and the banks to regulate the ability of such institutions to do this.

The Committee considered the meaning of `absolutely inalienable' in so far as pensions, benefits and allowances paid under the Social Security Act are stated to be absolutely inalienable pursuant to section 249. The Committee has been unable to reach any conclusion on the meaning of the phrase, stating that it was for the courts to make an authoritative determination. However, the Committee has raised doubts about the voluntariness of the direct credit scheme, which may in turn involve questions about the legality of banks using social security payments to offset debits in other accounts.

This report addresses great and pressing problems. As was pointed out time and time again in evidence, the people who are liable to repay overpayments, however they arise, are usually those least able to repay them. These people are often vulnerable and they need to be handled with care and compassion. At the same time there is a need to recover debts to the Commonwealth. A balancing act must be undertaken. In discussing the relevant issues in this report I hope that the Committee has assisted those who are in a position to ensure that this balance is achieved with the interest of the client as well as of the Government foremost in mind.

In talking of the Committee, I extend my thanks to the Committee for the work it did on this report. It was considerable. There was, on this occasion, a subcommittee of four who need special mention. There is Senator Giles, who is very much the quiet, but great, achiever in this chamber and whose work is often overlooked. Senator Powell, who has gone on not to greater things but to different things, has on this Committee been a veritable tower of strength and commonsense, and great thanks should be extended to her. Senator Collins, who was here a while ago but has now left the chamber, has now gone from being a great committee member to pursuing some micro-economic reform on the waterfront. That is a sad loss to the Committee but a happy gain for micro-economic reform. Then there was me. I am about to be followed, I understand, by Senator Vanstone. I publicly welcome Senator Vanstone to the Committee. She has already done great work and I hope with her as a deputy we will continue to work as we work so well now. So I welcome Senator Vanstone. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I would like to commence by congratulating you on your recent election to your high office and I look forward to working constructively with you. I would also like to commend Senator Cooney for his sterling efforts. I think he probably thoroughly enjoyed himself with all those arcane meanderings through the legislation. At the end of the day, of course, it was a very important inquiry that was conducted by the Committee, of which until recently I was the Deputy Chairman, and I certainly regarded that reference as one of particular significance.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the real question that arose out of all that and in a sense was not able to be properly explored was why there were indeed the levels of overpayment that ultimately emerged. I think the bulk, if not the entirety, of the report was taken up with some very necessary but technical assessments of the balance that had to be struck between the Commonwealth asserting its rights and those who, for one reason or another, found themselves with a very limited capacity to repay.

The important thing is this: the Committee itself was provided by the Department of Social Security with a distribution of overpayment reasons and that listed accounts outstanding at the end of the 1988-89 financial year as amounting to $214m. That is a very substantial sum of money owed by something in excess of 100,000 people. That means that the average overpayment was of the order of $2,000-indeed, in some instances, up to $8,000.

What is particularly significant about that is that we cannot simply dismiss overpayment as a function of somehow marginal overruns paid to a few people for a few weeks. It is quite clearly a very significant problem and one which I would have thought has to, by deduction, involve people continuing to receive moneys for, in some instances, very substantial periods of time. Indeed, to receive an average figure of some $2,000 a person would need to have received overpayments at the maximum level of benefit for in the order of 15 weeks. That does suggest a very serious problem.

However, it is not a problem that has been faced up to by this Government, and that is what I think is the most extraordinary result of the Committee's inquiry. It is highlighted by the most extraordinary announcement in last night's Budget: we are now about to be subjected to a massive inquiry and clampdown on social security fraud and overpayment. We are being told that in the current financial year the Government expects to be able to save $120m. Of that amount, $65m will come from a clampdown based on matching of Social Security and other departmental records, and $55m will come from the amnesty which will operate for a period of six weeks from yesterday's announcement.

Those are very substantial sums of money and they give the lie completely to the sort of nonsense that has been peddled by not only the current Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, but his predecessor, Mr Howe, who are constantly at pains to down play any suggestion of anyone cheating on the system or of any maladministration within the Department. By that, I do not mean any deliberate maladministration but inadequate monitoring and supervision of payments.

As Senator Cooney rightly points out, overpayments can cause very severe hardship and they also have the effect, especially if they are not able to be recouped, of there being simply less money to go to those who are genuinely in need. I think that ought to be our principal concern in the matter: to target welfare payments effectively so that moneys go to those in need and do not go to those that are not in need. That is what happens by definition with overpayments: people who are not entitled to the moneys, by one means or another, receive them and then often find that, because of that irresistible temptation that befalls us all to spend money that we have on hand, they are not in a position to repay.

The figures that were provided to the Committee showing that list of $214m contained no embellishments-simply a statement that that was the amount owing. But Senator Richardson then had the temerity to say a month or so later that some of those debts went back to 1962. He said, `These are debts that are accumulated over years. If one goes back to, say, 1988-89 as a reasonable base, in that year $95m was overpaid, $75m was recovered'. That is an extraordinary situation because what he is saying is that most of this money has been outstanding for years. But he does not tell us what attempts have been made to collect it and, if there has been a problem, what decision the Government has taken about that. Is it prepared to write off the amounts? If it does not have the legal power to write them off, why does it not seek that power? In other words, why does it not clean up the area? This money that is being owed going back to 1962 may well be technically owed by people who are no longer with us. That is simply a ridiculous state of affairs. It highlights the sort of slapdash approach that Senator Richardson has taken to this office since he assumed it.

I think one would have to say that administration has never been Senator Richardson's long suit. He is more interested in knocking political heads together and strutting his stuff in every area except his own. One can well understand that he finds it much more interesting to weigh into the telecommunications debate to protect the union or to talk about how he might be able to fix various factional difficulties. The fact is that administration is not particularly exciting, but it is absolutely essential to the proper conduct of government. Yet what we have had here is a Minister who is not prepared to do any homework and who down plays the problem to the extent that he dismisses it by saying that there is only $20m owing in the 1988-89 financial year and that the Government has a phenomenal record in the area.

If we are to take that at face value, what are we conceivably to make of last night's announcement that the problems are so rife that we are going to have this massive clampdown that is going to recover something of the order of $120m in the current financial year and, over the next three years, something of the order of $900m? That is an appalling state of affairs that demands an explanation. Whilst I commend Senator Cooney for the work he has done in the technical area, I think by far the most important question overshadowing that inquiry is why we have had such high levels of overpayment in the first place and how we are proposing to avoid them in the future. Make no mistake about it: declaring an amnesty is really little more than getting down on one's hands and knees and hoping that somehow people will come clean. That is most unlikely to be the case, given that they have been prepared in quite a number of instances not simply to accept an accidental overpayment or two but to go on for a period of months receiving overpayments and then, of course, not to repay the money to the Commonwealth. I would have thought that an amnesty was little more than a public declaration of failure, and a lot more will be needed to try to straighten out this area.

Overpayments, I think, will be a running sore as long as Senator Richardson is simply prepared to say on one day that there is not a problem and then to say on another day that there is a massive problem and we will have an amnesty. There needs to be a lot more technical work done to ascertain why people are overpaid in the first place. Whether that is achieved by means of additional review teams or whether it is achieved by requiring people actually to come into Social Security offices and sign on an ongoing basis for receipt of payments so that at least some eye-to-eye check can be made as to the bona fides and entitlements of recipients, we are going to have this problem simply compounded over time.

I welcome the efforts of Senator Cooney's committee in grappling with a very difficult problem, but it is really not much more than a peripheral issue in terms of the magnitude of the sums that we are concerned about today. I invite the Minister to face up to the question and to make a proper statement to the Senate to explain how this situation comes about in the first place-indeed, how it came about that his Department provided those figures without any qualifications. In other words, there was no suggestion that somehow the bulk of this money had been outstanding for years. It was simply put forward as a sum of $214m in outstanding overpayments, which on the face of it, I would have thought, constitutes a very serious problem and which, by its actions, I think the Department also regards as a very serious problem. I would be surprised if it would view with equanimity the approach taken by the Minister to somehow push it under the carpet and suggest that the overwhelming proportion of this money was attributable to years gone by, the inference being that it was not worth chasing up now.

I hope that we are going to see a much more serious attitude adopted by Senator Richardson as long as he remains in the portfolio. We all know that he has done his level best by way of number counting for Mr Keating to pay back the Prime Minister for the reward that he got by being appointed to this portfolio. I just hope that he will be big enough, whilst he remains there, to take it seriously and to come to grips with issues in a much more effective way than he has done today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled Debt Recovery Under the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlement Act. In commencing, I congratulate Senator Alston on his remarks to the extent that he pointed out something that this report does not highlight and, indeed, was not intended to highlight-that is, the massive problem of overpayment by the Department of Social Security and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. This, by and large, comes about in my view, not as a consequence of intention to cheat and defraud by individuals-although there is certainly a substantial element of that-but through the incompetence of the relevant departments and through the misunderstanding of the bureaucratic entanglement, if you like, that recipients of benefits from these two departments face.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston is, in my view, 100 per cent correct when he points out in his own words that if the departments concerned, in particular Social Security, got their act together and if the Minister could bring his Department to order in that sense, there would be far less of this problem. The Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs may well then not have to deal with such a problem. Obviously, it would not if the problem did not exist, but if the problem were of a much smaller scale it would perhaps not invite the Committee's attention. But the facts are that the administration of the Department is such that this is a monumental problem.

That is of concern in two respects: firstly, the fiscal outcome, of not collecting these overpayments, is very substantial-that is the element that Senator Alston has dealt with; secondly, of course, it creates another problem of interface between government and individuals. I would like to think, Mr Deputy President, that government deals with all individuals equally but, if one were to vary from that view, surely governments should deal with the most vulnerable more carefully than they do with the least vulnerable. The recipients of these benefits are in a very vulnerable position. Therefore, I suggest that there is a higher responsibility on the relevant departments to deal with those people fairly.

It is, I think, fair to say that that has not always happened in the past. I want no misunderstanding in relation to my remarks. I have no sympathy at all for people who want to cheat the Department of Social Security or the Department of Veterans' Affairs, but I equally have no sympathy with a department that has been told again and again that the manner in which it is dealing with members of public is not up to scratch and that, having been told that again and again, does not appear to have listened to that advice and does not appear to have done anything about the situation.

I would like to draw the Senate's attention to, in particular, the tenth recommendation of this report. It is one that I want to concentrate on this morning. The recommendation deals with the standard letters and advice on overpayment from the Department of Social Security. It is a common problem that people who receive advice from Social Security as to an overpayment simply do not understand what Social Security is alleging. The letters are not written in plain English. They are frequently written in a somewhat overbearing tone with an assumption of guilt on behalf of the recipient of the benefit, when that easily may not be the case. The guilt, if there is any, is of maladministration by the Department. Consequently, I want to draw to the Senate's attention those recommendations in this report that deal with the manner in which departments, especially Social Security, deal with individuals. As I say, that is primarily recommendation 10.

There are many other valuable recommendations in this report. Senator Alston describes them as technical. That may well be and in some cases clearly is the case. It is a very technical area. That is why people get caught up in it; that is why we have got the problem; and it has to be dealt with in a technical way to alleviate the problem.

In concluding, I point out that I have only briefly been on this Committee, having taken a place on it in May. I would like to express my thanks to the members of the subcommittee who prepared the draft of this report. Honourable senators may have heard Senator Cooney outlining who those members were and may have noticed that there was no coalition member on that subcommittee. Consequently, having taken my place in May, I asked the Committee whether it would hold over concluding this report so that I would have the opportunity to at least familiarise myself with the amount of evidence that it had taken and to work with the subcommittee on redrafting and settling the report.

I think some good work was contributed by everybody in the last couple of months in bringing this report to the stage that it is at today. I do want to thank the Committee for its forbearance in, basically, waiting for new members to be able to familiarise themselves with the evidence and giving new members the opportunity to participate in contributing to this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the motion that the Senate take note of the report and seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 31 May 1990, I lay on the table the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Australia-India Relations: Trade and Security together with the transcript of evidence, which were presented to the President on 24 July 1990. In accordance with the terms of the resolution, the President has authorised the printing and circulation of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

As Deputy Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I take this opportunity to commend the report entitled Australia-India Relations: Trade and Security to the Senate and, indeed, to all Australia in the absence of the Chairman, who is away from the Senate today, and also pending continuing contributions from members of the Standing Committee on this important report. It is a good report. It is a comprehensive, careful, well-informed summary with specific conclusions that address Australia's relationship with India and, to some extent, with the South Asian region as a whole. We had two terms of reference: the first, prospects for increasing trade between the two countries; and the second, the implications for the regional strategic outlook of India's enhanced defence capability.

At the outset, let me say that this is a report on which I would like the Parliament to judge the wisdom of our new title and general terms of reference to include trade along with foreign affairs and defence. Of course, these three areas are naturally entwined with each other. In this report the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade has very constructively looked at all three aspects in this important relationship between Australia and India.

From the outset, let me say that the relationship between Australia and India is undeveloped. Indeed, it has suffered from benign neglect until the last three years. Even then what has happened between our countries has been the outcome of a minority interest by Australian business and, at a peak level, by Prime Ministers, foreign Ministers and a few other parliamentary representatives, such as some members, including me, on this Senate Committee. That is not good enough.
Australia-India Relations

We are calling, in this report, for increased focus on India by Australian business and Australian government, for much improved information and much better coordination between the various government departments that are involved in this area. Indeed, we very explicitly call for the establishment of an Australia- India Council along the lines of the existing Australia-China Council, Australia-Japan Council and Australia-Indonesia Council. We call for a fourth major council to develop bilateral relations between Australia and India. I will return to that matter in a few minutes. We also call for focus to be given to Australian academic investments into the Indian subcontinent. We believe that whilst there exists in many universities some teaching and research presence with regard to India-whether it is in history, politics, economics, or even in anthropology, music and religion-there is an inadequate focus, and there are inadequate resources, to serve Australia well in terms of the need for academic expertise, the development of young graduates with the ability to be involved in business and government and to further the Australia-India understanding and relationship.

It was about three years ago that the then Prime Minister of India, Rajiv Gandhi, visited Australia and was a guest in this Parliament. That visit marked for me the reawakening of an interest between Australia and India and in the full potential that could be explored between our countries. That visit was followed the next year by the Australian Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) going to New Delhi, and subsequently by significant visits by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans. Indeed, he was there just a matter of a few weeks ago, and a couple of days after this important Senate report on Australia-India relations was released. It is my understanding that the Foreign Minister was fully informed when he arrived in India-this report having just been published-of the report's findings. It is my judgment, as an Opposition senator, that this is an instrument to greatly fortify whoever is in government in Australia in the important development of relations with India. The Minister, I trust, heralded this report. I believe that in his study of the report and his Department's study of it, he should consider fully implementing the recommendations that are set out in it. It is the natural next step or series of steps for this Government to take in redressing the inadequacies of the relationship.

Perhaps there is a $30m bill for the items that are set out in the recommendations of the Senate Committee. I put it to the Government that this is a small additional investment in relation to the $500m of trade between our two countries at the moment. Indeed, Australia has set itself a trade objective of $1,000m to be achieved by 1992. I note a general and initial finding of the Committee:

The Committee believes that India already is an important Asian power of the same general order as China, albeit with a less prominent international trading and strategic profile beyond its immediate neighbourhood. India's power will probably continue to consolidate over the next two decades and its economy will probably continue to open up.

India has 900 million people. A hundred million of them constitute what we would call a middle class. There is, then, a huge consuming public wanting goods that Australia is well placed to help to provide. There is the development of an infrastructure in India in which Australian expertise can play an important part.

Recently, White Industries Ltd, for example, has gained a major contract in relation to coal development within India. Australia is well placed not only to have mutual economic relations in terms of joint ventures, infrastructure contracts and commercial trade, but also as a gateway for India to Japan and to the Pacific region. However, this potential has not been fully recognised, even by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Austrade does not have a sufficiently defined strategic plan in its relations with India. Yet that is all to hand. It is achievable.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, will be absent from the chamber for the remainder of this week. Senator Evans will be attending the fourth non-proliferation treaty review conference in Geneva, and will be making brief visits to Cairo, New York and Washington for consultations on the current Gulf crisis. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Gareth Evans in relation to his portfolio should be directed to Senator Robert Ray.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I am sorry that Senator Evans could not wait until after Question Time to leave. He was able to launch a book before Question Time. I ask: How many Australian hostages are being held in each of Kuwait and Iraq? Are Australian hostages being used as human shields to protect military installations? What is the current guidance of the Minister to such hostages to best protect there safety-bearing in mind that the Government has given contradictory advice to date? Which other countries have negotiated release of their nationals from the region of conflict and on what basis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that other countries have negotiated for the release of hostages; but according to an announcement made on Iraqi television on 19 August, the national assembly of Iraq has decided that in some circumstances the citizens of five countries-Austria, Finland, Portugal, Sweden and Switzerland, which have not taken part in the `military blockade', would be allowed to leave Iraq. The status and precise intent of this statement is still not entirely clear. We understand that the governments of some countries concerned have been notified by Iraqi authorities of the arrangements being made for departure of their citizens, while other governments have so far been unable to obtain clarification. There is confusion about whether the basis for the selection of the countries whose nationals can leave Iraq relates to the application of sanctions or participation in the multinational naval force (MNF), or both. While the countries nominated can be characterised as being amongst those which are applying sanctions but are not participating in the multinational naval force, they are not the only countries with citizens in Kuwait and Iraq which fit that criteria. In other words, non-participation in the MNF would appear not to be the sole criterion for the apparent discrimination between countries. The Australian Government is doing all in its power to secure the departure from Iraq and Kuwait of Australian citizens who are at present trapped there. It has repeatedly called on Iraq to respect international law and to leave Kuwait.

ANSWER.PARA: The number of Australians in Kuwait, I understand, is 72. The Australian consul has been visiting Kuwait and has, I think, made contact with 64 people.
