The previous figure of about 80 in Iraq is our best estimate at this stage. As much as possible, Foreign Affairs is trying to establish the whereabouts of all Australians and give them the appropriate advice, which Senator Gareth Evans went into yesterday. Some contact will continue to be established with those people by Radio Australia.
I might add that I do not think that it is appropriate for either the press or the Parliament to canvass names at this stage, as that may only endanger the people in Kuwait.

TALK.START.PARA: —But are they to be used as human shields?

—There is no evidence at this stage that we have that any Australians are being used as human shields. There is some concern that an Australian resident may have been moved into a very dangerous situation. We are trying to confirm this. She is not an Australian passport holder; she would be a British citizen who is a permanent resident in Australia. We are endeavouring to make further inquiries as to her fate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Against the background of the deployment of Australian naval units in the Gulf, I ask: Is the Minister aware of suggestions that the Wrigley report on structure of the Australian Defence Force is to be buried? Is the Minister committed to a comprehensive examination of the report and its recommendations and to a full public debate on the report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I received the Wrigley report in early July, and I immediately ordered its printing and public release on 1 August. I think one of the key recommendations in the Wrigley report is that there is a need for a much more sustained debate in Australia about defence. His report, going into the many areas that it did, provides a basis for that. At the time of releasing the report, I indicated that a period should be available for full public exposure of the issues raised by Alan Wrigley and discussion therein. I have also authorised Mr Wrigley to canvass his views and the views contained within his report as widely as possible. That goes to briefing of press, briefing of Opposition, right through the academia, et cetera, to give it the widest possible exposure.

ANSWER.PARA: I have indicated that, obviously, the force structure review would also take into account Mr Wrigley's view. To some extent Senator Loosley has misinterpreted that the force structure review would be the sole judge of Mr Wrigley's report. I would like to put that down now. I think it would be more appropriate for the process of government to establish an interdepartmental committee with a much wider range of views than merely Defence to comment on the Wrigley report and to recommend its implementation.

I have indicated publicly that many aspects of the Wrigley report have an attraction for me as Defence Minister. It is a very well-written and well-thought-out report. It is not necessary that every phrase used in that report is accepted by the Department of Defence. Some it would regard as slightly gratuitous insult. However, getting away from those two or three minor objections-it is a report that may well see a reorientation of our approach to defence issues in the 1990s. It has much of value in it and much appeal to the Government in it; but the public debate and processes of debate must continue over the next few months and then the Government will give its response.

The alternative response could have been for the Government to have received the report, assess it for eight months and release its findings with it. If we had followed that particular process, everyone would have said, `Why haven't you released the report? Why are you sitting on it?', et cetera. I think we followed the proper process. The moment it became available we released it for public debate to get as much input back as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question also is directed to the Minister for Defence. The Minister no doubt recalls that on Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) radio on Monday, 13 August he told Paul Murphy that the rules of engagement for Australia's ships going to the Gulf region would be released on Wednesday-which was two days later. What, therefore, is the Minister's reaction to the statement on AM this morning by the Prime Minister that anyone who believed the rules of engagement would be made public would be making a stupid assumption, and if anyone suggested such a course of action it would show `how little, in fact, they know about these areas.'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I said on the ABC radio was that the rules of engagement would be released publicly. I did not say that they would be released. I have never once said that they would be released publicly, but they have to be released to the captains of the ship. Senator Durack has made a great play in saying that the Government has been delaying on this issue. We have not been delaying on this particular issue. We have had the draft rules of engagement prepared for some time.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the difficulties we face-and apparently the Opposition does not want to concede this-is that with a number of nations involved in the Gulf area, it would be absolutely ridiculous for us to adopt a definitive set of rules of engagement without discussing it with those other naval forces. Those procedures are under way; the rules of engagement were transmitted to the captains of the ships this morning with one caveat, that if, in discussions with other countries with whom we are cooperating in that area, it transpires that the rules of engagement need to be amended--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what you said.
—Your cynicism, Senator Hill, is absolutely pathetic.
—But you said--
—Order!
—That is absolutely pathetic cynicism from Senator Hill and I am disappointed that he takes that attitude.

ANSWER.PARA: Returning to the point, those rules of engagement, having been issued to the captains of our vessels, will be subject to change if, after consultation with other naval powers involved in the region, it is felt necessary to make them gel and blend in with other rules of engagement being adopted. That is the position. The details were never intended for public release and I never gave that impression. If Senator Durack wants to so misinterpret the situation, so be it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What grounds did the Minister have for saying categorically on August 13 that the engagement rules would be released, even if one accepts the absurd definition of `release' that he has now given? What grounds did he have on that day to say that they would be released on the Wednesday-two days later-when it has now taken a week or more for them to be released in his sense of the word? Secondly, if and when the Government ever makes up its mind about the final details of these rules of engagement, will the Minister make a statement to the Parliament-at least in general terms-as to what limitations are placed on the captains of those ships in engagement situations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second part of Senator Durack's question is, of course, based on a false assumption. He says, `if and when the Government makes up its mind'. The Government has made up its mind; it has issued the rules of engagement. But, if Senator Durack expects me to issue totally inflexible rules of engagement without amendment from now until the end of the year, given the fluid situation and our relationship with other naval groups operating in the area, he is putting forward a ridiculous proposition. So the second part of the question is based on a false premise.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the first part of the question-and perhaps Senator Durack should cast his mind back and try to get over the political pettiness of his question-at that time we had strong hopes of United Nations involvement and that action would be taken under a United Nations flag. Had that hope been immediately realised, we would have been able to issue to our ships rules of engagement consistent with that operational command. That did not transpire, so we delayed the final drawing up and issuing of those rules on that basis. It has now become clear that it is less likely-one hopes it is not unlikely-that the ships will be under United Nations command. My hope is to issue the rules as quickly as possible because we all realise that the sooner they are out the more the ships' crews can practise according to them.

The only other point I want to make-and I intended to make it in answer to the first part of the question-is that I am quite happy to release the rules of engagement to the Leader of the Opposition and Senator Durack to study and for comment. That is in my brief. I already had that as a written part of my answer. I make that offer to them to read the rules of engagement and come to their own conclusions. I repeat that when I made that statement the rules would be released a week ago, it was predicated on my belief and hope that the matter would be under United Nations control. That has not yet transpired; we hope that it will. As the Chief of the Defence Force said to me this morning, rules of engagement are not the Ten Commandments; they can be amended according to circumstances. One should not be totally inflexible in one's approach to these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to a report in this morning's Australian Financial Review, which asserted that the Government plans to axe the investment promotion program. What is the Government's intention?

—Mr President, that report in the Australian Financial Review was news to me and news to everybody else, I suspect; but I suppose news is the function of newspapers. The Government does not propose to terminate this program prematurely. Under previous government decisions made in the Budget context, the scheme is to run until the end of 1992-93. Its future will be considered closer to that time, following a review of its effectiveness. This scheme is one in which the Government has investment advisers in various places-Japan, North America, Europe and so on. As I say, its future will be considered closer to the time when it is due to expire and there will be a review of its effectiveness in the meantime. I might add that this information was conveyed last night to the reporter who wrote the article in question.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I preface my question by noting that Zbigniew Brzezinski, the former national security adviser to President Carter, fears that a United States first strike against Iraq is under consideration and has predicted that-and I quote-`carnage, regional explosion and a massive loss of life', would result. I further note that Jody Powell, ex-President Carter's press secretary, has said the time may come when President Bush must balance the lives of the 20,000 international hostages in Iraq against the West's need to get rid of Saddam Hussein. I ask the Minister: First, is it the case that a United States first strike against Iraq is a real and growing prospect; secondly, if so does this contradict the Bush Administration's earlier statements that their Middle East deployment was for defensive purposes only; and, thirdly, does the Government accept Mr Brzezinski's prediction that a first strike would have devastating consequences not only for the international hostages but also for all people in Kuwait and Iraq? Finally, does the Government support a United States first strike against Iraq?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, this is probably a question more appropriately directed to Senator Ray, but let me say that there are all sorts of commentators who are concerned-as is each member of the Senate and each member of the Australian community-about the situation in the Middle East. The whole world is concerned about that situation and in that circumstance a variety of commentators will be offering views. I do not think it is appropriate for me to conduct a commentary on the views of commentators around the world about whether the United States is, in any section of the administration, bent on a first strike activity against Iraq. Certainly, if the circumstances in the Middle East, as they currently exist, were to escalate, I agree totally that the consequences would be very serious for people in that region and, indeed, for those countries which are involved. Anybody would have to agree with that conclusion and hope that it will not happen.

ANSWER.PARA: As the honourable senator said in her question, the consequences would be devastating. But this Government has made a commitment, together with the United States and other countries, to a role in the Gulf in pursuit of the arrangement which has been put in place to try and alter the course of the Iraq Government's apparent intentions. That does not make us a party to certain views which might be being canvassed in sections of the United States Administration or otherwise and it is not a matter upon which I can comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Again I ask the Leader of the Government-and I stress that this is in his capacity as representing the Prime Minister in this chamber rather than as a substitute for the Minister for Defence-whether the Government supports a United States first strike in Iraq.

—The Government's position in relation to Australia's involvement in the Gulf has been articulated on a number of occasions by the Prime Minister, the Foreign Minister, the Minister for Defence and others. I can add nothing to what I said in answer to the first part of the question. I do not believe that the United States Government has consulted further with the Australian Government at this stage about further developments in the Gulf.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to a letter in the Canberra Times of 13 July, written by the late Brian O'Neil, a great Tasmanian and indeed a great Australian, pointing out that the tax pack which was received by every Australian taxpayer was in fact printed largely on imported paper. Is it a fact that the bulk of this document is printed on supercalendered and uncoated mechanical paper product which is not available in Australia, except for the forms which were printed on Glopaque, which is available in Australia? Is it also a fact that Australian-made paper products are designed for precisely the same purposes as the tax pack-for example, Econoprint and Offset Magazine, which are made at Wesley Vale on the north-western coast of Tasmania? Will the Minister tell the Senate why the Government went for a foreign product when similar products were available from Australian manufacturers? Will the Minister give an assurance that next year this tax pack will be printed and published in Australia, as it was on this occasion, but on Australian-made paper?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that this question reminds me a bit of a question I was asked on the radio the other day, when the interviewer said to me, `Are you aware, Senator, that there is a Customs shipment which came into Melbourne and, because particular articles being shipped into the Port of Melbourne had four additional bolts on them, the Customs rejected them and said a higher rate of duty had to be paid? Is this not, Senator, a considerable inefficiency in the administration of Customs and a moral problem for Australia?'. That was the essence of the question, to which I had to plead, I must say, a fair degree of ignorance because I was not familiar with the particular circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: I have to do that again here. I am not aware of the paper on which the particular documents to which he refers was printed. I am, of course, aware that a number of grades of paper are not made in Australia and are imported. I am aware of the fact that we have a very substantial deficit in paper products because of the fact that we do not make a complete range of papers in Australia and also because we do not produce sufficient volume. But I will direct the question which the honourable senator asked me, relating to a particular document and the availability of substitute or alternative Australian papers, to the Minister administering the appropriate department-I am not even sure who that is at the moment-and I will provide him with--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised.

—Senator Hill says he is not surprised. It all depends whether the Department of Administrative Services made the purchase or the Treasury made the purchase. I am unable to say at this point of time but I will find out. I will not only hopefully be able to enlighten Senator Harradine but also Senator Hill en passant, as the French say.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I ask the Minister whether last night's Budget announcement that the tax file number system will be massively extended to cover all social security, veterans affairs and student assistance is a complete dumping of his Government's promise in 1988 that for privacy reasons the tax file number would not be extended beyond the tax system.

—Senator Boswell has raised a very important issue, namely, the relationship between the efficiency of the discharge of government programs and the obligation that governments have to taxpayers to ensure that moneys spent on programs are in fact directed well to the target recipients. But there is a privacy issue and I have been assured by the various Ministers concerned that it is their intention that Mr Kevin O'Connor, the Privacy Commissioner, be involved in the monitoring of the way in which these provisions work. It is very important that that balance be found, as I say, in order to protect the revenue on the one hand and to protect the privacy of individuals on the other. I am very confident that Kevin O'Connor, the Commissioner for Privacy, has the confidence of this chamber and will be able to report to this chamber if he finds that there has been any adverse impacts resulting from the operation of the matters to which Senator Boswell has drawn our attention.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does not the Budget announcement concerning the wider application of the tax file number system simply represent the third attempt by the Hawke Government to impose a personal identification numbering system on Australians, the first attempt being the Australia Card and the second, the recently aborted Health Insurance Commission proposal to link pharmacies with a number of government department databases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be helpful if I gave a little more detail on the requirement for income support recipients to supply a tax file number. I believe that the thought that this amounts to an Australia Card enhancement will be found to be without proper foundation. One will recall that the Australia Card proposal was for a national identification system covering all Australians, with some exceptions. Its main intention was to prevent tax evasion and its use would have become an integral part of life in Australia, including employment arrangements, financial transactions and contractual arrangements of various types. It is a most comprehensive proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: The measure announced in the Budget last night falls far short of this. Its purpose is to connect the revenue and income support records in a way which strengthens the income test requirements which surround most income support payments currently available in Australia. The measure does not apply to all Australians. It applies only to those people who are clients of the agencies mentioned in the Budget Papers. The measure is not intended to detect tax evasion, but rather to ensure that income support payments are based correctly on the amount of other income derived by the recipients.

The Department of Social Security and the other agencies involved already undertake independent checks of these amounts of other income but the process is manual and very costly. The Budget measure takes advantage of developments in computing technology so that the necessary checks can be made at minimum cost. As I have indicated, the intended arrangements have been and will continue to be discussed with the Privacy Commissioner and will be subject to constant monitoring by him to ensure that the privacy principles are met in every respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Administrative Services. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports that the old Parliament House has been neglected and allowed to deteriorate? Does the Minister agree that the old Parliament House is worthy of preservation for its significant role in the parliamentary history of this nation? If so, what action does the Government propose to ensure that this important building is secured for present and future generations of Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have in fact seen reports that Senator Colston alludes to, that the old Parliament House is, as is claimed, being allowed to deteriorate. I think at the outset it should be put very clearly and succinctly that those allegations are in fact erroneous. No-one expects--
—Have you been down there for an inspection?
—I have been down for an inspection and I did not go down with blinkered vision either.
—Did you see the leaks?

—We are talking about an old building. We cannot expect it to appear as new. Of course, once furniture and individuals are removed from it, there is a case to ensure that on a care and maintenance basis the building is maintained at a proper level. The Government is also concerned to ensure that the building has a future. It has already decided what the future for the old Parliament House will be, once it is refurbished-to create a museum of constitutional and political history.

ANSWER.PARA: I also alert the Senate to the fact that in the Budget last night the Government boosted funding to the old Parliament House fourfold. We have maintained-in fact we have increased-the amounts of money allocated for the continuing care and maintenance of old Parliament House. The allocation for this financial year is $700,000, an increase of $200,000 over last year's level. But we have also allocated $1.35m to develop detailed design options to return the old Parliament House to its 1927 configuration for use as a public building. This reflects the Government's commitment to continuing to maintain the building but also to its ultimately being a constitutional and political museum.

I should also in this context repeat and put on record the Government's decision that the old Parliament House will be used for a number of purposes within the broad definition of `constitutional and political history museum'. It will be used for the National Museum of the Australia and the Electoral Commission's Education Centre. It will also house a Government Information Centre. It will also house the Australian Heritage Commission and will be made available to the Australian Archives to display some of the most significant artistic and written records that the Archives has in its possession.

In conclusion, I ask the Senate to note that there has been an increase of funding allocated in last night's Budget. In terms of the $1.35m for the detailed design option work, I think it can be seen that this is the first step towards the old Parliament House achieving its final use.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to last night's Budget announcement that the introduction of a $2.50 charge for pharmaceuticals for holders of pensioner health benefit and health benefit cards will be offset by a corresponding increase of $2.50 a week for standard rate pensioners and beneficiaries. Does the Minister acknowledge that there are currently many thousands of elderly pensioners in nursing homes, retirement villages and hostels who pay a high and fixed proportion of their income for rent and board, and that such people will lose a large proportion of their increased payment in increased rent and board? If this is so, what steps does the Government propose to take to ensure that these people are properly compensated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are two problems. There is the problem concerning nursing homes; there is also, I think, the problem of looking at what State housing commissions might do with the $2.50 increase in terms of the rent charged to tenants. So we have a twofold problem. As for those nursing homes that are subsidised by the Commonwealth, I think we will be able to quarantine all the pensioners in those homes from suffering any disadvantage because of last night's decision.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of private nursing homes, we will be contacting those homes. We will be negotiating with them and we are very hopeful that they will not be taking into account that pension increase in terms of taking money away from the nursing home patients, most of whom I think pay 85 per cent. In respect of State housing commissions the same will apply. We will be negotiating with them over the next few weeks and months and we are very confident that the States will not take advantage of this situation either and that no pensioner will be disadvantaged by the decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware of a recent article in the Sydney Morning Herald which said that some accountants and lawyers would advocate income minimisation practices to attempt to reduce non-custodial parents' liabilities under stage two of the child support scheme?
—A Labor lawyer.

—For Senator Panizza's education-and I think those of us who have been here for a while know that he needs quite a bit of it-this did not come from a Labor lawyer. This came from one of those smart, very clever lawyers from a very big firm-the kind of people who support Senator Panizza. There is nothing cheap about these kinds of lawyers. It takes Liberal Party people to be able to support them. Unfortunately it showed that there were plenty of noncustodial parents prepared to conspire with lawyers to affect how children in Australia can live; to minimise the amount of money that can be provided for kids. That is a pretty miserable performance. This particular lawyer was giving advice on how income might be minimised so that non-custodial parents just would not have to pay up. The whole direction of the Child Support Agency and the Government's reforms in the last few years has been to make both parents contribute to the bringing up of their kids. That is the only way we can have a sane, sensible, sound social security system. People such as this lawyer deserve the condemnation of everyone in this Senate. All they are doing is seeking to inflict misery on the kids by artificially protecting non-custodial parents. That kind of thing deserves the support of no-one here-only condemnation.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: Does the Minister agree that outlays by the Federal Government for its own expenditure purposes this year after the proper net deduction of asset sales and public debt interest are budgeted to increase by 11.9 per cent in money terms or 5.4 per cent in real terms? If so, I ask him to explain how such a profligate increase can be described by the Treasurer-as he did in his Budget Speech-as maintaining: . . . fiscal policy as the Government's principal weapon in the fight against the current account deficit and our overseas debt.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Short knows full well and I guess finds unpalatable, this Government has had an outstanding record of restraint in government outlays-something which never happened in the entire period of previous governments. That has been over the last four years. What this Budget does, of course, is maintain the fiscal discipline of recent years at a time when there would naturally be a tendency for outlays to rise and revenue to fall as a result of the slowdown in the Australian economy: outlays to rise, as they are anticipated to do, for example, in relation to unemployment benefit; revenue to fall for a variety of reasons which are articulated in the Budget Papers. But the Budget surplus this year is larger than any on record and it has been brought about by both a fall in outlays to gross domestic product and a fall in revenue to gross domestic product. Outlays to gross domestic product this year are anticipated to be 23.5 per cent, down from 23.6 per cent last year. That is surely the most relevant measure of outlays. We have to look at the total economy and look at the pattern of Commonwealth government outlays as against the performance of the total economy.

ANSWER.PARA: We are not saying that in this Budget there has been fiscal slashing, if you like, of the same vigour as this Government has indulged in in previous Budgets. We are saying that we have maintained, over a period of years, a degree of fiscal discipline and restraint in Commonwealth government expenditure which is unsurpassed in the history of this country. We have done that for very obvious reasons of Budget strategy. Those figures are all set out in the Budget statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. On this day when the Parliament is first being televised, my question concerns the continuing insufficient media coverage and sponsorship of women's sport. Can the Minister outline the Government's initiatives to promote the role of women in sport both at the elite level and in the community, and in particular steps to ensure equity in the allocation of the sporting dollar?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crowley has had a continuing interest in this question over quite some time-as well she might. All the research that has been done in this country in the last few years suggests that women, and adolescent girls in particular, are not participating in sport anything like the rest of the community.
—My girls are doing all right.

—Of course, Senator Harradine's girls would be all right-he is just so enlightened in these matters-but there are those who do not have his advantages. There are also quite a few Australians who do not have as many kids as he does. For the rest of us, who are looking at attempting to increase those participation rates, there is a serious problem. Some time back the Sports Commission set up the Women's Sport Promotion Unit, which has been working away at lifting the profile of women in sport for quite some time, but recently the Government has developed two other initiatives to promote women in sport.

ANSWER.PARA: At a meeting of sports and recreation Ministers in New Zealand last week, the Sports and Recreation Ministers Council established an official subcommittee which will enhance the coordination between the States and the Commonwealth on the role of women in sport. It will have representatives from New Zealand, from the Federal Government and from all the States and Territories to provide advice on the coordination of policies between all of those bodies. The Council also endorsed the principles and the policies of equity in sport and endorsed the work of the Women's Sport Promotion Unit in trying to achieve that.

As a complementary initiative, Mrs Kelly, our new Minister responsible for sport, is establishing the independent Sportswomen of Excellence Committee, which will be launched on 10 September. This Committee will have three purposes: it will act as a role model for adolescent girls; it will raise the profile of women in sport; and it will obtain media coverage and financial support for women's sport as a whole. The Committee will be made up of some very prominent women in sport from around Australia. Some of them will be, indeed, household names. It will not be an advisory committee, as that is what the Women's Sport Promotion Unit already is, but it will be a lobby group which will promote women in sport and get more publicity for it than perhaps the Women's Sport Promotion Unit will have been able to do. By doing that, we will continue to raise that profile and we will get the participation rate of women and, in particular, adolescent girls up to where it ought to be.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SERVICES TO VETERANS: COST OF PSYCHIATRIC CARE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Can the Minister advise what reduction in Government spending will be achieved by the new initiative which requires veterans in long term psychiatric care to pay $145.25 a week, whereas previously they were cared for by their Government, which properly recognised that their war-inflicted conditions merited care without cost to them? Is this mean decision of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs part of Senator Richardson's strategy of cutting down on welfare cheats?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There would be no suggestion by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs that he would be treating veterans as cheats, or even making that surmise in any financial arrangements that are made in relation to their paying a contribution towards board and lodging costs when they are admitted to long term psychiatric care. Veterans' Affairs beneficiaries admitted to long term psychiatric care in gazetted mental health beds and residents of Anzac Hostel in Victoria, it is true, will be required to pay a contribution towards board and lodging costs from 1 January 1991. Nursing home residents have been required to pay such a contribution since 1987.

ANSWER.PARA: The change will bring residents in long term psychiatric care and in Anzac Hostel into line with nursing home residents. These expenses are incurred by all veterans in nursing homes and other long term institutional care. The contribution will be set at the same rate as that applying to nursing home residents. This is currently $20.75 per day, which is 87.5 per cent of the maximum single rate pension plus rent assistance. The contribution will be linked to increases in Veterans' Affairs and Social Security pensions. Before 1 January 1991, residents affected by the change will be individually notified and suitable payment methods will be determined.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Can the Minister confirm that the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee is currently able to meet only six days per year? Is it correct that there were an estimated 200 applications before the last meeting for consideration and only 18 were approved? What can be done to upgrade resources for the Committee so that its role can be considerably improved and evaluations of many important drugs greatly expedited?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I do not have any details on the exact proportion of drugs which could be evaluated over a series by the Drug Evaluation Committee, although I accept that Senator Reynolds would have had accurate information as the basis for her question. I believe that the question of drug evaluation is a matter of great importance to the Australian community, and one which is subject to some campaigns from time to time suggesting that the process be speeded up in a way which might lead to the entrance into Australia of drugs which are then found at some later date to have a deleterious impact on the health of those persons who might think that they could benefit from a drug that has been well publicised, perhaps, overseas and where doctors become aware through reading overseas medical journals of the claims being made about a particular drug.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no doubt that these wonder drugs are subject to considerable publicity and raise the hopes of those suffering from a particular disease or illness in a way which leads them, of course, to want the most speedy process of evaluation to take place. But I am sure that Senator Reynolds, as a woman, would be perhaps very well aware of the dangers that have faced women when drugs have been introduced in a way which has had a very deleterious effect on their health, whereas, of course, it was hoped that they would be beneficial.

The information which must be submitted by manufacturers wishing to market drugs in Australia is similar in both structure and level of detail to that required by other developed countries. Specific Australian trials are generally not required. That situation means that our regulatory process is in harmony with the best practice of those well developed overseas countries and that, while there may be opportunities for improving the regulatory process-and I believe dialogue with industry and doctors should continue to try to speed up that process-the evaluation system is a very vital protection for the public and cannot be speeded up in a way which could lead, as I say, to the entrance of drugs into the community which could, in fact, do damage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. Senator Tate mentioned overseas comparisons. Could he undertake to contact the Minister for Health and request comparative information about the time of processing approvals so that we can compare Australia with those other countries.

—I will undertake to follow up the matter with the relevant Minister, but I might point out that at a recent international seminar in Jakarta Dr Leo Offerhaus of the World Health Organisation regional office for Europe stated that Australia was one of a limited number of countries whose drug evaluation system provided adequate protection for the public. It is that sort of international comparison that I think Senator Reynolds and the general public would like to know about, and I think we can take great heart from that evaluation by the World Health Organisation. As to the precise details that the honourable senator wishes to have provided, I will ask the Minister to provide those.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DAMAGE TO PUBLIC PROPERTY IN PARLIAMENT HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is directed to you. Was there significant damage done to public property at a function in Parliament House last evening? Is it true that a painting was damaged? If so, whose party was it and what action is being taken to recover from the perpetrators the cost of the damage to public property?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I can inform Senator Reid and all honourable senators that both the Speaker and I are appalled at the wanton act to deliberately deface a painting by noted Australian artist, Fred Williams. My understanding is that the private dining room was booked by the Treasury Department as the venue for its annual post-Budget Treasury drinks, and I assume that that Department issued the invitations. At 2.30 a.m. on Wednesday, 22 August, the catering supervisor at the function called security staff to remove the painting after beer had apparently been thrown at it and food and cream had been smeared on it. The art curator is now assessing the damage to the painting, but the initial estimate is that it will cost at least $500 to clean. The final figure can be made only after a full examination has been carried out and a detailed assessment made.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators can be reassured that every effort will be made to find the culprits, and the cost recovery issue has already been raised with the Treasurer, who was equally appalled by what has happened. Neither the Speaker nor I, who have joint responsibility for the building, were at the function; thankfully, neither of us received an invitation. It is clear that we will have to look very closely at whether Parliament House facilities will be available again next year for the Treasury Department. I will report further to honourable senators when I have more information.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. Is it true that the Department of Defence gave permission to Hawker de Havilland to sell $850,000 worth of aircraft parts to the Iraqi Air Force and that this deal was only cancelled after the invasion of Kuwait? I ask the Minister why the deal received approval in the first place and when the decision was made to allow military exports to Iraq. I further ask the Minister whether this deal coincided with the decision to allow the Department of Defence to review military export sales, rather than the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade which happened in 1988. In addition to this, what other military exports, if any, have been made to Iraq since 1988 or to any other country in the Gulf region? I also ask whether it is true that the decision by the Department of Defence to allow the export of former Royal Australian Air Force Mirage aircraft to Pakistan caused great embarrassment to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade on his recent visit to the Indian sub-continent. Finally I ask whether any of the companies which sold weapons to Iraq that are now likely to be used against Australian and allied forces in the Gulf, were present at the AIDEX `89 arms bazaar held here in Canberra last November with Australian Government support, and which companies are now being invited to take part in AIDEX `91 in November next year. I refer particularly to the French company--
—Order! Senator Vallentine, it is a very long question.
—I will leave it at that, Mr President.
—Thank you.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time of the invasion of Kuwait there was one permission relating to goods and this involved a quantity of engine spare parts for Iraqi Air Force trainer aircraft being supplied by Hawker de Havilland. Military advice was given in accordance with procedures agreed by Ministers that the goods were not of major military significance. It was therefore consistent with Government policy that the goods be exported. The decision to allow this one exemption was made on 28 May 1990 and, as the honourable senator has indicated in the question, as part of our trade sanctions it was subsequently cancelled on the invasion of Kuwait. The answer to the second part of the question is basically no. The Department of Defence is not the sole authority to approve export applications. This is clear in the public guidelines, a copy of which was provided by my Department here last year, but the honourable senator may not recall what was in it. Government departments and authorities represented on the Standing Interdepartmental Committee on Defence Exports used the Government's seven criteria listed in those public guidelines. I assure the honourable senator that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is consulted in matters relating to exports.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the third part of the question, there have been no other military exports to Iraq since 1988. Approval for military exports during the same period to other Gulf countries include the following items: 7.62mm rifles and spares to Bahrain; demolition firing device to Kuwait in the United Arab Emirates; repairs and overhauls of T53 aircraft engines for Oman; one demonstration Land Rover to Oman; one indoor shooting range to Qatar; and radio equipment and spares to Oman in the United Arab Emirates.

On the final part of the question, I will leave it to my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to determine whether in fact he was embarrassed. I have to say though that the agreement of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is always obtained in regard to the disposal of surplus defence equipment and this included the sale of Mirage aircraft to Pakistan. The signing of the contract was the culmination of commercial negotiations that started in late 1988. Australia does value its friendship with both India and Pakistan and would not like to take any action that could in any way impair those relationships.

I think the last part of the honourable senator's question relates to the AIDEX and my response there is that the Australian Government is not necessarily aware of any foreign companies which have sold weapons to Iraq. However, we have to note that AIDEX is a privately run exhibition. No Australian companies whether present or not at AIDEX have sold weapons to Iraq since 1988, consistent with my previous answer. The only other company-not an Australian company-which may have had dealings there that we would know of is Aerospatiale which may have sold Exocet missiles prior to the AIDEX conference, not post-AIDEX.

May I say in conclusion, Mr President, that it is very easy to take cheap shots on defence exports, but I have often wondered why people distinguish between the morality of being able to export their defence items and being able to import them, therefore making those who export them to you immoral. I do not see anything wrong, and never have, in defence exports. But one must-and this country does as Senator Vallentine knows-debar exports to certain regions and countries of the world, and so we should. Those guidelines, as I say, are publicly available and I think we should stick to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Since an Estimates committee has received confirmation that regulations are being prepared to permit certain trainees in the family medicine program to be accorded higher rebates, or their principles to be accorded higher rebates for services they render as if they were vocationally registered general practitioners, since the Senate has a select committee examining this matter and since we have had confirmation further that those draft regulations have been shown to the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, as part of the process of the regulation, I ask the Minister: Have the draft regulations been shown to other interested parties? I ask the Minister further: Will he ask his colleague to arrange-as a matter of courtesy to the Senate-to have the Senate select committee offered the same courtesies as have been offered to the college and allow that committee to see and comment on the draft regulations before they are advanced to the stage of finality?

—I understand Senator Peter Baume's interest in this matter and I understood him to indicate that the College of General Practitioners was consulted in order to ensure that the framework of the regulations and their wording was appropriate to the aims which the Government has set forward. I do not know whether any other organisations have been consulted in the same way and I certainly undertake to raise with the Minister the question of the select committee being provided with the same opportunity in relation to the formulation of the regulations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I preamble the question by saying that on 10 May I asked Senator Button a question about the multifunction polis (MFP), in reply to which Senator Button said:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government has made it quite clear from the beginning that the private sector essentially has the economic carriage of this project. That is to say, Government resources will not be poured into it.

In view of the success of the Queensland Government in avoiding the imposition of the MFP on that State because the Queensland Government could not or would not provide $320m for land acquisition, does Senator Button believe that he misled the Senate in his reply on 10 May? In relation to the same matter, is he aware that the MFP committee made it quite clear to the Queensland Government that the capital gain in the land value had to accrue to the MFP project to make it economically viable? Is he aware that the South Australian Government is suggesting that the MFP public cost will be about $2.5 billion? The Federal Government in yesterday's Budget put aside $4m for MFP expenditure. In view of these very large anticipated government expenditures does he not agree again that he misled the Senate in his reply on 10 May?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not mislead the Senate on 10 May. I did say:

ANSWER.PARA: Government resources will not be poured into it.
I think the honourable senator referred to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a question of degree.

—We are talking about a project of large resources and certainly government resources will not be poured into that. I used an example on 10 May to explain the nature of the Government investment in the project. That investment has not only been Government. It has been private sector investments, State Government investments and also Commonwealth investments. But as far as the Commonwealth is concerned it would largely be made through contributions to the research and education elements of the MFP in the same way in which we normally contribute to research funds to universities and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Coulter raised the question of the Queensland site. The joint steering committee and the chairman of that committee, Mr Bailey, were concerned to see that there was not land speculation at the Queensland site. That was the point that they sought to ensure. The land being held by private owners, they were concerned that the price of the land be frozen and not be a subject for speculation. Of course, Commonwealth funds will be expended in completing the feasibility study in the next stage, to determine commercial feasibility, environmental assessment issues and social impact issues, and those are the matters in respect of which money has been allocated by the Commonwealth in this Budget for this financial year.

The task of the management committee at present will be to identify the elements of public cost and how to handle that issue of public cost, particularly in relation to collaboration with the private sector. The funds will be the Commonwealth contribution towards the detailed feasibility work at the Adelaide site, and they will be concerned with international investment promotion efforts and, most importantly, community consultation issues. I understand that when Senator Coulter raised this question on the last occasion, he was keen that the community consultation process should start. Senator Coulter started his own consultation process. That has been done by him in Adelaide-by calling meetings and public rallies as a way of consulting. That is also being done in Melbourne by the League of Rights and one or two other bodies like that-the Rainbow Alliance-and Senator Coulter is doing it in South Australia.

As a Commonwealth government, we prefer the more appropriate course of a widespread and intensive consultation process, which will be managed by Mr Bob Lansdown, the current chairman of Australia Post, a former distinguished public servant, a distinguished ex-serviceman, and one who is very committed to trying to provide as much information as possible and to consult with all those groups who have questions or concerns. I just hope that Senator Coulter might get behind these efforts as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I certainly would get behind the MFP if it had any merit, but I see no merit in it. I take up the Minister's reply in so far as he speaks about land speculation. Is it not the fact that in Queensland the reason that the project fell through is that the speculative gain was to accrue to the MFP and not to other speculators or land-holders who may already hold that land? Is it not a fact that one of the reasons that South Australia has been landed with this project is that the land is already in public ownership, can be handed over to MFP, and MFP itself, again, can gain the capital improvement in that land value as a consequence of the development of the MFP?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter, as a drop-out from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, is making an extraordinary allegation. He says, `If the MFP project had any merit'. That question is being examined continually by some very competent people. Senator Coulter alone-apart from Joe Camilleri of the Rainbow Alliance and a couple of other fringe dwellers in Victoria-has made the judgment that it has no merit. He talks about a process of community consultation. I find it extraordinary, coming from a person of his apparent background, as I read it in his curriculum vitae, that he should rush to judgment on this issue, alone, when others have not done so.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said in answer to the original question, these matters are the subject of examination, again by a management committee of very prominent and distinguished South Australian businessmen. The committee has on it people who are experts in public administration and other areas. They are considering these issues. The issue, of course, which Senator Coulter goes back to is the fact that there is public ownership of the site in South Australia and the question is whether that will accrue to the private sector in terms of private sector investment on the site. That issue is being considered now. If Senator Coulter has a view about that which he wants to put to that management committee, I am sure they will not wait with bated breath on the basis of his utterances here, but they will certainly receive him and hear his view.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Industrial Relations Act 1988 and the Industrial Relations (Consequential Provisions) Act 1988, and for related purposes.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Alston proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's continuing refusal to put the national interest in a fully competitive telecommunications industry ahead of its own factional agendas.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shortly after the Government fortuitously fell over the line after the last election, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, managed to summon up enough courage to leak a letter to the Australian in which he outlined his proposals for urgent reforms in a number of major areas and once again pronounced that the benchmark for measuring the performance of the Labor Government would be micro-economic reform. Of course, he denounced that in relation to the third term, but here we were again with a clear acknowledgment that it had failed and a determination to do better next time. He actually nominated telecommunications as an area in which he saw a need for fundamental change.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, these notions are highly susceptible to definitions that suit the speaker; and of course, the Prime Minister is no exception to that. What he defined as fundamental deregulation was confined really to the mobile telephone area, and of course that, as we well know, is an area that is bursting at the seams, an area in which Telecom has been patently unable to cope with demand and has been doing everything it can to keep the lid on any expansion of its activities. But Mr Hawke seemed to be bowing to the inevitable and at least acknowledging that that was an area in which there was clearly a need for deregulation.

That is about as far as our brave Prime Minister has gone. Since that time we have had leaks and counter-leaks and all sorts of efforts at being hairy chested behind closed doors; but we have not had any sign of Mr Hawke being prepared to come out and say where he stands on the issue-which of course is par for the course, leading from behind. I suppose he has now got that down to an art form. It used to be described as consensus. I think we all recognise it as lowest common denominator politics. But the last thing it is, is good for the national interest.
What a smorgasbord of petty intrigue and naked self-interest we have had in recent months parading as the national interest in this vital area.

Make no mistake about it. Even Senator Collins seems to be understanding the virtues of competition on the waterfront, and we are all anxiously awaiting the expiration of the first 12 months; but he should be very grateful he is not in this area, where there is absolutely no prospect of rational debate or discussion, let alone outcome. The reason for that is that the factions simply dominate the discussion. We never hear a skerrick of a suggestion about the national interest. We never hear about what goes on overseas, what the experience has been there, and what dramatic reductions we have had in prices and what improvements in quality of service in a whole range of areas. As Senator Collins well knows, one of the big lessons from the United Kingdom (UK) is that it did not go far enough. It simply allowed British Telecom to convert to a quasi private monopoly. It introduced a little carrier called Mercury, and it let it play around at the edges. As a result, some six years later it has about 5 per cent of the market. Six years later is pretty critical, because Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States all embraced competition at that time, and here we are, six years down the track, going backwards, with virtually no-one in there fighting for what I think every other commentator would regard as an absolute necessity.

Of course, Mr Keating is the shining exception. He happens to be on the right track for the wrong reason. He sees it as his opportunity to differentiate his own product from that of his hopelessly compromised leader.

We can understand why he sees a marked opportunity in that regard. But let it be said, if he was prepared to come out and go on the record instead of having his office bruiting about the virtues of competition we might be able to take him a bit more seriously. We now know that what he seems to be standing up for is unlikely to get to first base and he has even thrown in the towel in terms of competition between OTC Ltd and Telecom-not for any logical or rational economic reason, but simply because he does not have the numbers. His acolyte, Mr Dawkins, came back from overseas the other day realising that his only hope lies with Mr Keating. He immediately went on the record in his classic manner of leaking off the record and made it clear where he stood. But, of course, when he went along to the Centre Left and gave it his view of the world, he was very quickly jumped on. Mr Dawkins, I suppose, will remain quiet as a result.

This matter is one of fundamental importance in the national interest. One of the most dishonest arguments that used to be paraded when anyone was interested in the merits of the argument was that somehow we needed to have a monopoly in Australia to compete with all those big bad overseas mega giants. Overseas, in Europe in particular, that sort of nonsense is scathingly described and dismissed as the national champion approach. It is a classic example of pretending that somehow, even if an organisation is inefficient locally, if it gets on the big wide world market as a monopoly, it will be able to make some easy money. Now, there is just no proof of that at all and, indeed, Telecom's international record, I think, leaves quite a bit to be desired. It may be early days, but it certainly does not have any big runs on the board and the last thing that it wants, or that the nation wants, is for it to be allowed to perpetuate domestic inefficiencies in the name of somehow competing better on the world stage.

The Australian Financial Review made it clear what it thought of that sort of rubbish. It said that water should be thrown on the Telecom argument, that it must be bigger to compete overseas, and it pointed out that a Telecom merger with OTC will add only 18 per cent to Telecom size and move it only one rung up in international ratings. Australia does not need more concentration in telecommunications. It is a vibrant and growing industry on the verge of a revolution which will make huge amounts of data available to every business and householder. This is the sort of fertile business atmosphere which brings forth innovation. But, of course, those words are simply lost on the power brokers in the Australian Labor Party (ALP). That is really what this argument is all about.

I will give you the classic example of that. The gentleman who is prepared to poke his nose into every portfolio but his own, Senator Richardson, could not resist the temptation to weigh into this particular argument as he has weighed into so many others since the election, obviously because he is still totally dissatisfied with what was handed to him by the Prime Minister and is very anxious to get into any other area. But whilst he is in Social Security he is going to wander around causing trouble and supposedly putting out factional bush fires. What he said was, `I don't really think it matters whether Keating gets rolled. There are a thousand issues that crop up in the course of a particular parliament, and no-one from Bob Hawke or Paul Keating down wins on every single occasion everything he wants'.

Senator Richardson also suggested that one of the trenchant opponents of the Beazley reform plan, the Australian Telecommunications Employees Union (ATEA), could actually do very well out of the changes. Well, if ever there is a cat being let out of the bag, it is that, because the ATEA is opposed to any form of competition whatsoever. It will not wear Monstercom; it knows that that is not going to lead to any form of realistic competition. What the ATEA wants is to simply maintain the network in public ownership and ensure that it therefore has almost universal union coverage. If what Senator Richardson is saying is that the ATEA will come out of the deal fairly happily, we can rest assured that there is no prospect of competition emerging. Of course, Senator Richardson would be the last one to ever intervene on the merits. So we can take it, I think, from his contribution that it is all about numbers; it is all about who is going to get on side with whom; and it has very little to do with what is in the national interest.

That is where, of course, we are in stark contrast to the Government. Only yesterday did we finally announce in public the results of some very careful analysis of all the options and we have made it clear that we support full and effective and open competition, that we will proceed with the privatisation of Telecom, OTC and Aussat, that that privatisation will be managed so as to ensure that Australians retain majority ownership and control of strategic telecommunications assets. We will give employees preference in acquiring shares, and that is the very sort of thing that proved irresistibly attractive in the UK, where the union leadership of British Telecom demanded a boycott and yet there was a 97 per cent take-up. That will happen here, I have no doubt, as long as the ATEA leadership is not able to simply lord it over the membership.

So we will be on the record from now on as being the party, the coalition in favour of full-scale deregulated competition in an area that is bursting for competition and where it has been shown around the world that competition does deliver the goods. Do not let us be sidetracked by any nonsense that somehow one can come up with some example somewhere of a system that is working less than perfectly.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can.
—I suppose Senator Collins is going to trot out the UK, because he did not seem to be listening to me a moment ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The UK is not an example of the sort of competition we are advocating. The UK is an area where Oftel came on the scene too late and where a very one-sided duopoly has been allowed to operate for the last six years. But if we look at what can happen under competition and what has already happened in New Zealand, for example, we will see that there can be a dramatic improvement in things such as operator connected services, directory assistance, new connections, repairs and maintenance.

I suppose Senator Powell, who is trying to interject, has long been a fervent advocate of the total monopoly in this area and sings Telecom's praises at every opportunity. I get sick and tired of ringing up Telecom when my phone does not work at weekends and being told that unless I am a special customer I do not get my phone fixed on a weekend. I am classified as an ordinary domestic subscriber and that means I do not get my phone fixed at weekends. Every citizen ought to be entitled to have his or her phone fixed at a weekend. I am not asking for any special pleading, let me assure you. I am simply saying that the very basic requirement of a telecommunications carrier is to be prepared to fix up faults that emerge in the system and fix them up quickly. It is done within a matter of hours in the UK, in the United States (US) and in New Zealand; it is a matter of days in Australia. It is simply not good enough. In the US a caller will not wait more than 10 seconds if he rings directory assistance. Here he will be kept waiting indefinitely. It is a strategic ploy when someone rings 013 wanting information. Because Telecom has not been allowed by this Government to charge for directory assistance, it retaliates by queuing theory. That is very clear stuff, but it is not in the interest of consumers. So the Liberal Party is very much on the record as favouring competition that will be driven solely by the interests of consumers, and that is the last thing that is happening in the Government at the present time.

I think we have all seen some classic examples in recent days of the sorts of mammoth leaks that only occur when a government is in dead trouble. The Australian Financial Review had almost nothing else in it last week other than Mr Keating's comprehensive leaking of his own submission, then his own leaking of Mr Beazley's submission, followed by a counter reaction on the part of the Keating faction-all designed to somehow jockey the position and influence.
The sort of leak that we find in the media is one in the Age on 28 July:

The fracas is exposing once more the divisions of the Left. During a phone hook-up on Thursday night Left Ministers Hand and Bolkus told the faction's parliamentary executive that given the Left's present uncompromising line they would have to vote in Cabinet against both the Beazley and Keating plans. This they indicated would help the chances of the Keating scheme getting Cabinet support, that is, the option that the Left would like least.

This is Byzantine. I mean, what are they on about? This is all about playing games and ending up almost accidentally with a solution that they will not have a bar of. It is all about trade-offs. `Who are you for? Are you for or against the Treasurer? Are you going to stand up for Beazley or aren't you? Are you going to do a Ros Kelly and go public? Are you going to do a Dawkins and ring up Michelle Grattan and be quoted?'

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Please address people by their proper titles.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. `Are you going to ring up Michelle Grattan and somehow get her to write a whole series of stories about how Mr Dawkins is reported to have told colleagues where he stands on the issue?' These are the sorts of games that are played at the moment. There is no interest at all in the national interest, only an interest in factional in-fighting and jostling for position. We on this side of the chamber regard this as a very sad commentary on the state of the ALP and certainly a very sad reflection on any commitment that there once might have been to competition in the telecommunications area.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are seeing at the moment is a disgraceful abdication of responsibility-political harlotry, I suppose one could say-without any concern for anything but power and no corresponding responsibility attached to it. This sort of squalid factional jockeying will be played out no doubt at the national conference. We have been told time and again that there are those who want the national conference to be pre-empted by a Cabinet decision; there were those who wanted something put in the Budget Papers as a matter of principle; and there were those who thought that somehow the Party platform was sacrosanct. We had Ministers Crean and Ray going public and saying that there should not be any attempt to diverge from the platform, as though somehow this really mattered and the people of Australia were interested in these sorts of public statements about what faction is trading against what faction.

I suggest that people out in the real world do not want to know about the internecine squabbling within the ALP, they want to know what the Government will do to improve the telecommunications system and what it will do about effective competition. The notion of somehow merging OTC and Telecom and playing the resulting organisation against poor old Aussat, which is barely breathing, is a classic ant versus elephant exercise. It has nothing to do with what might have happened 10 years ago, as the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) well knows, because the Labor Party was never in favour of anything other than a 100 per cent monopoly controlled Telecom. At least there seem to be those in the Labor Party now who think that that is less than a perfect situation for the 1990s.

Let us talk about the 1990s and what will work in Australia if the Government is to get the price of one of its most expensive inputs down significantly. If the Government wants to see subscriber trunk dialling (STD) rates fall by 40 or 50 per cent, which it can easily do--

TALK.START.PARA: —They have done it already.

—If that is what the Minister thinks, then we know where he stands. He has no more interest in what has happened overseas with the introduction of real competition on the STD long trunks than he seems to have understanding of what the debate is all about.
—He will be gone in nine months, do not worry!

—That is right, there is not long to go. The fact is that telecommunications in this country has been mollycoddled for years. That monopoly has been propped up by all the factional interests in the Labor Party, by the union movement in particular. The public sector of the telecommunications industry is something like 75 per cent unionised, whereas the private sector is only about one-third. That is reflected time and again in the sorts of deals that can be done. We get ex-Telecom employees standing up in Caucus, presumably pretending that they are being objective, and arguing time and again for some form of monopoly protection that will satisfy the union. I think that Senator Richardson's contribution said it all in that regard. If the interests of the ATEA will be what determine telecommunications policy in this country then, as Mr Keating said, `God help the country'. I can only say that I am not encouraged-nor is anyone who is interested in genuine reform-by what we have been subjected to in recent days.

SPEECH.PARA: The timetable is urgent. The need for competition is great. We have already waited six years. The Government seems to have no conception of urgency; all it is interested in is playing little party games as though the Party platform is somehow what it is all about, as though somehow some factional compromise is what it is all about. I think most of us on this side know that it is about a lot more than that-it is about real competition, it is about service for the customer, it is about getting the systems right and it is about realising what will happen in the 1990s in terms of furious technological developments that will simply overwhelm any attempt to somehow keep the borders in place. As long as we go on with that sort of insular attitude, we will simply get the telecommunications system we deserve.
I conclude by harking back to the terms of the matter of public importance, namely:
The Government's continuing refusal to put the national interest in a fully competitive telecommunications industry ahead of its own factional agendas.
This is one of the saddest reflections on the policy paralysis that is besetting the Government at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The only contribution that Senator Alston made to this debate that made any sense at all was when he said, `This issue is of fundamental importance to the national interest'. It certainly is.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make two points about just how fundamentally important this issue is-not to Great Britain, the United States or Japan, but to Australia. There are two areas of enterprise in this country of vital national importance in which overseas comparisons are always fraught with a great deal of danger-that is, transport and communications, and for obvious reasons. Senator Alston has a well-established record for his mindless, ill-informed and consistent attacks on Telecom Australia; in fact, he once described Telecom as a `sheltered workshop'. It is interesting to note the comments made by Senator Alston in Melbourne from time to time as to the attitude that is taken on the same issue by some of his conservative colleagues who represent areas of Australia that are outside the six capital cities. The one turn in this debate which I am personally delighted about is that after 12 months of ducking, weaving, prevaricating and lying on this issue, members of the Opposition have come clean, as Senator Alston has said, and finally admitted to the agenda which the Australian Labor Party accused them of having and which was specifically denied by their political representatives during the last Federal election campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —They rolled the Nationals.

—Precisely. Senator Tambling, for example, dodged, weaved and ducked and during the election campaign in the Northern Territory-my own little patch-again and again he categorically denied that it was the intention of the Opposition to sell Telecom. He said, `We are not going to do that'-because that was the Opposition's existing public position-`we simply want to free it up at the edges in areas like cellular phones'. Of course, all honourable senators are well aware of that line run by members of the Opposition. Finally they have come clean and stated positively that they want to flog the lot.
—What is wrong with that?

—That is highly hypocritical. Senator Alston would not come to this debate with the cleanest hands considering his contributions in the past. It is pretty hypocritical of the Opposition to come to this Senate and say, `We want a great overhaul of the telecommunications area which is long overdue and desperately needed by the country', when the only contribution in my memory that it has made to telecommunications in Australia is Aussat. We all know what has happened to that. That is a pretty hypocritical stance. Finally, the Opposition has come clean in saying that it wants to go--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Collins has referred specifically to Senator Tambling and Senator Alston in a context in which he has talked about `lying'. Despite there being no evidence--
—I have not accused either senator of being a liar. Sit down, you are just wasting time.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I understand that it is unparliamentary to make any such reference to an individual senator. As Senator Collins has certainly not sustained that accusation, I hope he will deny that he has made any such allegation towards an individual.
—Order! Provided there is no assertion towards any individual, there is no breach of the Standing Orders.

—Members of the Opposition finally have come clean in this debate and admitted publicly that they want to sell, in their entirety, all of our major telecommunications carriers in Australia. What is wrong with that? I will tell the Senate what is fundamentally wrong with that. I have already referred to the great danger of the simplistic, mindless comparisons with countries such as Great Britain and the United States. In the area of transport and communications, we have to look for an effective Australian solution designed for the horrendous problems we have in this area. Australia has one of the most difficult transport and communication tasks of any country in the world. Australia is effectively-and this is the fundamental root of the problem-a continent the size of the United States of America with a population the size of the city of Los Angeles. That is where these comparisons fall to dust and become absolute nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston made reference to waterfront and coastal shipping reform. In this great continent of ours we have got 12,000 miles of coastline, barely 17 million people and widely dispersed ports, yet these same stupid silly comparisons are made. It is nothing more than blind ideology for ideology's sake. What nonsense for Senator Alston to come in here and pontificate about the factions within the Australian Labor Party when the Opposition has produced, after at least three years in here of denying that it was going to do it, a policy requiring and committing it to the complete sell-off of Australia's telecommunications to private interests.

Senator Alston gets far more highly excited about the particular views in the Labor Party on telecommunications than I do. I am very glad that these views are being expressed in the Australian Financial Review and the Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —Really?
—Yes, really.
—It is open government; I will give you that.

—It certainly is. It would be a very moribund and anaemic party indeed-in other words, the kind of party represented opposite-that would not engage in discussion on an issue of such fundamental importance to the national interest of this country as the disposition of its telecommunications network.
—So you would have no compunction about dropping a Cabinet document-you don't seriously believe that.

—I have no compunction at all about encouraging that public debate and having all those views canvassed, as they finally will be at the national conference. Senator Alston is terrified at the prospect of actually having a real debate on an issue. He thinks that is something to be condemned. His party has a far better system. The political representatives of Senator Alston's party go out on the hustings and tell the people who are voting for them precisely the reverse of the real agenda they are running.
