Senator Alston has got conservative colleagues who go out on the hustings, reassure the electorate that they are not going to sell Telecom and then, as a party, get together behind locked doors, engage in a debate that nobody hears about and produce a total about-face and a reversal of its stance.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no difficulty at all in that sense with having all these issues widely broadcast, because I am pleased to belong to a political party that does treat an issue as fundamentally important to the entire nation as the disposition of our telecommunications carriers as we do. Senator Alston has said that this is a factional thing. What a load of nonsense. As someone who has been a member of the relevant Caucus party committee on transport and communications for the whole time I have been in this Parliament and a member of other parliamentary committees dealing with this same issue, the reality-and Senator Alston's ideology would blind him to it-is that the position adopted in the various parts of the Labor Party is based on the fundamental concerns that the people expressing those views have for the outcome of the issue.

I may disagree with the particular position they are putting but all of the participants in this debate that I have dealt with as a Minister in this portfolio and as a member of the Caucus committee have not based their concerns on factional ideology. They share a broad philosophy about what final outcome will be of maximum benefit to this country-not to the United States of America, Japan or Great Britain but to Australia.

The only concern that the Opposition has is this blind faith in competition-sell it off, flog it off, dispose of our entire telecommunications network, put it into private hands and everything will be all right. The cold hard fact is-and the Opposition refuses to acknowledge it-that there will always be a natural monopoly in the areas of both transport and communications in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't seriously believe that.

—Senator Alston is denying that and saying that it is nonsense. It is a fundamental, demographic fact of life to which Senator Alston is blinded. I take an example again that Senator Alston has used. It is silly to compare the ports of Australia, for example, with those of Copenhagen, Europe or the United States of America. In Australia we have very small volumes of cargoes by international standards, widely dispersed ports, 12,000 miles of coastline and only 17 million people. Even if maximum reform were introduced on the waterfront or into shipping, there would always be a natural monopoly. The same applies to telecommunications.

SPEECH.PARA: By international standards, we have a very small communications market in Australia-a huge continent with a tiny population. As a result, there will always be a natural monopoly while ever the population of this country remains at about 17 million people spread across 3 million square miles of continent. Of course, Senator Alston simply wants to place that natural monopoly in the hands of whatever carpetbaggers turn up on the doorstep first with a paper bag full of money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Collins, you must withdraw that comment.

—I withdraw that, Mr Acting Deputy President. The truth is, as the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Powell) has already referred to, that the National Party of Australia should hang its head in shame on this issue. It has run around my patch and no doubt elsewhere. For example, the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Tim Fischer--
—Poor Tim!

—Poor old Tim. He issued a press statement prior to this about-face on policy on the issue of Telecom-not to his Opposition colleagues, who have just sold out him and all his constituents, but to us, the Government. Why did he put out this press release? We are committed to the retention of a publicly-owned telecommunications operator in this country, but we want to free it up with competition. Despite the persistent interjections from Opposition senators that have been continuing now for something like 10 minutes, we will do so. In the light of that reform, minor by Opposition standards, the Leader of the National Party was provoked into putting out a press statement, getting stuck into us, and saying, `Any moves to privatise or amalgamate Australia's major communications systems must take into account the need to provide adequate economic services to rural and remote Australians'. Indeed, they are the Australians who are going to be flushed down the drain by what the Opposition has now finally admitted publicly it is going to do.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the Opposition's policy of completely privatising all of our major carriers in Australia will fragment the market in which a natural monopoly will, in my lifetime, continue to exist, despite the efforts of any government, because of the size of our population and the continent we live in, and hand that natural monopoly over to private enterprise to do as it will. Will private enterprise continue the $530m program that Telecom currently has in force for providing direct dial private telephone services to remote Australians? I think not. Will it provide all of the community service obligations that Telecom provides? I think not.

Where do we go to find assurances for remote Australians in what the Opposition is proposing? There is a little paragraph in its policy that says that that will be a direct Budget item. Well, good luck, folks! I know enough about the Budget processes and the tough negotiation that goes on among all Ministers and across all activities in the public sector to trust the disposition of telecommunications services to an item in the Budget. Remote Australians will suffer very directly from this outrageous proposition. I am at least pleased that the debate has been brought into very sharp focus by the Opposition, for once in this debate, being just a little bit honest. Australian taxpayers will miss out on the dividends that Telecom and the OTC Ltd currently return to them as shareholders. More importantly, telephone users will miss out on Telecom and OTC profits being reinvested into their networks.

Senator Alston is continuous in his mindless attacks on Telecom. The facts do not stand that argument up to very good analysis. One measure of the effectiveness of an enterprise is the price to consumers. I have not time in this debate to go over the many other aspects which, particularly for Australians who live in remote parts of Australia, demonstrate the effectiveness of Telecom's operations. Telecom is the second largest employer in this country. It employs some 84,000 people. It operates a telephone service, very efficiently by international standards, across 3.5 million square miles of country. It handles 10 billion calls a year, with about eight million telephones connected and hundreds of thousands of others about to be connected. In addition, it has managed to bring about a progressive reduction in the cost to the consumers of those services despite the enormous difficulties and costs of providing them across our nation.

Between Melbourne and Sydney STD charges have fallen in real terms by 45 per cent in the past five years, and by a massive 85.2 per cent since 1975. Senator Alston knows that that is true but chooses to ignore it. In the same time off-peak rates have plummeted by a massive 60 per cent and 89 per cent respectively. Currently, Telecom's plans, which are already being implemented, point to further substantial cuts in the STD rate. As a `remote Australian', I have to say that Telecom, with an organisation of its size and complexity, is not perfect. Telecom recognises that itself. In my view, it needs competition and constantly to review and update its services. But by and large it is not only an efficient organisation; it is a superb national asset which the Opposition has now nakedly and finally announced it intends to flog off to the highest bidders, who will then be able to use that natural monopoly in our telecommunication services not for the benefit of Australians, but for their own profits and to hell with the rest.

There may be some short term advantages for those Australians who choose to live in the half a dozen cities in which the majority of our population is concentrated. But to Australians who choose to live elsewhere-and one hopes that for the national good of this country more people will continue to live elsewhere in Australia-the Opposition's proposal is a disgrace. It is totally contrary to the national interest. It is completely a result of the blind, ideological pursuit of people such as Senator Alston who are not interested in debating or examining the issues.

The Australian Labor Party (ALP) is committed basically to three principles. The first is that there will be competition introduced into the system for Telecom. Second is the principle that we will establish a fully publicly owned telecommunications entity that is capable of competing successfully and aggressively on international markets. Thirdly, and just as importantly, we are committed to ensuring that the ordinary consumers of Australia-all of us-benefit from the reform program that the Government will be introducing.

Finally, I say on behalf of the ALP and the Government that we will oppose as vehemently and as effectively as we can-and in my own case with some degree of heat and a considerable degree of commitment-the Opposition's outrageous proposition, despite the denials of its political representatives during the election campaign to the contrary, that there be a total sell-off to private interests of all telecommunications carriers in Australia. Such a policy is totally opposed to the national interest. On the other hand, the Labor Party is committed to a reform process which, while providing the best possible deal for consumers, will retain in the national interest and in national and public ownership the major telecommunications carriers of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Collins said, finally the Opposition has come out of the closet. It is interesting that it has done so during the Budget period with its plans, which we all believed were under the surface anyhow, to privatise Telecom Australia, hoping to bury it away. But it is not buried away. The Budget was such a ho-hum exercise that focus has been brought into particular sharpness today by Senator Alston having a go at his favourite portfolio-we all know what a reluctant shadow Minister for social security he is-by bringing this matter of public importance before the Senate today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will totally privatise-that is official. The National Party of Australia has sold out its country constituents. This flows from the blind, unquestioning lip-service that is paid to mythical goals of competition and deregulation-lip-service paid not only, regrettably, by the Opposition, but also, particularly of late, by the Government. I hope that Senator Collins in this debate has not been engaging in any way in a similar sort of exercise to that in which we have seen the Opposition engaging on the question of telecommunications carriers.

I took Senator Collins to be saying that we should not put up the provision of community service obligations and its cost as a Budget item because that would be vulnerable. It certainly would be vulnerable under a coalition government at any future time. But Senator Collins did not say how those community service obligation costs would be met. He did not say that cross-subsidies would be retained. All he said was that we would retain public ownership. The question is: How would the community service obligation of our telecommunications carrier, which under a Labor Government will continue, as he has said, to be in public ownership, be met? It is a key question which has not yet been answered.

Ministers Beazley and Keating have skilfully directed the debate from the question, `Do we need competition?' to `How much competition will we have?'. They have done so without providing any concrete evidence, any more than the Opposition has, as to why competition is necessary or even desirable, and avoiding the detail of where there is to be competition, what kind of competition it should be and, most particularly, in which regulatory regime that competition will be introduced. The two key questions that remain unanswered by Senator Collins's somewhat passionate speech are those: how will the community service obligation costs be met, and within which regulatory regime will competition be introduced?

The Australian Democrats and many others, including significant sections of the Australian Labor Party, are convinced that deregulation will disadvantage the average consumer. We have already experienced deregulation of financial institutions. In 1983 we were promised viable financial institutions maintaining consumer-oriented practices. But what did we get? We got bigger profits for banks, higher charges and interest rates for consumers, and instability in the financial sector. As a Victorian I have seen some of the worst results of that instability, and I am sure that the Federal Labor Government is not terribly happy with the consequences for its Victorian colleagues of some of the results of that financial deregulation. It is our contention that we can expect for ordinary Australian consumers a similar result in the area of telecommunications. Therefore we remain implacably opposed to competition on the basic telecommunications network.

I wish to make it clear that it is not just the Australian Democrats and some elements of the Australian Labor Party who have these concerns. The term `telecommunications users' was used by Senator Alston in his speech. I point out that there is a national network of telecommunications users which has as its constituent member organisations the following groups, whose members represent the wider community and who are extremely concerned about the trend in this debate: the Australian Consumers Association; the Australian Council of Social Service; the Australian Financial Counselling and Credit Reform Association; the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, some of whose members I saw in the gallery earlier today; the Communications Law Centre; Disabled Peoples International; the National Council of Women; the Rural Telephone Subscribers Association; and the Telecom Action Group.

Australia's telecommunications system is, of course, our nerve centre. The nation's cohesiveness, its efficiency, its competition and its security are all dependent upon that system, a system which the Opposition wants to sell to the highest bidder. It is our contention that the system currently serves Australia well. Telecom bashing has become almost a refined national sport in recent years. The result has been the development of a public perception that Telecom is not serving the country's interests well. I must say that the spokesperson for the chief coach in that national sport for many years has been Senator Alston. He is doing it again today.

In spite of the fact that neither the Opposition nor the Government particularly likes letting the facts get in the way of a good argument, I think we should look at the facts in this debate. If we ever hear facts from the Opposition and lately from the Government, they actually tend to come from the same source. It is quite interesting that Professor Henry Ergas, one of the key advisers, first of all to the Opposition, and now to the Department of Transport and Communications and the OTC Ltd, at least seems to provide `the facts'. Those are `the facts' that are being used by the Opposition-and have been used for many years-and that now are being used in the argument between the Beazley model and the Keating model on the Government side.

But there are other sources of facts. I commend to the Senate and to all who are interested in this debate Mr Jack Keavney's book, Telecommunications: The Time for Truth. Jack Keavney is not exactly a public sector monopolist advocate. He is a former Director of the Freedom from Hunger campaign. His earlier book, Private enterprise the winning way, argued the legitimacy of profit and the benefits of competition. He has a long record in private industry.

He wrote this book because in his line of business travelling overseas he had so many bad experiences with these wonderful telecommunications networks that we are supposed to want for this country. He came back here and was so pleased with the contrast between what he has experienced here as a business person and what he has experienced overseas. I do commend this publication as an independent voice in this debate claiming that the information we are getting both from the Government and the Opposition is far from independent.

I will just put some examples on the record. In the 1988-89 financial year, Telecom Australia made a profit of $973m for all Australians. Senator Alston came here and kicked it around the head for doing that. The average charge to consumers for a basic service increased by just 1.2 per cent, well below the consumer price index. Telecom had an operating revenue of $7,977m. That was an 11 per cent increase over the previous year. Costs rose by only 9 per cent, reflecting efficiency in productivity gains. There was an improvement in labour productivity of 12 per cent, and between 1985 and 1989 Telecom trimmed full time staff numbers by over 10,000 workers.

Importantly, Telecom currently purchases around 90 per cent of its materials and services from other Australian companies, and 70 per cent of those materials and services are Australian made. The value that Telecom added to these goods and services in 1988-89 was somewhere in the region of $6.4 billion, a contribution of 2.6 per cent to Australia's gross domestic product, probably the largest contribution of any individual Australian enterprise, an enterprise which is owned by us, the general public. Out of this Telecom was required to pay to the Government payroll tax of $136m. So I claim it is a myth that Telecom is not serving us well, because the reality is different. Remember, it is owned by all Australians still.

OTC, our international carrier, is recognised as being internationally competitive and innovative, and its charges are the lowest in the world in purchasing power parity terms. Aussat Pty Ltd seemed to be the albatross around the neck of Australian telecommunications. As recently as yesterday in the Australian Financial Review, Professor Bill Melody, former chief economist to the United States Federal Communications Commission and now Director of the Centre for International Research on Communications and Information Technologies in Melbourne, called Aussat a potential goldmine. He believes it could capture 8 to 10 per cent of the total market using its own and Telecom's capacity. Why hand a goldmine over to private interests when it could make money for all Australians?

The Australian Democrats propose to bring these telecommunications carriers together to allow a stronger base to compete internationally and ensure the best provision to the public. We need to beef up Austel and set in place a regulatory regime so that where we do introduce competition-and not on the basic network, in our view-it is seen to be and is, in fact, in the interests of the wider community and in the interests of genuine increased efficiency and not in the interests of some private corporate entity. We must always come back to the question of whether or not competition is valuable in the wider community context. We need to consider the effect deregulation will have on average consumers, those people that I listed earlier, both in terms of the costs of services provided and the equity of access to those services. Access must never be forgotten.

Proponents of deregulation on both sides are very selectively presenting overseas data to try to con the public. Again these are more facts that get in the way of a good argument. In the United States (US) in 1984, the ATT monopoly, which was a private monopoly, was broken up. In the 50 years prior to that, the average cost of the telephone service had declined by approximately 60 per cent. In the first year of divestiture, customers' telephone bills actually increased by an average of 17.1 per cent. The fierce competition is along the thick routes. That would happen here. Local calls would become more expensive. Subscriber trunk dialling (STD) zones would get smaller, so the higher charges would begin sooner. Big business would be the beneficiary.

There are many other facts which I am not going to have time to put on the record, but the end result is that many citizens in the end cannot afford telephones. There has been an attempt in the US to target the community service obligation payments, and it has failed. In Maryland, for instance, it costs $70 to disperse $42 of assistance. Yet we want to substitute cross-subsidy within an efficient public carrier making hundreds of millions of dollars for us Australians for something as inefficient as that.

In the United Kingdom (UK), Mercury, the competitor, will not install phones in country homes. Mercury callers cannot access British Telecom phones, and 20 per cent of people in the UK now cannot afford phones. Canadians, of course, are required to pay for directory assistance, and within the metropolitan areas local calls are now timed. In New Zealand local calls are free, but STD rates are much higher than in Australia and they apply in a much smaller area.

In contrast, public monopolies maintained in such countries as France, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Switzerland and the Netherlands all have top quality telecommunications systems. The Australian Democrats reject this gung ho privatisation and deregulation introduction of competition approach. It has been taken on both sides. The only beneficiaries would be big business and those consumers on the thick routes, the Canberra-Sydney-Melbourne axis in the south-east corner of Australia. Cream skimming would leave Telecom to shoulder the burden of remote users and other less profitable sectors. We must ask the question, particularly of the Opposition but also of the Government-which would debilitate Telecom by free introduction across the board of competition-if Telecom had been on the market five years ago, who would have bought it? The answer is Alan Bond. Where would we and the consumers of Australia be now? He had to go to Chile.

Let us just say that the Democrats are entirely behind the continuation of a strong and combined telecommunications carrier in this country, the retention of cross-subsidy and the retention of good, efficient service. We are not saying that there is not a need for further efficiencies-there is-but that that should be our goal through a publicly owned telecommunications carrier in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —A party which cannot govern itself cannot govern the country. If ever a statement returned to haunt its author then certainly that was it. It is indeed a truism that we all remember who said it-it was the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), repeatedly, during the March Federal election campaign.
—He was right.

—Senator Tate says that he was right. Indeed, the Prime Minister was right, and ever since the election we have seen to whom that statement applies-the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and this Hawke Labor Government. Consequently, and sadly to the detriment of all Australians, we have seen this Government, ever since that March election, racked by bitterness, dissension and division across a whole range of issues, between a whole range of Ministers, and between Ministers and the back bench. As a result this Government is now quite unable to take decisions which are urgent, which are necessary and which are in the interests of all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Among the most important of these issues, of course, is the future of telecommunications as an industry in Australia. What we see in the words of the matter of public importance which has been proposed by the Opposition today is the Government's continuing refusal to put the national interest, in a fully competitive telecommunications industry, ahead of its factional agendas. The Government has sacrificed the national interest to the self-interested demands of its left wing factions. Despite its own acknowledgment that one of the key areas for micro-economic reform must be the introduction of competition in the telecommunications industry, it has heeded the self-interested howls of protest from the unions, and from its own factional opponents, and agreed to defer any decisions with regard to the future of Telecom Australia until it has been told what to do by the delegates at a national Labor conference next month. The result is that we have a duly elected government that is afraid to take hard decisions. It is afraid to govern without the say-so of its back room manipulators in the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU).

We have a Government in total disarray, with Ministers making conflicting statements on telecommunications reform, and bickering publicly about which options should be adopted or, indeed, if any should be adopted. The monumental failure of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to make any provisions for micro-economic reform in last night's Budget is a tragedy of enormous proportions for the future of this country. It is yet one more opportunity which this Government has wasted to try to remedy some of the damage it has done to the Australian economy over the last seven years. None of the crucial issues of micro-economic reform were addressed in last night's Budget. Australians, in particular with regard to this debate, will still have to put up with an inefficient and costly Telecom.

Revenue is up in real terms in last night's Budget, but it depends heavily on slugging provisional taxpayers, and squeezing government instrumentalities such as Telecom and others. The Treasurer should have used last night's Budget as a centrepiece for a three-year strategy of comprehensive structural reform. This of course involves an anti-inflationary strategy, as was outlined in the coalition's Economic Action Plan, industrial relations reform, transport reform, privatisation, taxation reform and most importantly, in the context of this debate, telecommunications reform. But none of these were addressed in last night's Budget. If one had listened to the Budget Speech, and read the Budget Papers, one would think that they were not important issues.

In looking at the need for telecommunications reform the submission which the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, put to Cabinet, with regard to reform, analysed the benefits of competition to the consumers and concluded that telephone charges would be lower for most consumers. His submission drew evidence from a wide range of studies, and reports, to support conclusions which the coalition had already been advocating for a long time. The benefits of competition, which the Cabinet submission identified, include: greater productivity resulting in significant cost savings; lower tariffs and charges, especially on long distance calls; a wider choice of services and products; and an improved service to customers as management competed for customers. Despite all this evidence the Government cannot agree on what is best for the communications industry. It is no further towards implementing any changes than it was when it came to office seven years ago. It seems to have missed the point that competition is the key to improving service, and also to achieving lower costs, not only in telecommunications but in all areas of industry including service industries.

We have on the right-hand side Minister Beazley advocating a merger of Telecom and the OTC Ltd to form megacom, perhaps more accurately described by some as monstercom, presumably based on the `big is beautiful' theory, and to sell off Aussat Pty Ltd to form the base of a second private network. The whole of Mr Beazley's duopoly plan of combining Telecom and OTC and having only one other competitor in Aussat is seriously flawed. Austel pointed out in its recent report on mobile telephones that duopolies bring few benefits, but have real disadvantages. There can be no real competition when there are only two so-called competitors because they get together, rig the market, and deny the consumer the benefits that wider competition can bring. In the middle, of course, we have the Treasurer wanting to sell off OTC to form a second competitive network. On the left side we have the left wing factions of the Labor Party and the unions, most particularly the telecommunications unions, burying their heads in the sand and refusing to contemplate anything that remotely smacks of competition or privatisation, with their ideologically blinkered and self-interested arguments being applied to the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Protecting their own monopoly.
—And protecting their own self-interested monopoly. I ask honourable senators to listen to the statement put out by the left wing of the ALP after a meeting earlier this month:

SPEECH.PARA: This meeting reaffirms its opposition to privatisation proposals in the aviation and telecommunications industries.
A further quote is:
. . . to maintain our campaign to mobilise party members to defeat the current privatisation drive within the ALP.

If that is not a challenge to micro-economic reform, I do not know what is. The response that we have heard from Senator Collins has been interesting. It is also interesting that Senator Beahan is to speak for the Government later in this debate but Senator Childs, who is one of the most vocal opponents of any change to Telecom, is not speaking in this debate. He has been gagged by the Government because it knows of the division that racks it and it does not want that put on public display in this debate today.

Of course, we do not only have dis- agreement on the Government side as to which is the correct path to follow; there is also disagreement about when it will make a decision. Micro-economic reform, of which this major change to our telecommunications industry is a very important part, was supposed to have been a major goal of this Government during its last three-year term of office. Despite its re-election in March, and one would therefore presume with the support of the Australian people to belatedly proceed with some of these reforms, it cannot do so. That is because the Labor Party comes before the Australian people. The views of the Labor Party are given more prominence than the views of the Australian community. As I said earlier, the Government needs the approval of a special national conference of the ALP before it can do anything, if ever it can decide which path it will eventually follow. The Government did not act during its last term in government and, of course, after its re-election Ministers Beazley and Keating indicated that change was urgent and it would be detailed in the Budget. They acknowledged that an urgent decision was necessary.

As recently as a fortnight ago Senator Cook agreed that it was important for telecommunications changes to be detailed and announced in the Budget. But the Government has allowed its hands to be tied by the unions and by factional disputes. We now see the decision is delayed to some indeterminate future time after the September special conference. Just look at a sample of some of the headlines in the newspapers, as a result of this indecision and brawling which are going on in the Labor Party, `Keating faces Telecom defeat; Dawkins concerned over Beazley's megacom deal; Telecom reforms anger ALP factions; Left warns Government: Keep to policy; Keating's ``arrogance'' riles backbencher; Beazley's grand plan clashes with Labor Party platform; ALP lines crossed in brawl over megacom; Reform urgent, PM tells Beazley'-that is a laugh and yet there is no sign of any reform. We see delay and procrastination despite the overwhelming evidence in favour of competition in the telecommunications industry.

When New Zealand introduced competition and deregulation overall prices fell by 21 per cent, in real terms, between 1988 and 1989. In Japan, competition has resulted in lower charges for many services, including trunk calls, cellular phones and pagers; and, of course, there was no increase in the cost of local calls. Australia does not compare well with other developed countries in the areas of communication charges and productivity. Australia has the second most expensive local telephone call charges after Britain on a three-minute basis. Our local call charge is 21c compared to Japan's charge of 9c. Canada and the United States do not charge for local calls at all, although a local call area is admittedly somewhat smaller than in Australia.

It is interesting to note the improvements in the New Zealand telecommunications system after deregulation there. Before deregulation it took six weeks to get a telephone installed; now it takes two to three days. It used to take two days for a repair team to arrive; now it arrives within hours. There used to be 85 lines per employee and already their workplace efficiency has increased so that there are 98. Of course, there is scope for further improvement there.

I have already mentioned the improvement in call charges. Where there has been partial deregulation of the Australian telecommunications structure in the international sphere, there has been a general fall in communication costs. These range from a 5.6 per cent fall in international telephone call charges to an 11 per cent drop in international telex charges in the last year. Telecommunications cost analysts, NUS International, which provided these figures, say that the partial deregulation of the industry with regard to its international aspect in July 1989 is responsible for Australia's improving position on international communications costs.

There is the evidence for the benefits of deregulation, yet the Labor Party and this Government continue to refuse to act on this evidence and evidence put to its own Cabinet. Even if it was willing to ignore its ACTU masters, the proposals that it is looking at do not begin to go far enough and would not produce real and effective competition. I have referred to that earlier in my remarks. All that the Government's proposals would do would be to strengthen government control and deny Australian consumers the benefits of real competition. It would appear that it is only the coalition, the Liberal and National parties, which has a firm commitment to the degree of competition that is required. In this country we desperately need a telecommunications system that provides the best service possible to the whole Australian community, can be delivered at economic and affordable costs, is based on sound economic and investment decisions, will stimulate investment, employment, exports and technological advances, and meets the needs of customers on installation, maintenance and service standards.

As I said, it is obvious that only the Liberal and National parties have a complete and consistent plan for full and effective competition in communications. Privatisation is a key aspect of ensuring effective competition and the benefits that that will bring to all Australians. Therefore, a coalition government will have, as its first priority with regard to telecommunications, full and effective competition. Upon election to government, it will proceed immediately with the privatisation of Telecom, OTC and Aussat within that framework of full and effective competition in telecommunications.

The timing, pace and conditions of that privatisation will be determined having regard to all relevant factors and the capital market's ability to provide the funds. It will be managed to ensure that Australians retain majority ownership and control of strategic telecommunications assets. Of great importance in the privatisation process will be the opportunity given to employees of Telecom, OTC and Aussat in acquiring shares. There are other details of the Liberal and National parties' policies. But this Government refuses to act. Only a future coalition government will achieve the desired goal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I am amazed that members of the Opposition have chosen to have this debate now. They must be hard pressed in thinking up topics for matters of public importance, given, as Senator Collins has pointed out, their previous record in this area and their proposed policy-if a two-page press release can be given the honour of being described as a policy. I am happy to cross swords with the Opposition on this subject because it demonstrates fundamental differences between the Opposition and the Government, between the Liberal and National parties' approach to policy formulation and that of the Australian Labor Party and the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the Opposition have trouble coping with the concept of internal party debate or, for that matter, with the concept of community consensus. They very often criticise the concept of consensus in this place. They are a top down organisation. They have always been a top down organisation, and they are showing no signs of changing to fit a changing world. It seems to me that they are relating much more to some of the moribund nations of eastern Europe, which are now finding that the top down way of operating simply does not work and that community consensus is the way to go if one is going to get anywhere. In their parties the membership has no real say, nor have they ever had any. Coalition members of parliament in this place can ignore party policy. The coalition platform does not have the standing that a party platform of the Labor Party has. Labor's platform is binding on members. The rank and file of the Party have a say in the processes of policy making, have a say in the ultimate policy and bind their parliamentarians to follow the policies that are decided by a much wider group of people.

The Liberal and National parties do not work like that. As I have said, they are top down. So their party conferences become meaningless, empty talkfests, with the television coverage focused on the bulky figure of John Elliott swaggering around, rather than with any substantial debate around any issue. Everybody, including the journalists, knows that ultimately it does not matter what is decided at those conferences, because the parliamentarians are free to do what they want to when they get here.

In contrast, the Labor Party takes its internal democracy seriously. I am not ashamed of that; I do not think that anybody should be. It has done this for nearly 100 years now. Members opposite need to be reminded that the Labor Party is not only the oldest party in continuous existence in Australia-it will be celebrating its centennial next year-but is also arguably the oldest social democratic party in the world; although there are some arguments about that with Germany. It has a structure which, whilst not perfect-and I would be the first to admit that-makes a genuine attempt to involve members and to involve through those members the broader community. It tries to achieve consensus between the various points of view on some of these fundamental and substantial issues. The fact that there is widespread debate, particularly on issues which go to fundamental beliefs of party members and, by extension, fundamental beliefs of the community that they represent, is an historical feature of the Labor Party. I believe it is a strength, not a weakness. I am certainly not ashamed of it. I am a lot prouder of that sort of process then I would be of the sort of process that drives both the Liberal Party and the National Party.

The factions are a part of that process. I am not going to mount a defence of factions, because I do not think I have to defend factions to members of the Opposition; it is really none of their business. But the factions are a part of this process. They are an informal means by which internal party debate is organised and co-ordinated. Factions have become the focus for various streams of opinion within the Party. The Party itself represents a wide cross-section of opinion. In the main, factions fulfil a positive role. Senator Alston's posed concern, and Senator Chapman's for that matter, about the role of factions sit uncomfortably with the views of the State President of Senator Alston's own Party in his own State-Victoria. Michael Kroger, the Director of the Liberal Party in Victoria, made it quite clear that he thought that it might be worth considering introducing into the Liberal Party a factional system similar to that of the Labor Party, because we seem to manage our affairs much better. He was sat upon fairly quickly and he has not said it too many times since, but he did say it initially, and I believe that is his view, despite the fact that he has been told not to express it because it might make it seem as though we are more successful than they are.

I have no problem with debate on this important issue. I think that is a healthy process; I think it is a process that the Liberal and National parties might copy; nor do I have a problem with the role of factions in facilitating this process.

The motion refers to the Government's continuing refusal to put the national interest in a fully competitive telecommunications industry ahead of its own factional agenda. It is because the Government is committed to finding a solution in the national interest that the debate is going on. It seems to me, given the two-page statement of policy that the press release from Neil Brown indicates, that the Liberal Party and the National Party would be well advised to go through the same process, because it is very clear from that document that there has not been very much thought given to the implications of the apparently very simple things that are expressed in that document.

Unlike the Opposition, the Government is not driven by blind ideology, as Senator Collins has already indicated. It is not quasi-religious zeal that determines our policies. The whole approach of this debate towards the telecommunications question recognises that the telecommunications industry is a strategic industry of considerable importance. It recognises that it is undergoing rapid change with almost exponential developments in the technologies that drive change within the systems at a national level. It recognises that the telecommunications industry must be positioned firstly to provide a modern, efficient, technologically advanced and competitively priced system for the domestic market; that that system should be a seamless system, where a phone call in a country area can get through to any part of the world with relative ease-not like the system that applies, for example, in America, which is often cited by the Opposition, where it is fine if a caller lives in New York or San Francisco or Chicago; but he should try making a call to Australia from Phoenix and see how he goes. If he can get anybody who even understands where Australia is, he will then be shunted from one company to another until he finds one that can actually give him a link through to Australia. That is not a seamless system; it is not an efficient system; but it is, as a result, an increasingly expensive system. It certainly does not compare with the system that we have here.

A telecommunications system needs to position itself, then, to provide that modern, efficient, technologically advanced system at the domestic level, and that system needs to be seamless. It also needs to position itself to be able to take advantage of the rapid growth in telecommunications around the world and particularly in our region. It needs to have a critical mass to be able to compete with some of the massive organisations at an international level in the region where this development is occurring. It needs to position itself to achieve the development of a domestic telecommunications industry.

A telecommunications system also needs to recognise that the telecommunications industry must also satisfy certain social and economic imperatives. It must ensure, for example, the delivery of community service obligations (CSOs). It must ensure the fulfilment of regulatory requirements, including the setting of technical standards, for example. It must ensure that once adjustments are made for the costs of providing CSOs and regulatory requirements, it should earn an appropriate commercial rate of return on the funds it employs, and that it should earn that return not by pushing up prices but by creating greater efficiencies.

Despite what has been said by the Opposition, much has already been done, because the current debate is part of a long process of reform, starting in 1975 in the Whitlam years. Nothing happened in the intervening period, but it was taken up again in 1983 by this Government. So Labor has a very good record, and one in stark contrast with the Opposition's record, which Senator Collins has already drawn attention to, with Aussat being the Opposition's only claim to fame-and a pretty poor one at that. Even the Davidson report was being dumped by the Fraser Government in the years just before we come to government.

Much has already been done. Telecom's regulatory function has been transferred to Austel. The Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics has carried out detailed investigations into the identification and costing of Telecom's community service obligations. In all government enterprises, realistic figures of the value of their assets and of the total funds employed have been compiled so that, for example, through different accounting systems Australia Post found, when it revalued its assets, that it had to add $1 billion to the sum total of its assets. That has been done to Telecom as well.

The consumer price index (CPI), minus X formula has been applied. That is a formula by means of which increases in Telecom and OTC charges must, on average, be below the general rate of inflation by a defined margin. The margin is now at about four points below the CPI. There has also been more liberal access given for Australian users to Intelsat and other satellite systems. These have all been part of a whole raft of reforms to which these next stages are going to add. It is not simply a one-off thing, as to reform has never occurred before. We have been reforming telecommunications in this country on a consistent basis since 1975 with very little help from the Opposition.

Now there is a need to look at two issues in this reform process. One is enterprise structures, and the other is the sources of funds to maintan and expand these enterprises, not only in telecommunications but in other government business enterprises as well. The Government has been involved in a process of gradual reform, as I have said, not only in Telecom but in all government business enterprises, with the aim of developing-in telecommunications, in this case-a system which maximises the benefits to individual consumers and the nation as a whole through improved efficiency in the provision of services.

Now, the Opposition's policy, in so far as it can be called a policy, is predicated, as I have said, on a blind ideological belief in privatisation. This belief expressed frequently with almost religious tones by the Opposition is that privately owned enterprises are somehow superior per se to the publicly owned enterprises. That is simply not so and it is demonstrably not so. It is predicated on the faulty premise that privatisation is synonymous with competition. There are very good examples of that in England, where privatisation has not led to competition. It has led to a duopoly that is very highly regulated and which is being complained about by almost everybody there. A recent report by Professor Michael Beesley and Mr Bruce Laidlaw of the Institute of Economic Affairs is called `The Future of Telecommunications'. It says:
Major decisions taken when BT was privatised have tended to produce less competition than is now possible and desirable and unless modified will continue to do so. Mercury's-
which is the second carrier in England-

present strategy offers an insufficient direct challenge to BT on price, quality of service, or range of customers served. Although it has the potential to do much more, it is not likely to become a formidable alternative to BT in the long term without a change in policy.

There are other consumer responses which are negative in respect of competitive achievements as well. It is a policy which does not concern itself with benefits to individual consumers. It does not concern itself with the nation. It does not concern itself with the achievement of increased efficiency or of lower prices. To the extent that it shows any concern for CSOs, as Senator Collins has already pointed out, this is undermined by its system of funding. I would not trust our Treasurer to maintin CSO levels as a line item in the Budget year by year. I certainly would not trust the opposition if it were in government.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I have no concern about the open debate that is occurring within my Party. I think that is a positive thing on an issue which is highly complex and which deserves that sort of attention. Finally, the Government can make its decision in its own good time, not when the Opposition says it ought to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —This telecommunications debate is really about competing interests. It is the national interest versus the Australian Labor Party (ALP) political faction interests. What it is really about is who will succeed Bob Hawke. We all know that both Keating and Beazley want to be the next Prime Minister. Until now nobody thought that there was any competition for the current Treasurer (Mr Keating). Well, a victory for Beazley in this debate will help his prospects no end. It seems that Keating is staring defeat in the face on this issue and that the failure of Mr Dawkins, the Keating ally, to convince the Centre Left of the need for competition-and he has clearly failed to convince Senator Beahan-is bad news for the Treasurer. The Centre Left's faction convener, Senator Beahan, said that the faction's position `certainly would not be very close to the Keating position'. That is putting it on the line. There will be no support there for Keating. Even within his own faction Keating is losing out and Mr Beazley's aspirations are getting a shot in the arm.

SPEECH.PARA: What about Senator Richardson's nice intervention in this debate? He is a good numbers man. When Senator Richardson comes out and says, `I don't think it really matters' you can bet your bottom dollar it matters a hell of a lot. But Mr Keating is bound not to take defeat on this issue lying down. There are reports that the Treasurer wanted to take Austel away from Mr Beazley's portfolio. He has been successful in these endeavours before; he was quite successful in taking the Industries Assistance Commission away from Senator Button and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. Of course, when Michelle Grattan criticised the Treasurer in the Age the other day she said:
. . . he has also let his impatience and arrogance run free. He has acted as though he is the Communications Minister'.
So this debate is clearly about who will have the power when Bob Hawke goes. It is all about numbers. That is not the way to run a debate in the public interest.
Senator Beahan, who claimed not to be concerned with ideology, is a colleague of Senator Childs who managed this wonderful quote last week in relation to the proposed ALP conference on this issue:

We know we haven't got a majority at the conference, but we believe from the reports of other sections of the party that we can get something that is in conformity with the spirit of our platform and yet might-
note the word `might'-
satisfy the need to have a modern, effective telecommunications system.

Is that not terrific? With a bit of juggling around the edges the factions might let Australia have an efficient and modern telecommunications system. Yet Senator Beahan tells me that this is not about ideology. We have heard from both Senator Chapman and Senator Alston, who outlined very successfully the arguments, the disagreements and the ructions that are running through the Labor Party on this issue.

Senator Alston clearly outlined the desire of the trade unions to have total control over our telecommunication systems, come what may. From Senator Collins we got what I can only describe as an historical and hysterical contribution. It bore little relevance to the entire debate. He was simply trying to argue that the Opposition, by introducing a strong and powerful debate at this stage in the new Parliament, was somehow at odds with the position it had taken before the election. In case honourable senators had not noticed, this is a brand new policy; it is one that we will be promoting hard and strong; it has a lot to do with the interests of Australians and nothing to do with ideology.

These arguments were typical of a man trying to defend the indefensible-the Labor Party's lack of a coherent policy in the area of micro-economic reform which is highlighted by this telecommunications debate.

Senator Powell made the usual confused Democrat contribution. As always, she was trying to be the lackey of the Government while trying to appear independent at the same time. When Senator Beahan, belonging as he does to the great party of nationalisers, gave us his apology for the faction system, he deigned to mention eastern Europe, which is finally throwing off the yoke of oppression of nationalised ownership of all those things which make up a free economy. Eastern European countries will be taking the bull by the horns and entering into free market economies and they will surpass us if we have this Government in control much longer.

There are very positive things to say about this new policy of ours. First, Australia needs an honest and effective telecommunications system with true competition, which will result in our having efficient and cheaper services for consumers and better opportunities for exporters. We certainly do not need to repeat the error of the two-airline policy. Mr Beazley is advocating a duopoly. He would give us again the errors of the two-airline policy, with one government-owned entity and one free enterprise entity, resulting in a cost plus situation instead of competition to give effective lower prices to consumers.

It is necessary to place Telecom into private hands in order to have a truly competitive system which gives benefits, as I said, to exporters and consumers alike in the domestic market. Very simply, we would have a system which would provide the best service possible to the whole Australian community, which could be delivered at economic and affordable costs, which would be based on sound economic and investment decisions, which would stimulate investment, employment, exports and technological advances, and which would meet the needs of all consumers on installation, maintenance and service standards.

What is wrong with the telecommunication system we have got? Let us take a look at the management objectives. In its August edition, the Business Council Bulletin considered the New Zealand experience, and defined the necessary elements. Management objectives were high on that list of priorities. At the moment we have a great problem with poorly specified and contradictory objectives for management. Managers require clear and unambiguous objectives to maximise the commercial performance of any firm. It should not be up to Telecom managers to assess non-commercial objectives; that is the role for politicians to be pursued in a cost effective way; that is our job. Managers require authority to make key decisions required to achieve efficient commercial outcomes. They must be free to make those decisions on recruitment, remuneration, dismissals and procurement of inputs. The sacking of George Maltby of the OTC Ltd reveals that managers in telecommunications in this country have little authority to make managerial decisions. But managers should be allowed to manage.

Under a government regime, reporting requirements are artificially set. The most appropriate form of stewardship is demanded by shareholders in the operation of the market. That requires true competition. Salaries need to be linked to performance. There must be a genuine attempt-and this was denied to OTC-to allow bodies to operate in an effective way.

From the New Zealand experience we have seen some salutary lessons. A whole new structure of Telecom has removed the costly controls imposed by old, centralised, bureaucratic structures. Very specifically, staff numbers have been reduced by 1,400 in the head office, while the total work force has been reduced from 25,000 to 19,000 and it is expected to fall to 14,000 by the end of the year. More efficient pricing is being achieved through the removal of cross-subsidies between local and long distance calls. Consumers have already benefited from 20 per cent reduction of toll rates and business rental reductions. Contracting out of services is being used extensively. The rate at which telephones are being installed has increased fourfold while the waiting time for the installation of telephone lines has been reduced from six weeks to less than 72 hours for 96 per cent of customers.

The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has criticised the Hawke Government for its lack of sound telecommunications policies. The OECD has maintained that greater private sector participation and competition should be allowed. Specifically it proposed that repairs and installation should be open to the private sector. Competition between existing transmission modes could be increased and modi- fications to the structure of telecommunications prices introduced to bring them more in line with marginal costs.

The Government has asserted that somehow we use privatisation as a credo. We certainly do assert that the private system produces more efficient results than does public ownership. But before anyone becomes involved in the privatisation debate for Telecom or anything else it is really necessary to get rid of a few myths. First is the point that privatisation needs three things to be viable: one, it needs to bring about an improvement for consumers; two, it needs to bring about an improvement for employees; and, three, it needs to bring about employment for managers. If we meet those three criteria the benefits are most valuable.

Very often the privatisation debate becomes confused with the need to reduce debt as though somehow the reason for privatisation is merely the retirement of government debt. But the efficiency gain is the primary role for privatisation. Secondly, it is a nonsense to assert that when a government has a so-called community service obligation, that government must somehow be involved in the production of that service. That quite clearly is a non sequitur. In most cases, social objectives can be pursued through far more efficient means of transfer payments than through the direct provision of subsidised services.

The most vital efficiency improvement can be derived only through the final step of private ownership. The Opposition has brought forward this policy which it will propound and propose in a most definite and determined way. Only with the full involvement of the private sector can there be provided the necessary incentives to provide Australians with a system of telecommunications that has been denied them. Privatisation will ensure that employees who buy into telecommunications will at last have a genuine stake in the performance of these firms.

At the present time in this country we have one million shareholders and we have three million trade unionists. I look forward to the day when in this country we have more shareholders than we have trade unionists. I look forward to the day when we have more people who have a stake in Australia's future, who are willing to invest in Australia's future, than we have people who are simply an appendage to it.

The Opposition has brought forward this policy at this time because it believes that it is important that if micro-economic reform is to be achieved it has to be put on the agenda at this time. The Government has fudged through two elections claiming that it was dedicated to micro-economic reform. And it fails every test. It failed in its last term and it will fail in this term. As I said right at the beginning, this debate on telecommunications is about who will succeed Bob Hawke, not whether or not Australia gets a better telecommunications system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —(South Australia) (4.44)-In speaking in this debate, I first want to respond to Senator Bishop's comment about hoping one day to see more shareholders in Australia than trade unionists. If I am correct, Senator Bishop is a fully qualified lawyer and as such I believe she is probably a member of the New South Wales Law Society which would have to be one of the most effective trade unions in Australia. It is a trade union that has the luxury that no other trade union has. Not only does it act as a trade union in the protection of its member interests but over the years it has been given under statutory laws of various States the right to set its own fees, its own salaries and its own conditions. I hope that in the micro-economic reform debate that we are having in this country Senator Bishop does not always direct her attention at the blue-collar workers whom she seems to despise. I hope that she also looks at the professional groups such as the legal profession that she is a member of and that under any definition is ripping off people in this country, is inefficient and has more restrictive trade practices operating than any other professional interest group.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to see decent micro-economic reform operating not just in the area of traditional industry but also in the area of the professions. I have never yet heard anybody in the Liberal Party, any lawyer in the Liberal Party, stand up and criticise the operation of her profession when it is ripping off the public of this country because of its restrictive trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about getting back to the topic?

—I will get back to the topic. I will get back to the topic of telecommunications. As a member of the Federal parliamentary Labor caucus transport and communications committee, I belong to a number of subcommittees which are debating and dealing with this issue of telecommunications. I have a long interest in telecommunications. During the Whitlam Government I was principal private secretary to the then Postmaster-General when the old Postmaster-General's Department was broken up into two commissions-the Australian Telecommunications Commission and the Australian Postal Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to point out to Senator Bishop and other Opposition members that since the end of the Second World War the only changes that have taken place in telecommunications and the communications industry have occurred under Labor governments. In the late 1940s it was the Chifley Government that established the Overseas Telecommunications Commission. For the next 23 years Liberal coalition governments did not do a thing in telecommunications except allow the then Country Party to rort the system of telecommunications. As someone quite rightly pointed out, under the policies of the then Country Party it would have been cheaper for the Postmaster-General's Department to buy a farm than connect it with a telephone.

The Whitlam Government established the two commissions. What did the Fraser Government do for the next seven years? Nothing, except respond to Kerry Packer's suggestion that we ought to have a satellite system in Australia. Kerry Packer woke up that it was going to go broke so he got out of it. The Labor Government inherited Austel which, at the last count, has probably lost something like $600m to $800m. So, a Labor Government has always bitten the bullet on making changes and reform in telecommunications. So when we hear the members of the Opposition bleating now about not enough change being made, that they are the only ones with the solution, we have to be more than a little cynical.

The only thing we have seen from the Opposition is a two-page statement released, I think, yesterday or the day before, by Mr Neil Brown, the shadow Minister for communications, outlining the Opposition's full privatisation program. I think that whether one believes, disagrees with or supports privatisation or deregulation, one aspect of this statement that has not been given the publicity that it should be-I hope it will be in the future-is paragraph 6 where the Opposition outlines how it is going to handle community service obligations (CSOs). How would the Opposition fund the loss making areas in telecommunications in Australia? Quite simply, it would put it in the Budget. I cannot think of any promise that the Australian public is more likely to treat with mistrust.

A coalition government may put the community service obligation in a Budget. But we all know that in a year or so, when things get a bit tough and the coalition is looking for a few savings, it will be the first to say, `Well, we'll cut $200m off the CSO and put it back on the consumers'. We know that is what would happen. The coalition certainly would not go and ask its mates in private industry, who would be running the private sector in a deregulated and privatised telecommunications system, to make a reasonable contribution when they are cream skimming against Telecom. I think that is going to become an important part of the debate. At least I can say to the Opposition, `I am glad you put it in writing; we finally know how you are going to try to fund CSOs'.

Over the last two months my colleague Senator Burns and I, as members of the Telecom working party of the Caucus committee, have sat through eight or 10 full days hearing ranges of submissions from all sides. I now have a stack of paper about five foot high of all these submissions. A couple of things came out of all these submissions, from all sides-from both the public and private sectors, from the carriers, from the private interest groups, from the pressure groups, from the public and so on.

One thing is for certain: there is no Western country that has an open, freely competitive, free market system of telecommunications, and nobody proposes it. No-one says, `We want to have a free market'. When you say to some of the people in the private sector who want to have some competition, some opening up of the system, `Well, let's be fair dinkum. Let's have a complete free market. Let's have no regulation. Whoever wants to establish a system, go for it and do it', they are all absolutely horrified. When it comes to the bottom line they want only one thing: a duopoly, a triopoly or a quadropoly. All they want is the license to get a cut of the action. They do not want competition from other people. They just want to be given the license to have a section of the action, a section of the profits.

A number of these people made it quite clear that in a duopoly or a triopoly, or even under the regulated system that Senator Bishop and the Opposition are proposing in their document, even with a privatised Telecom, there will be only three or four operators. They will not want anybody else coming in competing in an open market. They will want us with regulation, with a tribe of regulators-100 or 1,000 more regulators than we have at the moment-to ensure that they are protected, that they do not get open competition.

The United States of America is used as the great example of open competition. The Chairman of Bell South-and I do not think he would mind my mentioning his name-came to Australia and gave evidence to our committee. I do not think that was the only reason he was in Australia, but he was certainly keen to give evidence to our committee. He explained that when American Telephone and Telegraph (ATT), the regulated monopoly in America in the early eighties, was broken up, the one big monopoly was replaced with about half a dozen regional monopolies. He said that as an executive in ATT he opposed the break-up. But once it was established he found that in the area of Bell South, covering the 43 million people of the southern States of America, it had a stronger monopoly than ATT had. It is able to buy up more of the small private telephone companies. No-one can compete against it; it controls the market.

The only area in which there is open competition in America amongst a number of competitors-but again it is regulated; there is a set number-is that of trunk calls between different regions of America. But in Bell South's area, the southern States of America, there is no competition on local telephone calls. There is a regulated, guaranteed monopoly for Bell South. There are similar examples all around the world where so-called competition is supposed to operate. There is not open competition; there is a regulated duopoly, quadropoly or whatever it is and nobody from the private sector wants it any other way.

So the Opposition should not go on giving us this hogwash in its statement about free competition. It does not want free market competition; it wants a regulated system that gives two or three private sector organisations the opportunity to get into the market with certain protections guaranteed to them.

In all the discussions that we had, as I say, I saw no evidence anywhere to argue that it is demonstrably true that competition against the network is going to provide any better service to the range of telecommunications consumers in Australia. I certainly agree that there is a case to be answered-and I support it-that in a large number of areas in the add-on services there should be competition and Telecom should not have a monopoly. In many of those areas I think we will end up with a better service to the public. I believe, for example, that the first telephone monopoly should end at the socket, not at the phone. I think we will get much better customer service from Telecom if there is competition between Telecom and other companies in providing the first phone.

When I asked one of Australia's biggest telephone manufacturers whether he would be worried about the ending of the first phone monopoly, he said, `No, as long as you give us two years notice and as long as you allow Telecom to compete in provision of the phone, we would be more than happy with it'. One of the members of the committee asked, `What about the import of cheap telephones from Taiwan, Hong Kong and so on?'. He said, `Look, you do not understand. Our company here in Sydney exports telephones to Taiwan. The phone that we provide to Telecom we sell in Taiwan. Why? Because technologically it is a superior phone. It will not break down if it is accidentally dropped. We use highly technical manufacturing procedures and so on'. He made it quite clear that he thinks that there are great opportunities for a more vigorous part of the market, and I think that is an area that certainly should be looked at. I find it interesting that a company in Australia is already exporting telephones to Taiwan-something I am sure Senator Bishop would support, because she at times tells us that she is very interested in trade matters.

I say in conclusion that what the coalition has put before us in this document of two days ago is a very glib proposition. It will not work, it will create chaos in telecommunications, and above all else, the ordinary consumer will end up paying more. I agree that there is a great debate going on in the Australian Labor Party at the moment over what we should do with telecommunications and other micro-economic reform, but it should be remembered that the Opposition was in government for 30 of the last 40 years and did absolutely nothing in this area. It never had a debate about it. The only thing that was ever done when Senator Brownhill's party was in government and running telecommunications was to rort the system to make it inefficient to pay off a few old mates in the back blocks of Queensland for the Queensland National Party. That is the sort of policy we had under the coalition.

We have tried to get all the rorts out of the system, to get an efficient telecommunications system and we have done much better. We are not perfect, I agree, but the proposals we are putting forward will mean we will get a better telecommunication system. But we will not, in the grip of some ideological mayhem, throw out the baby with the bath water and destroy a telecommunications system that, on balance, has done a good job in Australia. We certainly want to see it improved. I believe that the Government and the Labor Party in the next month or so will come forward with a proposition that will improve our telecommunication system, but we will not put it forward in the way the Opposition has, which is basically a recipe for chaos.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The debate is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON CERTAIN ASPECTS OF THE AIRLINE PILOTS' DISPUTE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Government's response to the report of the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, in August last year there was a strike by the airline pilots of Australia, members of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. They were after an increase of about 28 per cent in their salaries. This was resisted very strongly by the management. One of the arguments that was used at the time was that the productivity of the airline pilots was very low and some very false statistics were put out as to how few hours the pilots flew in a year.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us deal with the truth about the low productivity, if indeed it was as low as it was alleged. The artificially low figures were arrived at because the number of pilots who were involved in retraining programs was very high, because it was at a time when the 737s were coming into the airline inventories. The principal reason why pilots did so few hours on duty, up to the recent past in Australia, stemmed principally from inefficient practices of the Australia airline managements. Airline managements had not been in the business of trying to get productivity. They had given in to union demands on behalf of the flight attendants, the baggage handlers, the transport workers-the whole lot of their employees. Whatever they wanted the airlines always gave them, so at the end off the day they were getting less work than they should have got out of all their employees.
Airline Pilots Dispute

The legislative requirements imposed by the Department of Civil Aviation and, latterly, by the Civil Aviation Authority also limited the productivity of Australian pilots. While there is a theoretical maximum number of hours laid down by the regulatory authority that a pilot can fly, so many other conditions apply along the way that a company could probably get only about 70 per cent of the nominal hours that were allowed out of air crew because of excessive regulation.

The pilots went on strike. The management resisted and then the pilots resigned because they had advice that they would be subjected to legal action. The consequences of that for the nation were really quite tragic. Many lives have been seriously harmed and the careers of many people have been destroyed as a consequence of a dispute which was allowed by the government of the day to continue to the great detriment of the individuals and the nation. The government of the day failed to recognise its national responsibilities to mediate, to guide and to resolve the issue between the disputing parties. As the Senate inquiry showed, it could have been resolved from about the middle of September. At that point the Australian Federation of Air Pilots was ready to settle on any terms, but the Government and the airline managements conspired in a massive lockout. If the management alone had run a lockout, one can imagine the bleatings of a Labor government. We would have been back to the early days of the Industrial Revolution.

The consequences were that many people lost their livelihoods. Honourable senators only have to visit Cairns in my own State to see the empty shops and the tragedy there. People borrowed all the money they could to start businesses to support the tourist industry, and now those hundreds of families have lost everything they had and will never get restarted in business. It is the likes of Senator Collins and Mr Hawke that brought those people to the economic hardship and bankruptcy that they face today.

It is now 13 months after the strike started and, sadly, the consequences are still with us. The airline services that exist in Australia today are not a patch on what they were 12 months ago. I was coming out of Darwin the other day and I said to the Australian Airlines booking clerk, `How long will we be in Mount Isa?'. He said, `Sir, we do not stop in Mount Isa now'. I said, `But you always went Brisbane-Mount Isa-Darwin-Mount Isa-Brisbane'. He said, `Since the dispute, Sir, we cannot afford to go to Mount Isa except for two days a week, perhaps'. The story is true. Cairns has probably about a quarter of the services that it had before the dispute. Of course, the damage to our international reputation as a tourist country simply cannot be quantified.

What happened when the strike started? The first thing was that the Government conspired with the airline management to totally destroy the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. As I have said continually in this chamber and in public meetings outside the chamber, I have never carried any brief for the Air Pilots Federation. I believe it is badly advised and made an enormous mistake, but it has paid for that mistake. In the conspiracy we saw the Government using the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) and the Royal Australian Navy as strike breakers, running a commercial service with the Australian defence forces at rates that were ruinous for the Defence budget because they were very heavily subsidised. The figures probably reflected about one-sixth of the true operating cost of running the Boeing 707s and the C130s that were put on the line. It was a gross abuse and was something that the members of the Australian Defence Force felt very bitterly about. They are prepared to do anything in a national emergency such as floods, bushfires, cyclones, and instances of that nature, but they do not see themselves as tools in a political war, which is the position the RAAF and the Navy were put in when they had to fly services for paying passengers through last year.
