We also saw the importation of strike breakers. It is one of the sad things of life that members of the Australian Labor Party today have no knowledge of their history and their ideals. The incumbents here-the minor union officials and the small time schoolteachers who inhabit the ranks across the chamber-have no knowledge of the ideals and the traditions of their great Party. For members of the Labor Party to support strike breaking, let alone strike breaking by the armed services and by importing workers from overseas, as they did and are still doing with airline captains and pilots, is just unbelievable. Overseas crews and aircraft were brought in. The Government used every resource it had to persecute the pilots, not to resolve the dispute.

It was against this background that the Senate resolved to set up an inquiry in the latter part of 1989. I was a member of the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute. I have served on committees longer than any other member of that Committee. But I must say that I have never served a committee that so acutely embarrassed me as that Committee did, because it was a blatant political ramp. I apologise publicly to those witnesses who appeared before the Committee and who presented submissions to the Committee for the way they were treated in such a blatant party political exercise as that Committee turned out to be.

Senator Collins was one of the ringleaders. He got his reward in a ministry. He carried the can very well for the Government, defending the Civil Aviation Authority, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, and the airline management at every opportunity, hectoring witnesses and doing what he could to grab cheap publicity through the hearings of the Committee.

I do not wish to rehash the evidence that was given to the Committee, but I will repeat what I said earlier: from the middle of September the Pilots Federation was prepared to settle on any reasonable terms, but it was not allowed to be spoken to or negotiated with by the Government and the airline management.

What happened throughout the dispute? One of the things which concerned the Senate and which led to the setting up of the inquiry was the fact that many people were flying aeroplanes in Australia who did not know and understand the Australian safety regulations and the Australian air traffic control procedures. The evidence that was given to the Committee showed quite clearly that there were a significant number of serious breaches of air traffic procedures. People were carrying out illegal and unauthorised maintenance procedures on aircraft. We had a case with one of the foreign airlines of internal wrenching bolts in the nose-wheel landing gear being sawn so that they could be put in with a screwdriver instead of being put in with an Allen key and torqued up. We had evidence of inadequate familiarisation before licences were granted to foreign pilots. Even more bizarre were numerous examples of flight crews not being able to speak English and not being able to communicate with air traffic controllers on the ground. In one situation an aircraft was pushed back in Sydney-an air hostess gave us this evidence-and the crew jumped off as the aircraft was being pushed back. When next seen, they were arguing under the wing of the aircraft after it was pushed back from the terminal.

We also had incidents of charter operators from the European theatre using the techniques of European charter operators; in other words, they were operating very close to the bone, using minimal fuel loads when operating into places such as Townsville and Cairns where the weather systems are different from what they are in Europe and, more importantly, where there is not the availability of alternative airfields within five minutes flying time. It really is a long way to fly from Townsville to Mackay in those circumstances. Fortunately, we got through that situation without any accidents at all, but it was more by good luck than by good management.

The Committee also heard evidence that the Civil Aviation Authority could not have done more for the management of the airlines in the first phase of the dispute. It bent over backwards to facilitate the entry of foreign aircraft and foreign pilots and to waive and bend regulations. After a week or two of this it got frightened and, for the major part of the dispute, tried to apply its regulations as well as it could. But, sadly, we saw the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation operating as an instrument of the Government and not as a professional body.

Where are we now? We are in a position where we have got a very poor airline service in the country. The economic health of the airlines is considerably reduced as a result of this debilitating strike. The airlines are still in difficulty recruiting pilots. It is astonishing that the Australian Labor Party tolerates the persecution of the former members of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. They simply cannot get jobs with the airlines now. The airlines are recruiting pilots overseas. They have recruited so many pilots from overseas that there are hardly any Australian nationals as captains of aircraft, and the managements of the airlines have had to instruct the crews on the flight decks that only people with Australian accents make the announcements to passengers on take-off because the airlines have so many American, British, South African and other foreign nationals flying as captains of Australian aircraft. The airlines are still running this embargo against employing Australian nationals.

Not only that, but in a very sneaky way, by regulation, the Government ran through an amendment to the migration regulations so that these pilots recruited from overseas and flying for Australian airlines are now entitled to Australian citizenship. As a senator, I do a lot of migration work, and every month I see a number of young people who come to Australia on work permits and working visas, who speak English well, who have skills that make them employable in the Australian community and who not only wish but are enthusiastic to become Australian citizens. I have to turn them away because they do not meet Australian migration requirements. Here we have a government conspiring with the airline managements not to employ our own capable pilots but to recruit pilots overseas. Ansett Airlines of Australia is still recruiting today.

Finally, where are we today at the end of the dispute? The dispute started over a salary claim of about 28 per cent. We now have a situation where the pilots flying under contract are, admittedly, flying more hours-they are flying more hours because the Government's regulatory proposals and the management of the airlines has improved--

TALK.START.PARA: —Double.

—No, not double the salary, but the pilots are probably earning 35 per cent to 40 per cent more in salary than they earned before. So we had a dispute which resulted in airline captains and first officers getting around 35 per cent to 40 per cent more than they earned before the dispute. We have a national deficit because the country has lost billions of dollars as a result of the damage caused to the tourist trade. Many hundreds of innocent Australians involved in the tourist industry and elements of it have had their businesses irreparably destroyed because the Government failed to recognise its national responsibility to mediate and resolve the dispute when it had every opportunity to do so within about four weeks of the dispute starting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a member of the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute. I was, and still am, a member of Estimates Committee B which deals with the civil aviation portfolio. I remember when arrangements were made for Estimates Committee B to be brought back for a special day's hearing in order to give the Opposition every opportunity to put before the Committee its views on what was happening in the dispute, particularly on questions of safety and management. The Opposition was also given the opportunity, at great length, to question the officers of the Department of Transport and Communications. The members of the Committee sat there for a full day. Nothing was brought forward-despite leaked documents, some letters and so on-that could prove that safety was being put at risk in any way that should concern the Australian public.

SPEECH.PARA: Because that one day hearing did not serve the purpose of the Opposition, we then had to go through the charade-and I remember it very well-of the performance of the former Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Fred Chaney, standing at the table accusing Senator Collins and me of being thugs, bovver boys, standover merchants and so on, because we had the temerity to ask witnesses who had leaked documents the background and details of them. When the witnesses could not answer properly, we had the temerity to make the point that the Opposition had not proved its case. Because the Opposition senators were able to convince the Australian Democrats, particularly Senator Sanders as he then was, that it may not be a bad idea, the Opposition won the vote to establish a select committee. So Senator Collins and I were called upon to serve again, this time on the Senate Select Committee.

The Committee sat for days and heard evidence in droves from all sorts of people, including members of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP). We heard piles of evidence about the so-called breaches of air safety. Senator Collins and myself, and other members of the Committee, knew more about every so-called safety breach in air regulation, about turning left at Corryong by 15 degrees rather than 20 degrees, about someone not speaking the right language or misunderstanding a direction-in some senses, the most extraordinary trivia that we went through day after day. At the end, we did not find one scintilla of evidence that safety had been compromised, despite the extraordinary efforts of Senator MacGibbon in particular and Senator Brownhill to exaggerate and extrapolate from the most baseless assertions that air safety and the people flying in Australia were at grave risk.

Senator MacGibbon, in his 15-minute speech today, made more errors than I have ever heard any other senator make in the 3 1/2 years that I have been here. It was an astonishing speech. Senator MacGibbon exaggerated and, although I know it is not parliamentary to say that he told lies-I know I cannot say that-when one compares his speech with the evidence and the transcripts of the Committee's hearings, none of the things he said today stand up one iota. It was just an astonishing speech.

The most astonishing thing of all is that Senator MacGibbon impugned the reputation of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. He said that it was the political weapon of the Federal Government. He said directly that it was carrying out the political instructions of the Federal Government in the way that it was investigating all these so-called breaches of air safety. Senator MacGibbon did not tell honourable senators that so many of those reported breaches were organised by the Federation of Air Pilots and its supporters in order to use every opportunity to lodge complaints of the most trivial nature. Senator MacGibbon did not bother to tell the Senate that members of the Federation of Air Pilots harassed pilots, that the Federation occasionally may have put air safety at risk by trying to jam radio messages and harass pilots as they were being briefed in their briefing rooms at airports. Senator MacGibbon made no mention of those matters.

I have to say to Senator MacGibbon that in all the evidence before us, in all those interminable days, the only evidence that ever struck me as getting close to causing a problem in air safety was the activities of the Federation of Air Pilots in harassing those pilots who were still flying. Senator MacGibbon made no mention of that and it is clear-cut in the transcript. To then accuse the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI)-which openly made comments in the hearings explaining the background, comments which destroyed Senator MacGibbon's arguments as a supporter of the Federation of Air Pilots and of its evidence, and which knocked them for six-of acting as a political tool of the then Government is disgraceful.

Senator MacGibbon says that he is not a supporter of the AFAP. I am a member of the Australian Labor Party and my colleagues on this side of the House are all members of that Party. Many of us have close colleagues in the trade union movement. I do not think I have ever seen a member of parliament go to the wall or jump over the cliff so far to support any trade union as Senator MacGibbon did in support of the AFAP.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is not permissible under Standing Orders for a senator to ascribe motives to me which are quite false and absolutely baseless. I ask that he withdraw them.
—The Chair heard quite clearly what was said and there is no point of order.

—Senator MacGibbon did not once in all those days of hearing, particularly when we had the AFAP before us, ask one question or make one comment that would have suggested to the Federation that it may have made a slight mistake or misjudgment in its industrial tactics. No, there was not a word out of Senator MacGibbon at all. There was never any encouragement from Senator MacGibbon during those hearings at the time of the dispute for the Federation to withdraw from the strike. He was telling its members to keep boring on. He was after a political victory that he hoped would destroy this Government. Senator MacGibbon did not succeed. Perhaps that is why he is sitting on the back bench and not on the front bench, as he was before the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon never told the Federation, as Senator Collins did and as I did both publicly and privately, that he felt sorry for its members. For 30 years the AFAP had lauded it over management, and over other unions. The Federation had never suffered a defeat in an industrial dispute. Unfortunately, the Federation believed that it was unbeatable. It adopted the saying `How long can we last?-one day longer than the airlines'. That is what it believed and Senator MacGibbon did nothing to discourage its members from that view. Then Senator MacGibbon seeks to tell us about Labor principles!

The AFAP as a union has flatly refused to affiliate at any stage with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), because that means that it would have to be in an organisation together with people with lower qualifications and lower status. But when there were other disputes in the airline industry in the last 30 years-for example, when the Transport Workers Union of Australia and the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia had their members in dispute and it went to a strike-what did the glorious working class heroes of the AFAP do? Its members busted every picket line one could think of. They never gave one ounce of solidarity to any other worker in any other union in the industry. They were proud of the fact that they went against every other industrial dispute of those members.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then they wanted everyone else to support them.

—They then had the temerity, as my colleague Senator Collins suggests, to call on working class solidarity when for 30 years they had never given one ounce of it. It is a joke for Senator MacGibbon to imply that members on this side of the House have forgotten Labor principles and tradition.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon never at any stage tried to explain why the AFAP said, `We want 30 per cent or nothing'. He did not say, `Go and negotiate'. It was 30 per cent or nothing to start off with. Senator MacGibbon has not attempted to explain that the Federation members all resigned en masse.

I have talked to a lot of old hands in the Labor movement, both blue collar and white collar union members. Every one of them has taken the view that industrial mass suicide took place the moment that 1,700 members of the AFAP resigned their jobs. When that happened, the dispute, in effect, it could be argued, was over. They were no longer in the industry; they were queuing up for their superannuation payouts. I hope that is a lesson that other union members will never forget. The view to be taken is that one should never resign. Was it not Jack Lang who said, `Never put it in writing, and never resign.'?

Certainly Mr McCarthy and the Federation made a dreadful mistake that led their members out into limbo and over the edge of the cliff. Once they were out and had resigned, how could any other union, even if it had wanted to do so, support them? They were no longer in the industry. I repeat that it is a joke for Senator MacGibbon to say that we have forgotten Labor principles. I only wish that we had had an opportunity before the Federation went over the cliff in starting this dispute last year to explain to its members what they were about to embark upon. We would have told them that their actions would not succeed because the Federation had broken every Labor principle. It went out unilaterally. It did not seek the support of the trade union movement. Indeed, it did not seek the ACTU's support when it first started. It said, `You can all go jump in the lake'. It called on the ACTU only after it had committed a number of industrial errors, including the fact that its members had all resigned. It then called on working class solidarity. It is a classic lesson of how not to run an industrial dispute.

If the Labor Government at the time had given in after several weeks to the airline pilots, there would have been industrial anarchy in this country. Who would have been the first person to get up to criticise it? Who would have been the first person to cheer? Of course, Senator MacGibbon would have been, because he would have achieved his political objective. His objective was to destroy the wages system and the economy in this country for a political victory. He was hoping that at the forthcoming Federal election he would be delivered into government, because he had nothing else he was offering.

I suppose that it must have astonished Senator MacGibbon and other Opposition members to find that the Government stood firm and did not cave in. The ACTU did not cave in, but stuck to union principles and solidarity not to allow a rogue group of people, who up to that stage had acted unilaterally to destroy an industrial relations system which was to the benefit of the overwhelming majority of Australian trade union members.

I conclude by saying that I served on Estimates Committee B and on the Select Committee into this matter. I do not know how many hours Senator Collins and I put into that Committee, but it was a waste of time in every way. It was obvious from the first couple of days that the political objectives of the Opposition would not be achieved because there was no substance to what Opposition members were raising. Therefore, it was obvious that they would suffer a defeat. However, the hearing dragged on endlessly and it was similar to a fishing expedition. Opposition members were trying to find something, hoping that somewhere the evidence would turn up, and, above all else, hoping that a plane would crash-there is no doubt about that. They could then come in here saying, `We told you air safety was at stake'. That was what the political undercurrent was all about in this dispute. They wanted an accident.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: I think there is an imputation being made against me as a member of that Committee that I was hoping for something to happen. Somebody is playing with the fairies. I think that Senator Schacht should withdraw the remarks about members of the Committee on this side hoping for an accident to happen, because that is an accusation which I do not take very kindly.
—Senator Schacht, if your remarks included any imputation of an improper motive by a particular member of the Committee, you must withdraw it.
—I certainly withdraw it as an imputation against any particular member of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: We had the political exercise put forward to us. It failed-and I am very surprised here-in one last gasp, 13 months on from when the dispute started. I suppose one should admire Senator MacGibbon's gall or hide, in that he would still give it a run; he would still get up here in the Senate and give it a run when the Government puts down its reply to the report. In that sense, Mr Acting Deputy President, I admire Senator MacGibbon for his hide and his gall. I do not admire him for his remarks when he impugns such organisations as the BASI and made remarks that contained innumerable errors. But I hope this is the last time that we have to discuss this matter and waste the time of the Senate on a matter that should not have even been raised with us, because it was a political stunt and a political exercise that failed miserably. Overwhelmingly, the Government's position has been proven correct. Air safety was never at risk. By the firmness of the Government's action and in co-ordination with the ACTU we achieved the preservation of an industrial relations system that has delivered a living standard to a majority of Australians that is much higher and better than they would get under the system that the Opposition proposes to give us. I commend the Government's response and hope the Senate can support it unanimously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having just heard Senator Schacht speaking on this report, which is a Government response to the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute, I wonder whether he is really living in quite the same chamber as the rest of us here, because this is a reply by the Government to a report which makes me wonder why it has given a reply, because there were no recommendations made to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go any further, I think that it would be well for the members of the chamber here and others who may be listening to this debate to know exactly what this inquiry was about. Senator MacGibbon made some very pertinent points on why we wanted an inquiry. Let us look at what the terms of reference were. It was a select committee to be appointed to be known as the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute, to inquire and report not later than the last sitting day of November 1989. The matters that the committee had to look at were:

(a) the nature, extent and legality of all changes to training, licensing, administration, employment and other organisational and operational practices during the pilots' dispute relevant to the operation of airline services in Australia;
(b) the extent to which air safety may have been affected by any such changes;
(c) the nature, extent and legality of the compensation arrangements entered into by the Government and the airline; and
(d) the economic implications of the dispute.

With all due respect to Senator Schacht, who, because of his work on that Committee, of trying to actually hide the problems of it, got rewarded with the Chairmanship of the Foreign Affairs Defence and Trade Committee--
Senator Collins interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, Senator Collins, who was on that Committee, got rewarded with a front bench position, in aviation; but that is another story, because he has got plenty on his plate with looking after Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and other things.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically the Committee was one of the most unpleasant committees that I have served on as a member of this chamber because the Government was never going to agree, right from the start, about the issues which were being raised and which I have just alluded to. Senator Schacht has just given us a dissertation about industrial relations and other things, but he has not alluded once, basically, to the terms of reference that we were asked to look into. He was completely off key. Actually, the whole of the inquiry amazed me. We had television cameras and everything else there the whole time, but the lack of media coverage of the inquiry amazed me. I believe the Government tried to get it off the agenda very quickly. It did not want the people out in the community to know the full facts that were being brought up at the inquiry and it basically kept the inquiry well under wraps. I do not think that there was much about the inquiry on the media at any particular stage. We were concerned at a lot of the aspects that were brought up in the terms of reference. As hard as we tried, we were so often frustrated in our attempts to get to the bottom of many of the points.

Before going through some of the comments that Senator Collins has made in his reply here as the Government's response and some of the other things, I would like to make a couple of points. Of course, we knew from the start, as I said, that the Government was going to agree with the report in this response here today. There was never any hope of a report other than one that was totally satisfactory to the Government right from the start. At that stage, Senator Collins was not a member of the Ministry, and I was amazed at the briefings that he and Senator Schacht were getting from ministerial staffers. This Committee is one of the few committees that I have sat on when I have seen a little track being beaten from the back of the inquiry room up to the table where the Government senators were sitting by people bringing notes and asking the members of the Labor Party on that Committee to ask certain questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —You like to live in the dark, do you?
—Well, Senator Collins, it is not living with the past, I am just trying to--
—'Living in the dark', I said.

—Living in the dark. I am not living in the dark at all. I think Senator Collins was living in the dark, actually, because I do not think he really got to the basis of some of the aspects of the inquiry that he could have got to in order to make it much better than it was.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of safety, we discovered in the inquiry, was and remains very hard to define. I think Senator Collins made that point in the report. I would like to give him one little bit of praise for about two or three words in his governmental response.

I would like to quote again from what John Colewall had to say. He is an executive committee member from the New South Wales Technical and Air Safety Working Group of the Guild of Air Pilots and Air Navigators.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did have a big axe to grind.
—Well, it does not matter whether he had a big axe to grind or not. He is a person of good repute. Some of the points that he made as, he said, some essential features of the safety culture were:

SPEECH.PARA: Priority be given to safety over commercial interests . . .
Just think about that. Was priority given in the inquiry and during that pilots dispute to that? I continue:
Co-operative attitudes among all sections of the industry. Willingness to apply and abide by the most stringent safety regulations and career structure which encourage stability in the industry.

I believe that he made some very pertinent points in the inquiry on those issues, which were definitely not completely dealt with to my satisfaction at that time. Senator Collins alludes in his report to the increase in incidents. He said they should be considered as minor. They were not minor, and it is a miracle and a good reflection on the skills of our air traffic controllers at the time that serious accidents did not occur. I am glad that Senator Schacht did apologise for what he said earlier about us on this side, or me, in particular, wishing something to happen. Senator Collins has said in his reply here, or the Government reply, that there was an initial increase in incidents; the number subsequently decreased to normal levels. Surely that is what we were meant to be doing as a committee-to see whether different things were happening, to see whether there was an increase in incidents. There was an increase in incidents, and now the Government says, `Oh, no, no, they are only minor'. They were minor because nothing happened. Thank God nothing happened! But the position could have been quite the reverse.

We have evidence from the flight attendants, for example, in which the witnesses agreed that some of the Association's members had refused to fly with certain pilots and who quite seriously believed that safety had been jeopardised. I think that some members of the Committee from the other side of this chamber believe that they know more about flying than people who fly every day. For God's sake! Senator Collins does not fly every day. He sits here occasionally and sometimes makes some good remarks. Unfortunately, we sometimes have to give him a little bit of praise!

Witnesses from the Flight Attendants Association gave specific examples of how training and familiarity had been eroded during the dispute because of the dramatic increase in the number of types of aircraft their members were expected to fly. During the inquiry one member of the Flight Attendants Association said:
When it comes to operating these foreign aircraft we do not know which regulations we are operating under.

Surely that was a diminution of safety. Surely that was a lowering of the standards that have been so well maintained in Australian aviation in the past. The flight attendants admitted that they had not made more complaints about it because they feared for their jobs. Surely, if the inquiry had been a proper Senate inquiry, like those carried out by every other committee on which I have served in this place, it would have delved and got to the bottom of these complaints. Instead, the blockers came in from the Government, which made sure that nobody really got to the bottom of any of the complaints.

What about the question of Government compensation? It was never tested and it was quite wrong for the Minister to say, as he has just said, that the Committee agreed that the compensation arrangements entered into between the Government and the airlines were legal. We do not know whether they were legal. That is why we gave a dissenting report. The blockers from the Labor Party came in again and we never got to the bottom of it. It is all very well for Senator Collins to say that we did not push it hard enough, or that we were not able to achieve it. How in God's name could we achieve it when the Labor majority would not allow us to get in independent legal advice? How could we do it? The blockers from the Labor Party were obviously rewarded for doing their job. I do not quite know about Senator Cooney, who was the Committee chairman. He was not rewarded as well as the other two.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't do too well, did he?
—No, he did not do too well, but he tried to chair the Committee impartially. Obviously he did not chair it quite as partially as he should have done.
—Order! Senator Brownhill you are running very close to the Standing Orders.

—We do not really know whether it was legal for the compensation to be given in that way. I will never be entirely satisfied in that regard. Senator MacGibbon and I tried as hard as we could and we could not get any satisfaction on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point in the Government's response was that the compensation arrangements were part of the costs of the dispute which had to be balanced against the costs of yielding to the pilots' demands. When else has this Hawke-Keating Government given compensation and help to others who have been affected by industrial disputes? When has that ever happened in the past? There is a slight reference in the Government response to the effect that the dispute had on the community, and the Government has sought to address the damage caused to the tourist industry with the introduction of an assistance package to help the promotion of tourism. Senators should ask the people on the coast of Queensland whether anything could compensate them for the damage that was done, damage that was caused by two sides of an argument not getting together, and by a Government which has always talked about conciliation and getting people together, but which in this case pushed the two sides apart. The Government took one side of the argument right from the start and crunched the industrial wing of an organisation. I am not standing up for the pilots because they were just as bloody-minded as the owners of the airlines. This Government has a lot to answer for in the way in which it handled this dispute. It drove small businesses in the tourist industry to the wall and its actions have not made the airline industry all that much better since that dispute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I must agree with Senator Schacht. I have heard some concentrated drivel from Senator MacGibbon in the long course of debate, but nothing could even approach the nonsense he delivered here today. Having listened to it with some considerable degree of impatience, I have not the slightest doubt that when Senator MacGibbon was practising as a dentist, as I think he formerly did in Queensland, he would have had absolutely no difficulty whatever in extracting his own teeth from the inside. I am sure of that after listening to the contribution that he made to the debate this afternoon. As Senator Schacht said, his argument was so shot full of inaccuracies and nonsense that it was hard to take any of it seriously. He started off by asserting that the airline services to Mount Isa were discontinued because of the airline pilots dispute. The Darwin-Alice Springs, formerly Mount Isa-Brisbane-Sydney-Canberra route is one route with which I happen to be particularly familiar. The reality is that the services that formerly went through Mount Isa were discontinued for reasons that had nothing whatever to do with the pilots dispute. That might explain the fact that those services were not restored after the dispute ended, even though airline operations have returned to normal. That decision had everything to do with the loadings out of that port. It is said that one man's meat is another's poison: the discontinuance of the services to Mount Isa has advantaged the regional airline operators who operate out of Mount Isa.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an interesting fact in terms of the current debate on airline ownership in Australia, that there is a view put occasionally that the government-owned Australian Airlines, for example, performs a real community service in operating to ports which are not viable or commercial. In fact that is nonsense. Australian Airlines currently services 25 per cent of the ports that it serviced in the mid-1970s. For the last 20 years Australian quite sensibly has been predicating all its decisions on straight commercial grounds. That is why it has discontinued the services to Mount Isa and that is why those services are now operated largely by regional carriers. It had nothing whatever to do with the pilots' dispute.

However, that assertion is typical of the absolute nonsense that Senator MacGibbon has continued to contribute to this debate. The difficulty, as my colleague Senator Loosley has just said to me, is that members of the Opposition have never been able to live with the full-blooded and unqualified support they gave to the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) at the time. They are still trying to get over it.

Senator MacGibbon said that there were serious breaches of air safety procedures. The only thing that particularly upset Senator MacGibbon was that he was trying very hard to hunt for headlines and failed to get them. I can remember Senator MacGibbon standing up in the Senate and predicting that there would be a mid-air collision of jet aircraft over schools and houses in Sydney. He had no basis for saying it, but of course he was trying to get a headline. He failed. It was very difficult, of course, when he and Senator Brownhill were running the same stuff in the Committee. The only headline that I can recall-and Senator Brownhill was complaining bitterly about it five minutes ago-was one about something that was revealed during the Committee's investigations, and one that they found extremely embarrassing. That headline was about a flagrant breach of proper flying procedures by the then President of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, who was caught red handed during the dispute flying an aircraft which he was not endorsed to fly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were any charges laid about that?

—No, and that is a very interesting interjection. As a result of that incident, an airline pilot did suffer, but of course it was not Mr McCarthy. To protect the President of the AFAP, his mate told an untruth-the officers themselves confirmed that-and accepted the responsibility for flying the aircraft. He copped a 28-day suspension of his airline pilots licence, so there was certainly some punishment meted out. Unfortunately, it was meted out to the wrong bloke, but that got a headline.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon talked about major safety breaches. There were two major safety breaches revealed during the evidence given to the Committee. There was a whole string of trivial incidents, comprising the majority of the incidents reported to the Committee, dragged up by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and run dutifully for them by their lobbyist in here, Senator MacGibbon, on a daily basis in both this chamber and the committees of this Parliament.

Most of the incidents were proved to be nonsense. There was just a whole host of them, such as the Air North Pty Ltd DC3 pilots, who were flying F27s for which they were not endorsed to fly. I remember that that interested me, of course, because Air North is a Northern Territory company. One should have heard what the operator of Air North, John Hardy, had to say about that when I contacted him. It turned out to be absolute rubbish, like most of the other things that were raised.

Of course, two serious incidents were revealed during the airline pilots dispute, one of which was described by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) or perhaps the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA)-one or the other-as being genuinely the closest we have ever come in recent times to a major airline disaster in Australia. As Senator MacGibbon knows full well, regretfully that incident involved an Australian Airlines Boeing 737 with an Australian crew on board that had nothing to do with the airline pilots dispute at all. It came within a hundred feet of landing on the Bruce Highway in Queensland, mistaking it for the runway.

The second incident, which was streets apart from the trivia that Senator MacGibbon raised during this inquiry, unfortunately also involved another Australian Airlines 737 operating, I think, into the Cairns airport. Both of those instances were described by expert witnesses to the Committee as being the two most serious breaches of safety that had occurred in recent times in Australian airspace. But, of course, no mention has been made of that by Senator MacGibbon. In fact, I can recall that Senator MacGibbon tried desperately at the time to prevent that evidence from being pursued in the Committee because it did not suit his purposes.

Senator MacGibbon made a most outrageous statement during this debate. It was a contemptible statement. It is the reason I chose to speak. In fact, I did not intend to speak after Senator Schacht contributed to this debate because I think enough time has been spent on this subject. Senator MacGibbon said, and backed it up with a further interjection, that the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation acted as an arm of the Government, not as air safety investigators during the dispute. That is a contemptible statement and Senator MacGibbon knows that it is nonsense.

I have dealt with a great many people and organisations in my 14 years as a member of parliament. As a member of this Senate and the numerous committees on which I have served, I have dealt with many members of various Commonwealth government bureaucracies. Since being a Minister I have had extensive dealings with BASI. I say unreservedly-perhaps under other circumstances this is something I would not choose to say-that, as a result of close contact with any group of professionals associated with the Commonwealth bureaucracy in any sense at all, I have no greater respect for any officers than I have for the officers of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. They are as professional and as dedicated a group of public servants that this country has got.

I must say that in all of the criticisms that were raised by Senator MacGibbon, Senator Brownhill and the other members of the Committee during the investigation, none of them were so low as that made today by Senator MacGibbon. I am sure that he will later regret what he said, although he has shown no signs of it today. He followed up what he said with an interjection, which I hope appears in Hansard, which supported his original statement. That is an outrageous and contemptible statement.

One can criticise the CAA, if one wishes, on a whole range of issues. One can criticise the Federal Airports Corporation, I have no doubt, on a whole range of issues. But, in terms of anything that has come before this chamber or its committees, I would like Senator MacGibbon to find just one incident that would justify that outrageous slur he cast on the officers of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation which, of course, is under my ministerial control. I refute that statement. I think he honestly owes BASI an apology-BASI acted as an arm of the Government!

Another piece of extraordinary nonsense that Senator MacGibbon contributed during the debate, which must have provoked a horse laugh from anybody who has heard of it and has flown on an airline recently, was that the airlines in Australia are so sensitive about the importation of overseas pilots that they have issued instructions that no member of the flight deck who has not got an Australian accent will communicate with the passengers through the public address system.

TALK.START.PARA: —True.

—True, Senator MacGibbon says. I flew down from Darwin just recently on a 767 and 20 minutes out of Darwin I could have sworn I heard a voice saying to me, `Good afternoon. This is your captain speakin'. We are passin' through 25,000 feet at this time. Thank you all for ridin' with us today'. Now, I am sure that was not an Australian accent. But I must tell Senator MacGibbon, through you, of course, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the `atrocious' American accent is an accent which has been noted, remarked upon, and enjoyed in recent times not only by me but by thousands of other passengers on both Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I cast no aspersions on Australian pilots because, depending on the individual, some of them have very, very professional public relations attitudes in terms of their communications with the passengers. But the Americans do seem to bring a very special touch to it and their voices are heard on a daily basis on the public address systems of aircraft around Australia. But that does not stop Senator MacGibbon from delivering just one more piece of comprehensive nonsense to this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are really hypersensitive, aren't you.

—Why? For putting down lies and nonsense? No, I do not think so. The one thing that Senator MacGibbon and Senator Brownhill have great difficulty in reconciling themselves to, in terms of principles, is the full-blooded, unqualified support they gave the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. Prior to this dispute, Australian pilots were the most featherbedded and unproductive pilots operating in any airline system in the world.
—An aristocracy.

—That is a fact. It is an industrial aristocracy, as my colleague Senator Loosley has just said. Who, of course, said that publicly apart from me? None other than the Federal President of the Liberal Party of Australia at the time, John Elliott. He had a great many things to say. He said that the pilots of his own corporate jet `flew twice the hours of any Australian airline pilot and still spent most of their time sitting around doing nothing'. Senator MacGibbon knows that.

SPEECH.PARA: So the Australian Federation of Air Pilots went on strike for a 30 per cent non-negotiable pay rise to add to the already grossly unproductive nature of their flying regime. They would not negotiate. The proof in the pudding is in what is now happening. Senator MacGibbon is a great advocate for the defence in this matter. He defended the pilots again here today, saying, `Well, they are getting all this extra money now, even though'-he adds as a qualification-`they are flying a lot more hours'. I will tell you how many more hours they are flying, Mr Acting Deputy President.

The reality of the strategic nous of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots is demonstrated by the fact that the airlines of Australia are now operating normal services-that is, the same level of services that they operated prior to the dispute with 50 per cent of the pilots they formerly employed; half the number. Of course, they are getting the pay rises that Senator MacGibbon has referred to.

In the course of this Committee's deliberations the pilots of Qantas Airways Ltd, largely unheralded, went before the Industrial Relations Commission without any fuss, without dragging Australia's international aviation sector to its knees and breaking all of the people that operate in that sector, and very quietly and very happily negotiated a pay rise of between 14 per cent and 17 per cent for themselves. Bill Kelty went to the Australian Federation of Air Pilots on more than one occasion to try to help the pilots. I still remember his extremely graphic description of what happened every time he went to them with an olive branch and where he wore it after he left the room.

TALK.START.PARA: —Painfully.

—Painfully. As Bill Kelty said, the Australian Federation of Air Pilots-and it is probably a good thing it did not in retrospect-could have gone to the Industrial Relations Commission without the slightest industrial action, without one single dollar lost to the Australian economy, and negotiated a similar pay rise for its members on the same featherbedded and unproductive conditions that they were still operating under. Instead of that, the Air Pilots Federation destroyed the civil air operations of this country; it destroyed its members; and, ultimately, it destroyed itself. It is a pretty clever trade union that can accomplish all of that in six months. It sums up at a very direct level indeed when one talks to some of the members of that organisation whose lives and professional careers were destroyed by the Air Pilots Federation-which Senator MacGibbon seems to think is such a huge joke.

SPEECH.PARA: One of those members, a former Ansett pilot, had a conversation with me in Smith Street Mall in Darwin which was only typical of many conversations I had, not only with rank and file members of that organisation but with officers of that organisation during the dispute. He said to me, `I received instructions from the union leadership to send them an undated pre-signed resignation from my job'. This was a pilot of 25 years. He said he did so because the Federation had taken a collective decision that the union leadership ran the dispute and it was running the dispute. To quote him almost exactly, he said, `I knew it was stupid when I did it. The day the Federation officers from Brisbane rang me and advised me that they had handed in my resignation along with everyone else's I couldn't sleep. I went home that night and spent half the night sitting listening to records and drinking coffee. I went to bed at about three o'clock in the morning and I tossed and turned for three hours. I woke my wife up at six o'clock in the morning and said to her that that was the most stupid thing I had ever done in my life'. That is a real story, from a real pilot, word for word as he told it to me in Smith Street Mall.

That is only typical of dozens of conversations I had with members of the AFAP during that dispute. That really nailed down for me the true tragedy of that stupid dispute-without any question the most stupid industrial dispute that this country has ever seen. It was not caused-despite the cloud-cuckoo-land that Senator MacGibbon continues to live in-by the airlines; it was not caused by the Government; it was caused by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and chiefly its Executive. It was a tragedy. The entire country suffered, and is still suffering from it. The pilots deserve condemnation for it. But not one ounce of criticism of the AFAP, not even the mildest form, let alone condemnation, have we heard from Senator MacGibbon during this entire debate. Instead we have heard a continued parade of unsubstantiated nonsense and a condemnation and slur on an organisation which does in fact operate professionally and competently. That is to Senator MacGibbon's lasting discredit unless he has enough gumption, enough hide, enough remorse and enough honesty to get up in the chamber-and I am quite happy to give him leave if he wants to do so for five minutes now-and apologise to the Bureau of Air Safety officers for the slur that he cast on them during this debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on the organisation and operations of the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on the adequacy of international terminal and aircraft handling facilities at Sydney Airport. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
