SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the documents.

I wish to congratulate the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on this report on television violence in Australia. I believe that it is a very timely report and it is a subject which has received wide community concern. It is encouraging to note that the interest of the public in this inquiry was overwhelming, with 1,114 individuals and organisations making submissions. This can only go to emphasise the degree of concern about this issue in Australia.

Next to the family, television is probably the most important influence on child development in our society. Children view an average of three to five hours of television daily. By the time he or she graduates from high school the average adolescent will have spent more time in front of the television than in the classroom. The popularity of television is easy to understand: it informs us, it entertains us and it keeps us company. Television, to use its own cliche, brings the world into our living rooms. It is difficult to document the effects of such extensive television exposure on children, and adults for that matter. However, television viewing may be linked with violent or aggressive behaviour, obesity, poor academic performance, active sexual behaviour and the use of drugs or alcohol. I note that such programs have such a critical influence that the Chairman wrote in the preface:
The evidence which emerged provides compelling reasons for considering the recommendations in relation to other areas of the media: For example, pay television if and when it begins in Australia.
Thus it is essential that television is used as a positive, creative force and to avoid its negative influences.

Up to now television stations have been feeding the Australian community a steady and constant diet of violence and tasteless entertainment. This is not only in their normal programming but also in their so-called news and current affairs programs. Indeed, sometimes if one watches half of the television news all one has seen is violence. It has been estimated that by current standards an average viewer will see some 45,000 murders or attempted murders on television by the age of 21 years. This standard diet of violence is not only desensitising the community, and young people in particular, to violence, but also is encouraging an acceptance of violence as a norm of behaviour. It is no wonder that the incidence of violent crimes is increasing.

The latest batch of programs for screening on our televisions includes programs such as Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, a show so popular that it seems to be the only subject in conversations and games with young people, including young children. Yet this show is violent enough that some pre-schools and kindergartens in this country have banned children from playing Ninja Turtle games and playing with those sorts of toys. Another program, Houston Nights, with 36 acts of violence in an hour, promotes the consumption of large quantities of alcohol, casual sex, revenge and the concept that good will win through violence.

Unfortunately, these programs are typical of those on our television screens. This is coupled with the output of television stations which increasingly see news and current affairs as entertainment and compete with each other for graphic footage of violent crimes. I believe that the standard of television stations must improve. I note that this fact is addressed when the report maintains that the best response to the acknowledged community concern about violence on television is by way of supervised self-regulation by television licensees.

I also feel that I should say that parents, particularly when their children are watching television shows that contain violence, ought to say to their children, `Turn the television off'. I think that that is one action that these days parents do not like to take: to stop their children watching television.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Industry Commission has attempted to cover a very broad topic in this reference entitled Pulp and Paper: Bleaching and the Environment. The question is: What does the resultant 112-page report mean to those in Australia who have the task of regulating the environmental impacts of pulp and paper making and to those who produce the pulp and paper? In 1989, the Commonwealth Government developed a set of environmental guidelines for application to new bleached eucalypt kraft mills based on extensive study done by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO).

The director of the relevant CSIRO institute, Dr Roy Green, was asked whether there was any evidence in the Industry Commission report that had called into question any aspect of the government guidelines for new bleached eucalypt kraft mills. He replied, in a word, no. Dr Green explained that there was no scientific evidence presented to the Industry Commission which was not considered by the CSIRO in drafting its report on pulp mills or in advising the Government on the guidelines last year.

Bleached kraft pulp production is only one aspect of the industry, but it is the aspect that has raised the most concern amongst the public, due mainly to the loud media campaign against the construction of the Wesley Vale pulp mill. Although it has been pointed out before in the Senate, I will take this opportunity to again reiterate the fact that the Wesley Vale mill, as originally designed, would have complied with the Commonwealth guidelines. Dr Green's assessment, therefore, is important because it shows that the Industry Commission has not in any way called into doubt the correctness of the present Commonwealth guidelines for such mills.

As far as the view of the actual producers of pulp and paper is concerned, the report is seen as being very mixed in its quality and accuracy. The choice of words found in this report is often not what would have been considered scientifically correct. For example, `Should chlorine bleaching be banned?' is one heading in the report. Under this heading is the following:
The community is justifiably concerned about discharges of organochlorines from pulp mills. But the levels of such discharges are hard to measure and their long term effects are largely unknown.

So it is difficult to conclude that discharge of organochlorines should be banned altogether, particularly in view of the cost that this would impose and the environmental impacts of the alternatives. Producers and governments have responded to community concern, and consumer demand for unbleached and non-chlorine bleached products is strengthening.

Mr Cole, the Chairman of the Industry Commission, has stated that the Commission concluded that chlorine bleaching should not be banned. To someone not familiar with the industry and this particular aspect, the sentence quoted may not seem to justify the conclusions stated by Mr Cole, at least not with any real force. Community concern is justified only inasmuch as it may be fuelled by the media and environmental groups, not by any scientific evidence. Where there have been true adverse impacts observed from the discharge of effluent from chlorine based bleaching plants, there is also very clear and well documented reasons why those impacts occurred.

There is no cause to believe that similar impacts are automatically a feature of all chlorine bleached pulp mill discharges. Furthermore, there are very large amounts of evidence to show what the long term effects are. In short, there need be no such effects. In the vast majority of cases around the world, and in the case of any new mill built in Australia under new Commonwealth guidelines, there are no impacts expected or evident. In view of this, this evidence is worth considering, I believe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak on this paper and to make several brief points. The Senate will recall that, when the Industries Assistance Commission was disbanded recently and we passed legislation to create the new Industry Commission, I moved-and, with the support of the Government, was successful-to have placed on the new Industry Commission a person who has knowledge and experience in environmental matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that this particular report which is before us is one which predates the positioning of such a person on that Industry Commission. Thor Handlo, from the Griffith University in Queensland is, I understand, the person who has been appointed to the Industry Commission. One looks forward to the day when one might not see the rather narrow types of report of which this is one example.

In picking up the point which has been stressed by Senator Watson, I note that in the report the statement appears that the acute and chronic affects of organochlorine discharge are not fully understood or quantified. Indeed, the effects of the effluents of bleached eucalypt kraft pulp mills are largely unknown. It seems to me that one rushes in where angels fear to tread when one assumes, in the light of such a statement, that large amounts of organochlorines can be discharged with impunity into the marine environment, which itself is very little understood, without the long term consequences being very damaging.

More fundamentally, there are two flaws in this report. Firstly, it assumes that the market will remain as it is and that within that market there is insufficient call for the use of unbleached, or less bleached, or bleached by other methods, pulp for the manufacture of paper. This is to argue that one should maintain the very unlevel playing field that we have at the present time. One of the things that the environmental movement has been saying for a long time is that, as a first step-not necessarily as a complete solution-to addressing many of the environmental problems one needs to put in the full and proper costs of environmental damage.

When the market is adjusted and levelled by doing that, those costs are reflected in the marketplace in the price of the products. One then sees that purchaser decisions are affected and that the market itself shifts, which is, after all, the way the market is supposed to operate. We are seeing in this report the assumption that the market will continue to operate with the prices as they are at present and with choices being made based on those prices-prices reflecting insufficient call for paper which has been prepared in other ways and which, therefore, would not support the increase in the use of paper prepared in these other ways. We would say that a broader view which took into account the full environmental consequences and placed evaluations on them, which consequences would naturally be fed back into the price structure, would so change the market that indeed there would be a much increased demand for these alternative products.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion that the Senate take note of the report and I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY COMMISSION-INTERIM REPORT ON PAPER RECYCLING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I wish to use this opportunity of making a few comments on the report. It is noteworthy that the Industry Commission's findings generally complement the paper recycling industry's position and underwrite its belief that while recycling should be encouraged manufacturers should be left to use recycled fibres in the manner most suitable to them, their products and also their clients' needs. In essence, there are seven main findings which arise from this particular report before the Senate today. Firstly, the report acknowledges that there is already a high level of paper recycling in Australia. Australia is in fact the sixth highest recycler in the world with 36 per cent of our paper products containing some recycled fibre.

In the areas of packaging, printing and writing papers, we already have a high level of recycling. The report saw the greatest avenue for increased recycling being in the newspaper and magazine grades of paper. The reason Australia is ranked sixth and West Germany fourth in the world for paper recycling is that West Germany recycles newsprint for newspapers and Australia does not. The report identifies economic, environmental and technical constraints to increased recycling. The huge land mass that is Australia and the sparseness of its population means that the collection of newspapers and magazine grades for recycling is often uneconomic. But this does not rule out, however, other uses of recycled paper such as packaging and insulation.

The environmental and technical constraints refer specifically to the de-inking of newsprint and how to deal with the sludge the de-inking produces. Whilst we acknowledge the de-inking problem, great progress in this area has been made over recent years and will continue. I doubt that not far beyond the year 2000 this constraint will be with the industry. The one finding which accords most praise from industry was the recommendation that there should be no mandatory standards for recycling for manufacturers or converters. This was not seen by the industry as allowing them to do what they like, but rather as the only commonsense approach. While some people may consider the legislation of mandatory standards desirable, the fact is that if the Government were to legislate that all copying paper was to contain, say, 20 per cent recycled fibre, there is no known test for determining whether there is 5, 20 or 40 per cent of recycled fibre in the finished product. So we can confidently say that while there is recycled fibre in the paper product, there is nothing to say about the quality of the recycled fibre. It is just a guess. Thus, to legislate on a point which cannot be policed would appear to me to be quite ridiculous.

I think it is interesting to note that on the matter of sales tax exemption for 100 per cent recycled paper the Industry Commission's comment is that such a tax is distorting and is unlikely to encourage efficient paper recycling. From my previous point I would ask the Senate to take note that there is no way of checking that paper which claims to be produced from 100 per cent recycled fibre does, in fact, contain 100 per cent recycled fibre. My second point is that artificially encouraging the production of 100 per cent recycled printing and writing papers, a product with severe technical limitations, would increase demand and price of a high grade waste paper and do nothing to encourage the use of waste paper which is in excess-and I refer to newspapers and magazines.

I must say that it is heartening to see that the Industry Commission, after very extensive study, has made findings with which the industry concurs and I believe this augurs well for future developments in this area. Whether the cost involved in banning the use of chlorine should be borne by the community or not, I think this is a different interpretation of the situation than that quoted from the Industry Commission's report but it is a more correct interpretation. The task assigned the Industry Commission was a very broad one and hard for lay people to come to grips with in the time allowed. As a result the report is very mixed in its quality and accuracy and thus its contribution to the question of bleaching and the environment, I believe, is negligible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek also to make a few brief remarks on this interim report on paper recycling and to pick up several of the points which Senator Watson has just made but in a somewhat different context. I agree with the remarks which he made that there are no objective tests by which one can judge whether a product contains 5 per cent or 50 per cent or 100 per cent recycled paper. Moreover, another point which he made and which is absolutely valid, is that at each step in the recycling process the quality of the fibre tends to degrade. The fibre is shortened and the quality of the paper one can manufacture tends to deteriorate.

SPEECH.PARA: But again I think the way of tackling these problems is through the price mechanism. I note that we do not, in this country and, indeed, in most industrial countries, place any value on trees which are in situ in the forest. They appear to acquire value as we chop them down and we turn them into woodchips, sawn timber, furniture, or whatever. They are given no value when they reside in the forest and the way to tackle this situation, very largely, is not through mandating fixed amounts of recycled paper but to put appropriate values on trees in situ so that the cost of that is then reflected in the use of new fibre, some of which, of course-I agree with Senator Watson-has to be used in manufacturing high quality paper. A certain amount of the paper bulk must always be made up with new fibre, good quality fibre, but the cost of that would be reflected then in the value which is put on the trees in situ and the cost of infrastructure to harvest those trees which at the moment in Australia is not adequately covered by the royalties which are paid.

That in itself would encourage the very high levels of recycling which are desirable for a whole multitude of reasons. Firstly, it would cut down the amount of forest which is cut for the manufacture of paper and also substantially reduce the amounts of pollution which occur as a consequence of the use of that paper in various ways. Senator Watson has also pointed out that at the present time we do not recycle newsprint in Australia into newsprint. One of the difficulties with paper recycling arises from that very fact that, while a certain amount of newsprint is recycled and manufactured into other products, the total volume of newsprint as a fraction of the total amount of paper is so large that unless some mechanism is found to encourage a substantial amount of that recycling we are faced with a very considerable problem. Again, I would simply point to the price mechanism which, through market forces, should be able to substantially encourage the recycling of that. If it were more expensive to use virgin fibre in newsprint because a higher price was put on that virgin fibre, then there would be a strong incentive to maximally use recycled paper in the manufacture of newsprint. If we could get a reasonable percentage of recycled newsprint back into newsprint, many of the environmental problems associated with the use of paper and the recycling of paper would disappear.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 6.30 p.m., pursuant to the resolution agreed to this day, I call on first speeches. In calling Senator Spindler to make his first speech in this chamber, I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —One's vision of the future is bound to be an intensely personal one, built up over time and fashioned by a multitude of factors. My own is based on the `she' society-sane, humane, ecological. Such a society is achievable and we in this place have the task to bring it about. However, one cannot move into the future without taking stock of the past and analysing the present.

SPEECH.PARA: If I were asked to identify Australia's most significant achievement, I would not hesitate to nominate the essentially cohesive and harmonious multicultural society which is evolving daily with contributions from people who came here from 140 different countries. Without a doubt the essential basis for this multicultural society is the innate respect Australians have for individuals and for people who are different. This civilised tolerance stands in stark contrast to my childhood experiences in war-torn Europe. Somewhat parallel to the reaction of an adopted child, I can now confirm that while most of you were fortunate to have been born here, I chose well when I came here as a 17-year-old migrant in 1949.

I was born of German parents in a part of Poland which belonged to Russia when they were born there. During those two or three generations, ethnic differences often became a matter of life or death. The beginnings were peaceful enough. In an early example of skills migration, the then King of Poland contracted several hundred German spinners and weavers, including my forebears, to come to what later became the city of Lodz to establish a textile industry. It is a matter of great pleasure that a boyhood friend and member of one of that area's great textile families, Norbert Bernecker, is able to be here today.

I was seven when the German armies invaded Poland. Towards the end of the war I became part of the refugee trek zigzagging westward between the advancing Soviet and retreating German troops. Seventeen schoolboys, a small proportion of the original contingent, finally came to rest north of Berlin and, after finding my parents, I lived in Saxony, which became part of the Soviet zone of occupation.

During that time the jigsaw puzzle of hazy and fragmented childhood memories came together into a conscious realisation of the enormity of the Holocaust. It was this, more even than the personal experience of destruction and casualties in the refugee trek, which shaped then and informs now my determination to work for peace in its most basic sense-the development of an ethos between nations and between individuals which rejects violence as a means of conflict resolution.

Hence my long and continuing involvement in the Australian peace movement and my support for a defence posture which is genuinely defensive. Australia needs weapons and equipment to defend its shoreline, rather than long-range aircraft and naval vessels on the assumption that we will rush into every conflict far from our shores. In the Middle East it is clear that Saddam Hussein must be stopped. However, the correct level of response for Australia is support for the United Nations economic boycott and a contribution of personnel to a peacekeeping force if requested by the United Nations. Such a request should go before both Houses of Parliament, where in this instance it should receive unanimous support.

Australia must turn away from the juvenile quest to compete in the sabre-rattling stakes, withdrawing badly needed funds which should be used for health, education and community development. Equally reprehensible is the continuing build-up of our armaments industry which is making us the weapons dealer of the Pacific. We need to build economic, cultural and social ties with the other nations in the Pacific and we need to integrate our armed forces with the economic and social development of the nation by giving them a role in natural disaster work and in the building of bridges, roads, railways and other infrastructure.

This philosophy has found expression in the Democrats' Alternative Budget Proposals published last week, in a proposed reduction of $798m in armaments expenditure and an increase of $430m in overseas aid, a continuing boost for our export trade, and an additional $477m for education, employment and training.

My early days in Europe are also responsible for my suspicion of chauvinistic prejudice masquerading as patriotism and for my intense opposition to all forms of totalitarian compulsion. No sooner had the simplistic propaganda of Nazism been exposed before our very eyes in those days as a corrupt sham hiding horrendous crimes, when the Iron Curtain descended and a new indoctrination attempt got under way-but not before we had been given a glimpse of the liberating notion of democracy when we attended school during the brief American occupation.

The first few years in Australia, when I came here at 17, revealed the significant extent to which a democratic, pluralist society mirrors the aspirations, both noble and crass, of its citizens. For the first time in years I could breathe freely and do what most migrants do-work to get an economic foothold in this new country where such aspirations made sense.

I had the good fortune to meet and marry a woman of exceptional quality. It was her selfless support and her commitment to our splendid children, Karen, Christopher, Linden and Rebecca, which enabled me to build a business and to pursue concurrently studies in law, business administration and political science, and later to become involved in politics. It is a matter of profound regret to me that these pressures led to a separation and that Julia is not here today.

My entry into politics was through the Australia Party where I took over from Dr David Smith as Victorian Convener, and my first contact with Don Chipp was in 1972 when I called on him with a friend suggesting he should take a leading role in the Party. This finally occurred in 1977 when the Australian Democrats were formed to challenge the two-party system. I welcome the opportunity to pay tribute to both Don Chipp and Janine Haines, who, as Party leaders, articulated so well the message of social and political reform in the face of the converging policies of the old parties.

I became Senior Adviser to Don Chipp in 1981 and later moved into the same position with Senator Janine Haines. My work included policy development and liaison between the Senate team and the Party organisation, and here a tribute is due to the scores of committed members who work day in and day out to achieve a better future for Australia. Janet Powell, Sam Hudson and Heather Southcott are just a few whose work in those days ensured the survival and growth of the Party and still continues to do so today.

But before that, there was a year at the Alice Springs Community College and a youth needs survey for the Northern Territory Government. Both involved work with Aboriginal communities, and this experience has given me an abiding respect and affection for Aboriginal people. More than that, it has generated a strong and continuing interest in their quest for justice and a place in our community which takes account of their cultural and spiritual heritage which can and should enrich our own.

United Nations consultancies in Tonga and Western Samoa reinforced my strongly held view that we must adopt a global approach to the challenges facing Australia today and that we must share resources and knowledge with Third World countries as a moral obligation which ultimately equates with enlightened self-interest.

Perhaps the most important formative experience was the five years spent as Administrator of ACCESS, the Outer Eastern Regional Council of Social Development. It was a funded pilot region under the Australian Assistance Plan and the task to establish a decision-making process which the community could use to allocate funds to community projects, was a practical and exhilarating experience in effective participatory democracy. It reinforced similar experiences in the Australia Party and in the Australian Democrats where it is one of the major factors in ensuring the Party's survival and growth.

Writing some 15 years ago, Carole Pateman demonstrated in her book Participation and Democratic Theory that effective participation is an educative process, leading not only to greater personal autonomy but also to increased concern for the common good.

A nominally democratic system will not necessarily realise its potential as Schumpeter showed when he characterised a `democracy' as a model where two elites compete for the support of an apathetic mass.
First Speeches

Australians have been suffering from the dead hand of such a two-party system for decades. It is bad enough when members on either side are forced into the ritual of meaningless confrontation and the systematic denial of their intellectual and moral integrity. It is little short of a disaster for the country when both parties adopt policy positions which coincide in their disregard for social and economic justice and a sustainable future for all Australians. In years to come, the contribution the Democrats are making in changing this stultifying system into an open participatory process will be seen at least as important as the growing list of successful amendments and the increasing number of reform groups which now acknowledge the Democrats as their parliamentary representatives.

The Democrats have now been recognised as the Party offering a vision for an alternative future. It is a vision for a sustainable society based on social equity, environmental sustainability, economic sovereignty, democratic control and international responsibility. To pursue such a vision people must have hope-hope that is grounded in the belief that it is possible to realise that vision or at least to move towards it. In 1986 I had a hand in drafting a notice of motion which listed a range of urgent social justice measures. When Senator Janet Powell moved it, that motion earned us the tag `the fairies at the bottom of the garden'-something of a badge of honour since the light on the top of the hill had grown very dim indeed.

In 1990-91 the Democrats' alternative Budget proposals are the first step in a continuing process not only to cost policy priorities, but also to show where the money is coming from. The proposals indicate a direction rather than a complete prescription and do not include all the additional measures the Democrats would fund, nor all the additional revenue options we would like to see pursued. However, it is urgent to make a start and while many of the alternative Budget proposals are starting points only, further action will follow in subsequent Budget years. In the macro-economic context they offer an alternative strategy to the high interest regime of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) which has hit families trying to buy a home and squeezed small business to within an inch of its life.

However, in turning to fiscal measures the Democrats reject the only strategy Mr Keating and Dr Hewson can conceive, and one that has been continued in this Budget-further cuts to badly needed health, education and welfare services. Instead we have shown that a surplus can be achieved not by cutting services but by making tax avoiders pay their fair share of tax just as pay as you earn taxpayers do. We have proposed a range of measures which will make our tax system more effective and more progressive, advance social objectives and raise more revenue.

Expenditure on community services is increased by $4 billion, while revenue is increased by $7.1 billion, yielding a potential additional surplus of $3.1 billion and opening the way for an accelerated reduction in interest rates and a lower exchange rate for our dollar to boost exports and reduce imports. We have included Landcare, forestry, energy conservation, habitat restoration and other conservation programs essential for a genuinely sustainable future. But this is not going to be achieved unless we enable all Australians to meet their basic needs and to participate fully in the social and political life of the nation. Accordingly, we have proposed to increase and extend young homeless and disability allowances, to provide concessional benefits for all pensioners with an income below $15,000 and to double the funding for grant-in-aid workers for ethnic communities-all of them neglected in the Treasurer's Budget.

While the Democrats advocate these and other urgent remedial measures to lift people out of poverty, we do not ask for institutionalised charity. Australian citizens are entitled to a level playing field, this time not just for large corporations, but for ordinary Australians. Hence there are increased resources and powers for the Foreign Investment Review Board, the Trade Practices Commission, the Prices Surveillance Authority and the Bureau of Consumer Affairs.

There is additional funding to ensure local content programming at the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and to protect the Special Broadcasting Service from commercialisation. There is increased funding for legal aid and more judges to make access to the law a reality. There is also a strong boost for public transport and a truly national railway system to be financed by higher excise on petrol and diesel fuel and a road freight levy.

I was pleased by two headlines which identify correctly the thrust of the Democrats' Budget proposals: in the Melbourne Age `Democrats propose tax-avoidance crackdown in alternative Budget', and in the Ballarat Courier `Democrats aim to tax rich to help poor'. In essence, it is a choice between allowing tax rorts to continue, maintaining low prices for health damaging products and allowing so-called entrepreneurs to rip off Australian families, or turning our country around with better research, better transport, an efficient and well supervised financial system, better education and a fair deal for homeless and unemployed people, pensioners and children in poverty. I know the choice which should be made, and look forward to working with you towards achieving these goals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Bourne, I remind honourable senators that this is her first speech in this chamber. Therefore I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first Australian Democrats were elected to Federal Parliament in 1977. Don Chipp and Colin Mason took their places in the Senate in July 1978. It is hard to believe that was 12 years ago-12 years of magnificent highs, terrible lows, and a great deal of very hard work. I know what it has been like for the Democrats in parliament over those 12 years because I have been working with the Democrats' parliamentary party since its inception all those years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: With our very first try at an election, we achieved the election of two senators-both of them were men. That figure rose to five senators-one woman and four men; then to seven senators-three women and four men; and now eight senators-four women and four men. If we keep growing at this rate-and I see no reason to suppose that we will not-by the year 2002 the Democrats will have 16 senators, all of them women. It would probably be prudent to mention here that I have done similar calculations on the numbers of women elected by the other parties represented in this Parliament, and have discovered that although it will take us a lot longer to take over in those parties, by the turn of the next century-not the coming century but the next-the entire Senate will be composed of women.

Back to the Democrats. When we first arrived we were treated with fairness, enthusiasm and good will by the officers of the Senate, the library staff and all the others who work so hard to make sure this Parliament runs smoothly. We were treated rather warily and I must say in some cases with a bit of disdain by many of the other parliamentarians and their personal staff. If one was a Democrat in the building in those days one felt a bit like an Edwardian curiosity-put in an alien place and left to fend for oneself. I hasten to say that not all parliamentarians and their staff treated us that way. Some-many of them are still here today-were kind enough to be helpful and friendly. Many others ignored us and just hoped we would go away; we did not. Over the years, and through successive elections, we have consistently increased our representation in the chamber and we are now an accepted part of the Parliament. Some Democrats have been here so long that we are almost part of the furniture.

I worked in the old Parliament House for 10 years and I was very familiar with its faults. The building was small. It was very cramped and very inconvenient. Most of us spent our 15-hour working days sharing an office about the size of the average kitchen. But even though many of the old facilities did not work and despite it being a cold and draughty place with plumbing of Third World standards, I loved working there. I felt at home. I was as inconvenienced as anyone and I realised that the building had reached the point where it was becoming an embarrassment to Australia, but I did not want to leave. Its very inconvenience engendered a spirit of camaraderie with every person who worked there. The building was cosy; it was frenetic and infuriating, but it was cosy. For 10 years I watched the old Parliament House gradually deteriorating around us and I moved with reluctance.

This new building has a great deal more room, more public space, more marquetry, more artwork, more facilities-in fact, more of everything, which is a good thing. But this very abundance of space makes it less friendly. Looking back, I believe that those crowded, cramped and inadequate conditions of the old House had an advantage for our system of government. When we worked so closely together, we simply had to make the effort to get on with everyone. We faced people not just across the floors of the chambers but also in the corridors and bathrooms. We all had to be civil to survive in that rabbit warren. In fact, we made life much easier for ourselves if we were not just civil but also made the effort to be friendly as well-and it was not that difficult.

The ghost of that camaraderie still inhabits this building, and its influence is beginning to be felt. Obviously, it is in the interests of all Australians that we strive to make this as special and as cooperative a place as many of us remember that old building down the hill to have been. I should add that the new building is growing on me. Every time I come here, I feel a little more at home.

It is now accepted by the Australian public that the Australian Democrats represent a valid point of view, different from those of the other parties, and that we should remain a part of the political scene in this country-not just remain, but grow. Like all honourable senators here, I stood for election because I have strong views on the way Australia should be run and the way we should attempt to have an effect on the rest of the world. Sometimes we cannot just sit still and let things happen around us when we know those things to be unjust or threatening to the well-being of people we love.

I know that around me in this chamber are many people who feel the same way, even if they disagree with my priorities. The vast majority of us are here because we genuinely want to make Australia a better place in which to live-and we all believe we know the best way to do that. I believe that way is to protect as much of the natural environment as we can, to protect the basic human rights of not only every Australian but also, if possible, every human being, and to move towards the achievement of a sustainable economy for Australia and a sustainable environment for the world.

What is left of our natural environment all over the planet is a vital resource, a potential source of habitat, of medicines, of sanity and, above all, an essential element in the delicate web of interconnected ecological systems which the human race is currently attempting so assiduously to destroy. The earth is an intricate and precariously balanced network, and we must stop playing with it. Every fragment of the natural environment which is left on this planet should be preserved.

Mr Deputy President, as you know, each Democrat senator is given the responsibility of shadowing several portfolios. Mine are foreign affairs, energy and resources, arts and heritage, and housing. On the matter of energy, my basic priority, and that of the Democrats, is to increase Australia's use of and contribution to renewable energy sources. We are all only too aware that our major energy resources are finite and that we have no guarantee of their automatic availability even in the short term-and particularly at the moment. In the past, Australia has led the world in this field and we continue to produce extraordinarily talented and dedicated scientists and inventors. Their discoveries and inventions must be nurtured and given high priority in this country.

On heritage, we applaud the moves over recent years to preserve Australia's natural and built heritage. I am particularly pleased to see the increase in awareness and appreciation of that heritage. It is a remarkable development and one which I have been delighted to observe just in my short lifetime. We can all only benefit from it.

When we discuss arts, we have to ask ourselves: do we want to be a civilised nation or not? If we do, then we must move to preserve and foster our culture and an awareness of all those diverse areas we group under the heading of arts.

Housing is a very difficult and heart-rending subject for many people, especially in my home State of New South Wales. As parliamentarians whose responsibility is the welfare of all Australians, we should be striving for a basic change in that area. If we are ever to bring housing prices to a reasonable level, this change should include stronger restrictions on foreign ownership of Australian property.

We all have our favourite quotations, and I believe that they reveal a lot about us. I would like to use one now which is indicative of my attitude to foreign affairs. It comes from John Donne's Devotions XVII, which was written around 1620, hence the rather feudal tone. I quote:

No man is an iland, intire of itselfe; every man is a peece of the continent, a part of the maine; if a clod bee washed away by the sea, Europe is the lesse, as well as if a promontorie were, as well as if a mannor of thy friends, or of thine owne were; any mans death diminishes me, because I am involved in mankinde; and therefore never send to know for whom the bell tolls; it tolls for thee.

We live in revolutionary times. Never before have we been so aware so fast of what is happening to our fellow humans all over the world. What is happening is to a great extent exciting, liberating and literally a cause for dancing in the streets. But we cannot forget that we also live in a world where starvation and torture are still the norm in many places. We have every right to share the jubilation of those in eastern Europe whose lives and expectations are changing so dramatically; to share the optimism and hope of the majority of South Africans that apartheid is at last coming to an end. But we must never forget that we also have an obligation to do everything in our power to try to alleviate the suffering of those who are still living in poverty, slowly and inevitably starving to death, of those living in terror of brutal regimes and of those whose lives are constantly threatened and disrupted by war.

Compared with most of the world, Australia really is a very lucky country. We live in a democracy where we all get a say in the composition of our Parliament, and where we need not worry that the local military junta will roll up to our door at any hour of the day or night and abduct one of our family by force, never to be seen or heard of again. We never have to contend with nightmares about the treatment of our children by a vicious, vindictive military power.

We are a relatively rich country, but that does not mean that we do not have to contend with the problem of Australians living in poverty. In particular, the conditions under which thousands of our children exist are unacceptable to a civilised society in the twentieth century. I was shocked to read that four years ago Sydney was the fourth most expensive city in the world in which to live; it is now the eighth most expensive. It is no wonder that so many Sydneysiders are living in abject or hidden poverty. Too many Australians are malnourished, but in world terms we are still fortunate. We do produce enough food for all of us, so no Australian need face the lingering torture of death by starvation.

Very occasionally, some blatant human rights abuse will take place in Australia and we will all be up in arms, inquiries will be held and the subsequent public outrage will eventually lead to some preventative action. The Australian belief in a fair go is never to be underestimated. But in far too many countries around the world human rights abuses occur with monotonous regularity. Even so, the world is going through a momentous period. I consider myself fortunate to have been elected at this time.

I do not want to turn this first speech into an academy award speech, but I do feel a real need to put on record my special gratitude to my family and those friends from all political parties who supported me in the course of my preselection and election. They put up with a lot of long phone calls, fed me, did my shopping and washing and looked after me when I was ill. Without their love and support, I would not be here.

I especially thank all those Democrats who worked so hard to make sure that I was elected. No-one knows better than we do in this chamber how much hard work is involved in an election campaign and how much we require of our members and supporters. I can never thank them all enough for their hard work and their goodwill.

One in every eight people in New South Wales voted for the Democrats. They put their trust in me to represent them and do the best I possibly can to make Australia a better place in which to live. It is a demanding prospect. In Jonathan Swift's book Gulliver's Travels, Gulliver describes the Lilliputians' criteria for public office in these terms:

Since government is necessary to mankind, they believe . . . that providence never intended to make management of public affairs a mystery, to be comprehended only by a few persons of sublime genius, of which there seldom are three born in an age: but they suppose truth, justice, temperance, and the like, to be in every man's power; the practice of which virtues, assisted by experience and a good intention, would qualify any man for service of his country.

I do not imagine myself to be one of those three geniuses born in our age. But I do have a healthy respect for and knowledge of our parliamentary system and, in particular, of the way the Senate works. I do have the very best of intentions. I imagine that if Swift had been writing in this century those qualities would also have qualified women for the service of their country. I hope that they, and my genuine desire to improve the lot of my fellow humankind, will be enough to allow me to acquit myself well in this place. I look forward to the challenge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Kernot, I remind honourable senators that this will be her first speech in this chamber. Therefore, I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I have looked forward to this moment with great anticipation, but now I find myself with mixed emotions. The honour of being elected by the people of Queensland to represent them in this chamber is immense and goes without question. To have the opportunity to serve beside such talented Democrat colleagues is also a great privilege. The increased Democrat presence in this chamber I see as a great benefit to Australia and to future generations of Australians. But the obvious excitement I feel at being on my feet in this chamber for the first time is tempered by a strong sense of responsibility and some concern as I consider the tremendous responsibilities entrusted to us by the people of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: The German sociologist Max Weber has said, `True politicians should be characterised by (1) passion, (2) a feeling of responsibility and (3) a sense of proportion'. How many of us here tonight have as our motivating passion or cause the simple desire to leave the world a better place than we find it? If my child and grandchildren in later years are in a better world than that in which we find ourselves today, and I have done my utmost to secure their future during my time in this chamber, then I will have realised my political passion.

Mr Deputy President, I am only the fifth woman since Federation elected to the Senate to represent Queensland. I come to this position tonight as the result of a chain of events which began when I was a teenager. Current affairs debates with my father were a regular occurrence in our family, but politics was first mentioned to me by my local Liberal member of State parliament, Mr Milton Morris, after I had made a speech at an official function at my high school.

My colleague Senator Bell, in his first speech, told the chamber of his success in handwriting competitions. I want to place on record the fact that the Ringarooma Kid is now joined on the Democrat benches by a Lions Club Youth of the Year-1965 vintage. I mention this because that experience, in the second half of my teens, clarified for me an understanding of my desire to contribute to society and to have a say where decisions which affected me were made. The particular shape of that contribution came in 1979 when I joined the Australian Democrats. I had found the Party for me and, I might say, for over a million voting Australians at the last election.

Over the 10 years that I have stood as a Democrat candidate many people have expressed a disbelief that I would choose to move from a profession which enjoys some respect to become a politician. It concerns me greatly that Australians consider most politicians to be self-serving, dishonest and isolated from the real world. I know that is not the case. Nevertheless, recent events in Queensland resulting in charges being laid against former National Party Ministers, and some of the evidence presented to the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales, must cause us all to reflect on the public perception of our role.

An endearing quality of Australians is the way in which they call a spade, a spade; many Australians tell me they find it hard to accept that their local member of parliament tells them privately that he supports their cause, but then has to vote against it because of party discipline.

Australians are a natural part of a worldwide movement demanding participatory democracy and greater accountability and they will in the next 50 years, I believe, demand an end to rigid party line politics. Issues and political decisions are no longer black or white-or even grey. There is an increasing need for dialogue and for a multi-partisan approach. The old rhetoric and labels of the past are unconvincing. The short term focus of successive governments has put our country in what many Australians regard as a perilous position.

We as a House of review will, I hope, place greater emphasis on the long term effects of our decisions. Such decisions made over the next 4,000 days by governments around the world, including our own, will either guarantee our children a safe and sustainable future or will ruin forever this fragile planet we have so long abused. It is rather sobering to reflect that we have only 4,000 days to the next century-4,000 days to get our house in better order.

In the time remaining I want to touch on a number of subjects important to me, to my portfolio responsibilities and to the people of Queensland. I want to begin with my passionate concern for the increasing foreign ownership of Australia's best and most beautiful land.

For 40,000 years or more our economy, in the hands of the original Australians, was totally sustainable. But in the blink of an eye-in the last 200 years since Europeans landed, and more especially in the last decade-control of Australia's economy has been passing out of the hands of Australians and into the clutches of foreign banks and financiers. In the name of short term economic solutions we are ceding control of this country's assets to overseas privateers and, at the same time, we are paying those foreigners some millions of dollars per hour for the privilege of their control!

It does not stop there. It really concerns me that both the Government and the Opposition would have us believe it is in our children's best interests to sell freehold title to the best parts of Australia to foreign speculators. But let us not blame only those foreign speculators who can spot a brilliant investment. Let us not lose sight of the number of Australian developers who get local government approval to impose on unsuspecting communities a hideous form of urban development ranging from a multifunction polis to a `mini city', and then sell off those plans overseas.

This, I believe, is where Australia is really being betrayed. Just think of an Australia 20 or 30 years from now where every headland boasts a high-rise development; where places we used to go fishing with our mum and dad are denied to our grandchildren because a tourist resort has been built for the sole use of foreign holiday makers. Think of an Australia without the unspoiled beauty of clean beaches, virgin rainforest, clear, clean tropical waters and old growth forests.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have tried to deflect genuine public concern by attempting to confuse foreign ownership with foreign investment. They would have us believe that the majority of Australians-those who oppose selling this country out from under us-are racist and anti-foreign investment when nothing could be further from the truth.

Of course we need foreign investment. We are, and continue to be, a developing country. But we do not need foreign investment at the expense of our birthright. If our country is so attractive to overseas investors-if we represent a desirable investment target in international terms-well and good. But if foreign investors want Australia, then let them lease it. With majority Australian equity and the benefit of leasehold we can still enjoy title to what is ours, while the foreign investors and their Australian partners are free to enjoy the commercial success or otherwise of their venture.

The other factor in this equation is the role played by the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB). Currently, part time directors virtually rubber-stamp foreign investment proposals, which are very rarely blocked. Although there is a power of forfeiture of an asset, there is no investigation into acquisitions by foreign buyers to ensure compliance with the law. I do not think that is good enough. The 1986 change in FIRB criteria for approval of acquisitions from `economic benefit' to `not contrary to the national interest' is an attempt to defraud the people of Australia. `Not contrary to the national interest' to the Treasurer simply means anything which will attract currency to Australia in the short term.

Mr Deputy President, the long term effects of such a policy are already being seen in the vertical integration of both the tourist and beef cattle industries in Queensland. It is not in the national interest for around 85 per cent of profits from these industries to flow from Australia.

Mr Deputy President, much of the business of this chamber over the last seven years in particular has focused attention on privatisation, on deregulation and on all the benefits that allegedly flow from these things. The deregulation of our airline system is imminent. As a matter of fact, I have to speak on the relevant Bill first thing in the morning. To blindly follow the United States example is, I believe, a grave mistake. Already, fares which initially came down in the United States are spiralling upwards again. The megacarriers, through a process of natural attrition, have control of the industry again and what may have initially been perceived as benefits to consumers are fast being eroded. In fact, the United States is now looking at some form of re-regulation. Our governments do not seem to wish to learn from the mistakes of others. Once they have set a course, no deviations are allowed, no matter how compelling the evidence.

The safety standards of Australia's major airlines are internationally renowned. Australian pilots are second to none in terms of both training and professionalism. That our safety standards are the world's best is a tribute to the dedication of pilots, engineers, maintenance and safety staff and cabin crew.

Although I am not convinced that de- regulation will result over time in major benefits to the consumer, my major concern with deregulation of the domestic airlines is the potential erosion of safety standards. The United States carrier Eastern Airlines is facing 60 safety related criminal charges at present, including faking maintenance records. This, I believe, is what competition at its very worst can bring. The unfortunate part is that it attracts unsuspecting passengers who can pay with their lives. It is imperative that the Government, the Civil Aviation Authority and the airline industry cooperate to the fullest to ensure that no similar erosion of standards occurs here.

The head of the Civil Aviation Authority, Mr Dick Smith, has been promoting a concept of affordable safety. We should note that this concept is nothing new; affordable safety is what has always been practised throughout the industry, from the design of a wing spar at Boeing's Seattle plant to passenger loads on small Australian commuter aircraft. Every day the level of affordable safety is being revised by competent professionals who have dedicated their lives to aviation.

Mr Smith has shown himself to be an extremely competent businessman with an ability to lead by example. His adventures, his retailing and his publishing efforts have attracted a great deal of attention and he is now a well-known and admired Australian. But Mr Smith is a new arrival on the professional aviation scene and his attempts at redefinition of what is affordable in terms of safety are not being done by a worldwide consensus of aviation professionals. This is a matter which I intend to monitor closely.

I turn now to a proposal which encompasses a number of issues of concern to the people of Queensland especially-the proposed Cape York spaceport. What a grand dream it is: Australia reaping hundreds of millions of dollars annually through provision of facilities, utilising technology from the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. It all sounds easy when one says it quickly, so it is not surprising that the whole issue has snowballed until we find an attitude not of `if' the project will proceed, but `when'. As far as I and other Democrats are concerned, the spaceport is not a fait accompli.

The people of Australia need some specific answers to some very pertinent questions: first, what is the real purpose of the base? Will it be used for military purposes? Any possibility, no matter how remote, that such a facility may be used for military purposes is totally unacceptable. Second, will the establishment of such a project really be of long term benefit to the nation as a whole? Or, on the other hand, will the tremendous costs environmentally, socially and financially outweigh any possible benefits? Is there any evidence that Essington Developments, as promoter of the spaceport, is living in a commercial dream world? The Comalco-led Australian space group dropped its plans for a spaceport on Cape York last year after it concluded that the project was `tenuous' and `unacceptable by general private commercial standards'. And Comalco is not alone. In a recent edition of the respected science magazine Search, Dr Sam Paltridge of the Centre for International Research on Communication and Information Technologies said that the Essington proposal was surrounded by `several myths'. He observed that most existing domestic satellite systems were characterised by `poor financial performance'-and we need look no further than Aussat for confirmation of that-and that these domestic satellite systems were already victims of substantial overcapacity. Dr Paltridge also stated that the onset of competitive fibre optic technology would greatly increase the capacity of telecommunication networks in direct competition with satellites.

It does not stop there. The world leader in commercial satellite launches, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, NASA, concludes that `the longer term demand for commercial launches of satellites was weak at best'. So there we have it. The international industry leaders say no and Essington says yes.

What of Essington itself? Honourable senators are no doubt aware that Essington's financial dealings were the subject of much interest in the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union as recently as 1985. It has been predicted that Essington will maintain a stake of only 10 per cent to 20 per cent of the spaceport venture, with most of the remaining equity falling into Japanese and American hands. In other words, we are being asked to sacrifice an area of international, ecological and environmental significance to allow a company with a dubious financial and management track record to make a tentative venture into one of the most sophisticated industries in the world, with little or no hope of commercial success, according to the international experts, for a measly 10 per cent of the deal.

The spaceport will decimate a 200,000 hectare site and we will lose forever at least 10 per cent of the portion of north-east Cape York registered as national estate. Mr Deputy President and honourable senators, surely, as trustees of this country for future generations, we have an obligation to do more than pay lip service to protection of this area of unquestionable international significance.

Before leaving this issue, I wish to raise the question of dislocation of the local Aboriginal inhabitants. Ninety years ago the Wathooti and Cuckoo Yu tribes were driven at gunpoint from their homes at Cape Grenville. Do we simply continue to perpetuate this unforgivable behaviour by once again denying the traditional occupants title to their homeland in the name of progress and to benefit a foreign backed conglomerate?

Mr Deputy President, because to me people are ultimately much more important than portfolios, I too wish to place on record my thanks to all of those who worked so hard to secure my election, which was never a certainty: my parents, for teaching their three daughters in the 1950s that females could achieve success equal to males; my husband, Gavin, for his generosity of spirit and unflagging support; our daughter, Sian, who is only seven years old, for her loving acceptance of a role which means that we spend more time apart than we would like to as a family; and the West End Uniting Church congregation for their moral support and confidence in me despite their own political persuasions.

I want to single out two people who have made extremely valuable contributions to my success and who are unable to be here tonight. The first is Stephen Tyler, a former State Secretary of the Democrats in Queensland, who died last December at the age of 35. Stephen had such a passion for reading Daily Hansard that it was noted at his funeral. I think we would have to argue that this is an unusual passion, and so I thought it a fitting tribute to him that his name be recorded within these very pages. The second person, John, is, I hope, listening to this broadcast in a hospice in Brisbane. I thank him especially for his spirited debates. It does not matter, John, that I was not won over.

Mr Deputy President, I am absolutely delighted to have made it to this place at last. I thank Mr President in his absence; I thank honourable senators from across the political groupings in this chamber, and I thank the staff of the Department of the Senate for their warm welcome and assistance to No. 76 on the pecking order. To achieve and maintain the passion, the feeling of responsibility and the sense of proportion of Weber's true politician is my challenge in this place.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL DROUGHT POLICY REVIEW TASK FORCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

There are three volumes to this final report from the National Drought Policy Review Task Force, which I would like to just make a few comments about. I believe that information on drought is very important to rural Australia. Queensland is a very big State; some parts have good weather and other parts are very susceptible to drought, and I believe it is very important that we look at the contents of one or two of the report volumes that are here before us today. The Task Force has certainly put down quite a lot of information about droughts and tells us in chapter 22 what its policy objectives are:

Our terms of reference require the Task Force to identify policy options to encourage primary producers and other segments of rural Australia to adopt self-reliant approaches to the management of drought.
Over 5 million people live in rural and provincial areas. Though most are not primary producers, the agricultural sector is a vital part of the rural economy.

This is indeed true. There is in the report a part which says that the task force recommends against the reinstatement of drought within the natural disaster relief arrangements. That really is a very big worry, I believe, to many of our people who over the years have been assailed by drought-and when one lives in the country one really knows all about drought. I lived in the city until I got married and went to live at Kingaroy. In the city one just turns a tap on to get water and, if it rains, we think it is a jolly nuisance. In the country we do not get the rain and we do not have the water to turn the tap on for, and it is a very big problem.

Mr Deputy President, you lived at Gallangowan in the Barambah electorate for quite some time, I believe, while you were teaching there, and you would know from those years just what I am talking about. I believe that this is something that we as senators really have to give consideration to. I do not believe that we want to go along with the Task Force recommendation against the reinstatement of drought within the natural disaster relief arrangements. I believe drought is something that demands help from governments, but when one reads this report one almost feels that drought is going to disappear from the vocabulary of natural disaster. The Government says, and the Task Force more or less indicates, that people should manage their farms better-`Do not worry about the drought but manage your tasks better'.

Let us think back to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd and the problem that that company had: the Government was willing to give it money to help it to manage its business better. And I believe it is very important indeed that the Government continue to help people in rural Australia who are the primary producers and who are the export earners. We need to be sure that we are able to continue to give them the help that they will need at the time of drought.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advance to the Minister for Finance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise an issue tonight which relates to two of the papers that were tabled today, namely, papers relating to the Advance to the Minister for Finance. From those papers it seems clear to me that the Government, through the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, has abused the parliamentary provisions covering the disclosure of budgetary expenditure. In my view, the Advance to the Minister for Finance has been illegally used to make special payments to favoured States at the expense of others. These payments are over and above those publicly revealed at the recent Premiers Conference. They total no less than $72m, and they were made to three Labor States.

SPEECH.PARA: Drought Policy Task Force

I will just explain the reason for my concern. The Advance to the Minister for Finance is, in effect, the Government of the day's reserve funds for use to meet purposes that were unforeseen at the time of Budget Appropriations and for which there is an urgent requirement for expenditure. The legal provisions relating to this are that the money is available for expenditure if the Minister for Finance is satisfied that the expenditure is urgently required and `was unforeseen until after the last day on which it was practicable to include appropriation for that expenditure in the Bill for the particular Act before the introduction of that Bill into the House of Representatives'. Departments are able to apply to the Minister for Finance for funds which are urgent and which are unforeseen at the time of the Budget Appropriations and the Minister for Finance can then authorise that one-time payment or he or she can reject it.

In some instances agreement will be made for departments to later reimburse the amount to the Minister for Finance. There is no limit to the number or amount of advances apart, of course, from the overall budgetary constraints. There is also no legal requirement, other than that which I have just read out and, in fact, that does make it a legal requirement for the Minister for Finance to demonstrate the appropriateness of the words `urgent' and `unforeseen'.

Advances to the Minister for Finance do not appear in the Appropriation Bills, nor are they passed by the Parliament in the way that other money Bills are. Advances to the Minister theoretically are scrutinised through members and senators carefully examining the advances when they are tabled in Parliament, through the Senate Estimates committee process and through the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. However, because of their relative obscurity, such scrutiny rarely occurs. Labor has developed into an art form the use of the advances to the Minister for Finance by disguising payments for purposes it wishes to shield from open and public knowledge and scrutiny. More and more, Labor has made its sensitive political payments through the advances to the Minister, instead of through special or other appropriation Bills.

In June of this year the Advance to the Minister for Finance showed a number of special payments to three Labor States. These were, firstly, a payment of $40m to Tasmania for a capital grant for restructuring the public service; secondly, a $20m payment to Western Australia for a capital grant for transport improvement; and, thirdly, a $12m payment to South Australia for a capital grant for water treatment projects. All three of those payments were highly political and controversial.

In the case of the Tasmanian $40m, the special payment was controversial because it was announced subsequent to the Premiers Conference even though the payment, as disclosed from the papers tabled in the Senate today, had been approved by the Minister for Finance before the Premiers Conference. That payment should have been fully disclosed at the Premiers Conference to ensure a fair understanding and fair treatment by all parties participating at the Premiers Conference.

In the case of the Western Australian payment of $20m for a capital grant for transport improvement, that payment was made on 29 June, the final day of the Premiers Conference. The payment was never publicly announced until its appearance in the documents tabled in the Senate today. The timing of the approval- that is, the final day of the Premiers Conference-would indicate quite clearly that a special deal was made at the Premiers Conference after Premier Lawrence had met with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in Canberra.

The third payment to which I referred, the $12m to South Australia for a capital grant for water treatment projects, was another deal that was not announced publicly until today. However, this payment follows three consecutive payments for water treatment projects made in 1986-87 and onwards from the Advance to the Minister for Finance. Those payments now total more than $100m. Quite clearly, with four annual payments now, there is no way in the world that anyone could suggest that that payment was either unforeseen or urgent. Again, this last payment was approved after the Prime Minister and the Treasurer had met with Premier Bannon on 29 June, the final day of the Premiers Conference. I wonder why that Premiers Conference was extended against everyone's expectations for that second day. Was it, as it increasingly appears likely, simply to enable these secret political deals to be done with the Labor States? I suggest that it is no coincidence whatsoever that Premier Bannon was also the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party.

The consequences of these secret payments through the Advance to the Minister for Finance are very important because they impinge on all the States of the Commonwealth. These payments undermine the fairness of the existing Commonwealth/State funding arrangements, particularly with regard to the distribution of the pool of funds available to all States. That flies totally in the face of the Prime Minister's recent call for a mutually fairer system of Commonwealth/State relations.

These advances tabled today show that this fairness is not in evidence. It does not occur. Labor is giving special payments to favoured States controlled by Labor governments. It is no coincidence that these payments also take the form of capital grants, rather than recurrent grants. The significance of that is that it means that the Commonwealth Grants Commission will not take the payments into account in its formulation of recommendations on the appropriate distribution of payments to the States.

The continuing payments, those to South Australia in particular, represent quite a clear abuse of the whole purpose of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. The payments were purely political and cannot, as I said earlier, in any sense be seen as unforeseen. One of the intentions was quite clearly to hide the payments from the other States at the time of the Premiers Conference and, therefore, to the very grave financial disadvantage of those other States. The other intention was, of course, to limit parliamentary scrutiny of a quite massive secret deal, amounting, as I said, to $72m, done between the Labor Party cronies.

The role of this important budgetary tool, the Advance to the Minister for Finance, is being undermined in this way by unscrupulous, devious and, I believe, illegal use of the Advance for political purposes. It is no less than a prostitution of the basic parliamentary principle that the expenditure of public moneys should be subject to freely accessible public scrutiny.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.40 p.m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: English Language Intensive Courses for Overseas Students

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 17 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Chinese students are studying in Australia under the ELICOS (English language intensive courses for overseas students) program in 1990.
(2) How many of the Chinese students in Australia studying under the ELICOS scheme overstayed their term.
(3) How will an upsurge in the number of students entering Australia under the ELICOS scheme and overstaying affect the Government's present immigration policy.
(4) Are some of the ELICOS institutions acting as de facto immigration agencies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department estimates that in June 1990 there were some 44,400 nationals of the People's Republic of China (PRC) temporarily in Australia, most of whom would have arrived as ELICOS students. Of this number:
- some 19,400 were here on 20 June 1989 and have not since departed or been granted permanent residence (eg through marriage);

- the balance of 25,000 is the net number of arrivals after 20 June 1989 less departures and change of status cases. This figure is based on actual numbers to February 1990 and estimates for arrivals for the period March to June 1990.

The Department of Employment, Education and Training advises that as at the end of April 1990, some 9,200 Chinese students were studying in Australia under the ELICOS program. Other PRC nationals would either be in other non-formal course studies, formal course studies, or be dependants of students or in other temporary entry categories.

(2) Latest figures available on student overstayers in Australia are as at 31 December 1989. Of all Chinese ELICOS students who arrived in Australia between July 1987 and December 1989, some 4,000 were still in Australia as overstayers on 31 December 1989.
It should be noted that earlier this year the Government offered all PRC nationals in Australia on 20 June 1989 whether here legally or illegally an opportunity to remain until January 1991.

(3) The number of ELICOS overstayers has been studied by an Interdepartmental Committee which has recently reviewed non-formal student entry to Australia. As a result of this review, the Government announced on 30 July 1990 a major overhaul of policy. The new provisions which are to be implemented on 1 January 1991, are aimed at ensuring that only genuine students enter Australia and that the ELICOS industry is properly regulated via Commonwealth legislation.
The Government announced its detailed response to the specific issue of PRC students seeking to remain in Australia on 27 June 1990.
