TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are seven Ministerial councils or similar forums in this portfolio.
(2) The names of these are as follows:
- Australian Minerals and Energy Council (AMEC)
- Australian Forestry Council
- Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council (MDBMC)
- Australian Water Resources Council (AWRC)
- Australian Agricultural Council (AAC)
- West Australia Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council (WAIOICC)
- Australian Fisheries Council
The general objectives of AMEC are:
``To promote the general welfare and progressive development of the Australian mining and mining industry and to consult on the nation's energy needs, resources and policies''.
The general objectives of the Australian Forestry Council are:
- to promote the management of Australian forests for the benefit of the people of Australia
- to advance the welfare and development of the industries based upon these forests
- to facilitate exchange of information between parties interested in all the uses and the protection of the forests
- to facilitate consultation and co-ordination between the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments on forestry matters, especially matters having interstate or national implications
- to formulate and recommend national forest policy for Australia
- to co-ordinate research into all aspects of forestry including the uses of forests and forest products.
The general objectives of the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council (MDBMC) are, as defined by Clause 7b of the Murray-Darling Basin Agreement:

``The function of the Ministerial Council shall be the general oversight and control over the major policy issues of common interest to the Contracting Governments (Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia) in relation to the Murray-Darling Basin''.
The major policy objective, as agreed by Council at its first meeting, is defined as:
``To promote and coordinate effective planning and management for equitable, efficient and sustainable use of its land, water and other environmental resources''.
The general objectives of Australian Water Resources Council (AWRC) are:
- to act as the peak forum of the Australian water industry
- to enhance the long-term management of the water industry and water resources for the benefit of the community
- to enhance the effectiveness and efficiency of the water industry and the services it provides.

The general objectives of the Australian Agricultural Council (AAC) were spelt out at the time of the Council's establishment in 1934; the functions have been reviewed from time to time but have remained unchanged since 1934:
- generally to promote the welfare and development of agricultural industries
- to arrange the mutual exchange of information regarding agricultural production and marketing
- to co-operate for the purposes of ensuring the improvement of the quality of agricultural products, and the maintenance of high-grade standards
- to ensure, as far as possible, balance between production and available markets
- to consider the requirements of agricultural industries, in regard to organised marketing
- to promote the adoption of a uniform policy on external marketing problems, particularly those pertaining to the negotiation of international agreements
- to consult in regard to proposals for the grant of financial assistance to agricultural industries
- to consider matters submitted to the Council by the Standing Committee on Agriculture.
The general objectives of the West Australia Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council (WAIOICC) are to provide:
- a means of consultation between Government, unions and employers on matters concerning the iron ore industry
- information to all concerned on iron ore industry matters
- a forum for working out by consensus procedures in industrial relations and industrial practices.
The general objectives of the Australian Fisheries Council are to:
- promote the welfare and development of the Australian fishing industry
- arrange the mutual exchange of information regarding fisheries production and marketing
- co-operate for the purpose of ensuring the improvement of the quality of fisheries products and the maintenance of high-grade standards
- co-operate for the purpose of ensuring uniform management policy
- consider the requirements of the Australian fishing industry in regard to production and marketing
- promote the adoption of a uniform policy on external marketing problems, particularly those pertaining to the negotiation of intra-Commonwealth and international agreements

- consider matters submitted to the Council by the Standing Committee on Fisheries.

Prior to that the Commonwealth provided a secretariat service for all meetings, although this was provided through existing resources of the Department of Resources and Energy and its predecessors.
The Australian Forestry Council is serviced by a Secretariat of two staff, located within the Forestry Branch of the Land Resources Division (Department of Primary Industries and Energy).
Costs associated with the Secretariat include salaries, travel (this varies according to where the meetings are to be held), printing of resolutions and general administration costs.

Secretariat services for the MDBMC have been provided by the Office of the Murray-Darling Basin Commission (MDBC) since 1 January 1988. There are no discrete secretariat staff as the secretariat function is performed within the overall activities of the MDBC while discharging its responsibilities under the Murray-Darling Basin Agreement.

Operating costs of the MDBC are apportioned between the four Contracting Governments in accordance with the Agreement. There is no discrete allocation of funds for the Secretariat function within the Commission's estimates.
Prior to 1 January 1988 Secretariat services were provided by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) and the former Department of Resources and Energy.

The Secretariat for the Australian Water Resources Council (AWRC) and its Standing Committee is provided by the Water Branch (DPIE). The total staff resources allocated to the Secretariat is approximately 1.5 staff which includes administration of the AWRC publication program.
A recent audit report (1989) estimated that the total staff costs (including estimated on-costs) were $78,017 per annum.

The Australian Agricultural Council (AAC) is serviced by a Secretariat in the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE). The Secretariat consists of three officers and is financed by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Costs associated with the Secretariat include salaries, travel (this varies accordingly to where the meetings are to be held), printing of resolutions and general administration costs.

The West Australia Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council (WAIOICC) consists of a Secretariat located in Perth, and currently comprises an Executive Officer, an Education Officer and a Stenographer. The Council's expenditure in 1989-90 was $360,000, shared equally by both Governments.

The Australian Fisheries Council Secretariat is provided by the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Costs associated with the Secretariat include salaries, travel (this varies according to where the meetings are to be held), printing of resolutions and general administration costs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, upon notice, on 19 July 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With regard to the Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women's submission to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology Inquiry into Small Business which recommends that: (a) the Small Business Association be used by government to disseminate information to members; (b) access to the conciliation and arbitration system be granted to small business representatives; and (c) a review of Federal and State Governments' taxation of small businesses be undertaken, particularly provisional tax and prescribed payments, what action has the Minister taken to address these matters to help women in small business.
(2) Can the Minister advise how many women are proprietors of small businesses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Report on Small Business in Australia prepared by the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology and released in February 1990, addressed many of the issues for small business in Australia. Many recommendations of the report respond to concerns raised by the Federation of Business and Professional Women, including taxation reform, a review of finance for small business, superannuation, and industrial relations.

Business associations, including the Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women, have been involved in consultations and have provided input helpful to the Government in formulating its response to the Report. The Minister for Small Business and Customs expects to be able to table the Government's response to the Report in the Budget sittings.
In relation to the particular areas of concern raised by the honourable senator:

(1) (a) The responsibility for the delivery of most small business programs is at State and Territory level through relevant small business agencies. Most communications will therefore take place at that level. The Commonwealth, for its part, will be examining the particular recommendations raised in the Report about improved communications.

(1) (b) In respect of access to the conciliation and arbitration system, I am advised that under the Industrial Relations Act 1988 employers, including those operating small businesses, are entitled to appear before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) either as an individual employer or as part of an organisation of employers registered under the Act. To register as an employer organisation, the applicant members must employ, on aggregate, at least 1000 employees unless the designated Presidential Member is satisfied that special circumstances justify the association's registration.

Any small business may gain access to the AIRC by way of a right to notify a dispute under s.99 of the Act; and/or participation in the award making process in settlement of the dispute. In addition, a small business which is not a party to a proceeding may, under s.43 of the Act, seek leave of the AIRC to intervene in the proceedings.
(1) (c) In relation to the matters of Commonwealth taxation put forward by the Federation, this also will be the subject of Government consideration.

(2) There are 248,700 female business proprietors according to Australian Bureau of Statistics 1988, Small Business in Australia 1983-84 to 1986-87, ABS, Canberra. These women represent more than one third of all business proprietors. An update on this information is currently being prepared for publication by ABS and should be available later this year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status for Women, upon notice, on 12 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the fact that women make up only 5 per cent of the total number of Commonwealth car drivers in Australia, with only 22 out of a total of 489.
(2) Is it that there are few female applicants for these positions, or is this inherent in governmental procedures that discriminate against women either by dissuasion or in the interview process.

(3) Is it that the Government's internal procedures do not promote women into these positions, or is it that there are no equal employment opportunity guidelines in place for Commonwealth car drivers.
(4) As the Minister responsible for the Status of Women, has the Minister given consideration to implementing a campaign to recruit more women; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The latest figures available from the Transport and Storage Group (TSG) of the Department of Administrative Services are that at 9 August 1990 there were 479 male and 22 female Commonwealth car drivers in Australia.

(2) I have been informed by the TSG that female car drivers were first employed in 1984 following press advertisements around Australia. They advise that since 1984, 66 males and 4 females have been employed as car drivers from within the Department, and 79 males and 19 females have been employed from outside TSG.
The number of women appointed over that period was proportionally higher in relation to the number of their applications than for men.
The selection criteria do not discriminate against women and TSG has continued to appoint women as and when vacancies arise. It should be noted that the number of vacancies which arise is very small.
(3) TSG follows the Equal Employment Opportunity guidelines of the Government and has ensured that women are given every opportunity for employment when vacancies arise.
There have been, however, a few occasions when the need to redeploy longstanding employees from other areas of TSG has meant that males have been placed as car drivers.

(4) Given that the number of Commonwealth car drivers to be recruited in the near future is unlikely to be significant, it would not be appropriate to conduct a campaign to increase the number of female drivers.
